name: TRATT.USHIGORO Ebisu
reviews: Everything is great! It really matches the rating given at Google map. Food quality is excellent, incl the draft beers (highly recommended) and the salad (5 star), not to mention the meat quality. The service personnel is patient to communicate with us as we don‚Äôt speak Japanese at all. We were recommended what is good and fit us (instead of what is most expensive and the more the better). It‚Äôs a new place so the environment is nice and cozy. V spacey. We are so glad that we made the right choice!

We had the set menu came with a bunch of different wagyu cuts, some were grilled by the staff, some we grilled ourselves.

The plum wine was absolutely incredible, would highly recommend to everyone.

The atmosphere was cozy, ceilings are low, so watch out for your heads!

3 people (one who doesn‚Äôt yakiniku) for ¬•16,000. The boys say it was absolutely delish. I don‚Äôt eat beef but had kimchi, cold noodles ( so so so good) and the seaweed soup. English menu available & staff were very friendly. Make sure to make a reservation ahead of time.

I recently visited this new spot in Ebisu, and I must say it offers high-quality meat at a very reasonable price, especially considering the area. The service was excellent, and I‚Äôm already looking forward to my next visit!

Was recommended to visit this place by a close friend and sampled some of the best cuts of beef I have ever tasted. Everything was high in quality and the service by the staff was impeccable. Without a doubt, One of my favorite meal in Tokyo.

name: RUMBLE CRUMBLE Ê∏ãË∞∑Êú¨Â∫ó
reviews:
‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è
I absolutely loved my visit to RUMBLE CRUMBLE Ê∏ãË∞∑Êú¨Â∫ó! From the moment I walked in, the shop‚Äôs charm and attention to detail stood out ‚Äî it‚Äôs a beautifully curated space in the heart of Shibuya/Harajuku that‚Äôs perfect for both casual treats and special occasions.

The cookies here are truly exceptional. They have this amazing contrast of textures ‚Äî crisp and golden on the outside, yet soft and moist inside ‚Äî which immediately tells you these aren‚Äôt your average sweets. The flavours are rich but balanced, and you can really taste the high-quality ingredients in every bite. People rave online about how these cookies are worth tracking down even outside the usual snack spots, and I completely agree!  Ôøº

What‚Äôs great is that the shop carries a wide variety of options, including classic cookies and the more indulgent cookie cakes that you can only get in-store. They‚Äôre perfect for gifts or sharing, and make for irresistibly delicious souvenirs after a day exploring Tokyo.  Ôøº

Another amazing thing I learned is that this brand has serious creative roots ‚Äî crafted with care and originally gaining popularity online for being hard to get ‚Äî so finally having a physical store where you can taste them fresh is a real treat.  Ôøº

Friendly service, great ambience, and some of the best cookies I‚Äôve ever had in Tokyo. Whether you‚Äôre a local or visiting from overseas, this place deserves every one of its five stars!
Nice place for good and fresh cookies they are freshly made and not too sweet. They have so many different flavours for each taste

Great atmosphere and really pretty shop but the cookies are overpriced and just not that good unfortunately. I got a classic chocolate chip and though it was warm, it had little to no flavor and then left a bad after taste. I hope the store improves their recipes.

This shop is a charming place to buy cookies. The staff member was friendly and provided great recommendations. Although the cookies are a bit pricey, it‚Äôs clear that they are freshly baked and have a homemade quality. You can definitely tell the difference compared to mass-produced cookies, and this shop stands out.

The variations of cookies give you a lot of choices. The staff are friendly and very helpful, and they can recommend what cookies to choose if you have trouble picking what to get. The price I think is a bit steep for what it is- the cookies are delicious, but still overpriced for a cookie. They are great as a nice gift, but I probably wouldn't be buying them for myself.

name: Oishi Park
reviews:
Oishi Park, Kawaguchi Lake is a very beautiful park and one of the best places to see Mount Fuji clearly. On a good day, the Fuji view from here is really amazing and very close.

Even without Mount Fuji view, this park is still very beautiful. There are many flowers and plants, depending on the season, so it‚Äôs nice just to walk around and enjoy the colors and nature.

There are also some restaurants and cafes in the park area, so you can sit, eat, or drink while enjoying the view. Quite relaxing.

I really recommend coming here for sunrise. Mount Fuji looks very beautiful with the orange sunshine, the atmosphere feels calm and special. Early morning, cold a bit, but totally worth it.

If you visit Kawaguchi Lake, Oishi Park is a place you should not miss.

One of the Most Breathtaking Views of Mt. Fuji! A Must-Visit in Kawaguchiko!

Oishi Park is truly one of the most stunning and peaceful places I have ever visited. Located along the shores of Lake Kawaguchiko, the park offers a perfect, postcard-worthy view of Mt. Fuji‚Äîso clear and majestic that it almost feels unreal.

The combination of the lake, seasonal flowers, and Fuji in the background creates scenery that changes beautifully throughout the year. Whether it‚Äôs the vibrant lavender fields in summer, the bright kochia bushes in autumn, or the crisp, clear winter views, every season has its own magic here.

The park is clean, spacious, and extremely well-maintained. Walking through the flower-lined paths is relaxing and perfect for photography lovers. It‚Äôs one of those rare places where you can simply sit, breathe, and enjoy nature without any rush.

What I loved most is how accessible and visitor-friendly it is‚Äîplenty of benches, cute caf√©s and souvenir shops nearby, and wide-open spaces to explore at your own pace.

If you‚Äôre visiting Kawaguchiko, Oishi Park is absolutely a must-visit location. The view of Mt. Fuji from here is one of the best you‚Äôll ever see, and the entire atmosphere is peaceful, refreshing, and unforgettable. I left with so many beautiful photos and an even more beautiful memory.

üìç Oishi Park Â§ßÁü≥ÂÖ¨Âúí
@ Kawaguchiko, Yamanashi üáØüáµ

We first visited Oishi Park (Â§ßÁü≥ÂÖ¨Âúí) on 18 November 2025 around 4:15pm. The sunset light over Lake Kawaguchi was warm and gentle, although a cloud covered the top of Mount Fuji üóª. The lower half of Fuji was still visible, giving the scene a soft, dramatic mood. The lakeside walkway, flower beds, and open viewing area made it a peaceful place to unwind before evening.

The free parking beside the park is very convenient, and it‚Äôs only a short stroll to the lake viewpoint, caf√©, and small shops.

On the second day in the morning, we visited Oishi Park again ‚Äî and this time, the weather was clear enough that we finally captured Mount Fuji in full view. The crisp morning air, calm lake surface, and bright natural light created the perfect scene. Seeing Fuji clearly after the previous day‚Äôs cloud cover made the moment extra special.

A relaxing lakeside park with stunning Fuji views ‚Äî beautiful during sunset, and absolutely rewarding when Fuji appears clearly on a bright morning. üóªüåÖ‚ú®

Oishi Park is a beautiful and well-maintained place with stunning views of Mount Fuji and Lake Kawaguchiko. The scenery is peaceful, clean, and perfect for a relaxing walk or taking photos at any time of day.

For getting around the Kawaguchiko area, I highly recommend buying the one-day pass for the sightseeing bus. It allows unlimited hop-on hop-off rides and makes it easy to explore popular spots along the Red Line, Green Line, and Blue Line.

Another great option is renting a bicycle. Many rental shops offer bikes for around 2,000 yen per day, which is perfect if you want to explore the area at a slower, more flexible pace.

Oishi Park is one of the most beautiful spots around Lake Kawaguchi to enjoy a clear and unobstructed view of Mount Fuji. The park is very well maintained with colorful seasonal flowers that change throughout the year, making it perfect for photography and a relaxing stroll.

The walking paths are clean and easy to explore, with benches where you can sit and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere. There are also small shops and cafes nearby selling local snacks, souvenirs, and ice cream, which is great for a short break while enjoying the scenery.

This place is especially stunning on a clear day when Mount Fuji appears in full view behind the flower fields ‚Äî truly postcard-worthy. Highly recommended for nature lovers, photographers, and anyone visiting the Kawaguchiko area.

A must-visit spot if you want one of the best Mount Fuji views in Japan!
address: ÔºíÔºïÔºíÔºïÁï™Âú∞„ÅÆÔºëÔºëÂÖà ≈åishi, Fujikawaguchiko, Minamitsuru District, Yamanashi 401-0305, Japan

name: Ubuyagasaki Shrine
reviews: A small shrine next to the bridge that offers a great view of the lake and Mt. Fuji. You have to climb a few stairs to reach the shrine. I highly recommend if you are biking or walking around the area.
Wonderful Shrine with a fantastic view of awesome Fujisan. I feel so fortunate to have been to this view. Thank you to keeps this area up.
Went there at about 6 am for a really nice view
Hidden spot up a hill with some very tiny stairs. You'll see amazing trees and leaves. Be careful going up, it's very steep. Once there you can get a great view and see a tiny shrine.

Highly recommended place for photo shooters.
You need to find a trail walk down by the lake. Then you will find you peace here.
address: 1 Azagawa, Fujikawaguchiko, Minamitsuru District, Yamanashi 401-0304, Japan

name: Mount Yoshino
reviews: Best place to see a mountain full of cherry blossom. Lovely mountain with great scenery. The place is very clean and very well taken care. There are restaurants and cafe in the area with great view. Best to ride the ropeway going up and just walk down later when going home. Bus is another option.
A peaceful mountain for a spiritual journey. There is a great view from up here. Its great for fall and spring

Mount Yoshino in spring is a dream come true for cherry blossom lovers. The mountainside covered in thousands of blooming sakura trees is one of the most beautiful sights in Japan. The views from the top are simply breathtaking!

Mesmerizing and breathtaking place. One of the best places in Japan for Sakura (Cherry blossom viewing). Hiking in Mount Yoshino is an amazing experience. It is nice to have food at the viewpoint by watching these beautiful Cherry blossom.
- 09-Apr-2025

Undoubtedly one of the best places in Japan for sakura viewing. Went there today on 6th April, 2025. All photos were captured on that day.
After arriving at Yoshino station from Osaka Abenobashi, we took the shuttle bus to Nakasenbon (15-20 mints ride) and walked till the Hanayaguru observatory (1.5 Km from Nakasenbon bus point) to have an unobstructed view of the entire Yoshino town all the way till the Kinpunsen ji Temple. However, the cherry blossoms in the Kamisenbon area around the viewpoint were just opening. Walked down the mountain to the rail station thereafter in around 2 hours (4.5 Km) while soaking in all the superb views.
address: Mount Yoshino, Yoshinoyama, Yoshino, Yoshino District, Nara 639-3115, Japan

name: Katsudon-ya Zuicho
reviews:
As good as I remembered it 9 years ago. They have branded t-shirts now, more staff and a better system for getting into the restaurant. But the quality is still there. We got there around 6pm and the line wasn‚Äôt too bad.

Juicy katsu, delicious sweet sauce, perfect katsudon runny egg. Just wonderfully made and comfort food Katsudon.

Cash is ideal and there is only one item on the menu, it is pricy for what it is but totally worth it.

Katsudon-ya Zuicho is a must every time I visit Tokyo! Their katsudon is just perfect. Not too soggy, with crispy pork, perfectly cooked eggs, and a nicely balanced sweet-salty sauce. The place is small with limited seating, so you‚Äôll probably have to wait in line, but it‚Äôs totally worth it.

Waited at least an hour prior to opening, and noticed only tourists are lining up which is not a good sign. No interaction with the waitress who serves the food as they all seems in bad mood. Only the person who took our order outside during the lineup was nice and welcoming. The cutlet was thin and either poorly trimmed or wasn‚Äôt the best quality because cannot even swallow the greasy parts like other katsudon place. Food is very average and not as impressive as per the reviews. Personally find this place is overhyped

JPY 1500 for a bowl of Katstudong with a small bottle of Sapporo.

I was at the bar counter observing the kitchen's operation first hand.
With a max of 8-seating space, each client spent approx 15 mins of eating then the staff gave a signal to bring new clients in and lining up waiting for me to leave so I had to finish my beer very instantly.  Cask only by the way!

The queue was managed very efficiently. Photo of cooking and staff is prohibited.

It was a 40-min queue with max of 15 minutes each individual customer was allowed to finish their food before getting checked.

My advice üëá
If you expect to enjoy the atmosphere and relaxing or chatting with your friends, look away.

For a solo or a couple, the Katstudong is very good, definitely worth queuing.

The food was great, especially the sauce on top. It combined the sweetness from the sauce perfectly well with the saltiness from the katsu and the rice balanced the entire meal superbly.

However, I would imagine that you can find something quite similar without having to stand in line for nearly an hour. During our meal there were seats free, because the people that were first in line outnumbered the number of available seats. I would suggest to actually let smaller companies to pass ahead then as that would speed up the queueing.
So with the considerable wait in mind I feel like 4 is as high as I will be able to give.

name: Ishiura Shrine
reviews: Stopped by late in afternoon on a November weekday and it was quiet.  Walked through small but pretty set of Tori gates and found small spot to sit by little waterfall.  No one was around so that really added to this review.  Serene and peaceful.  Not sure it would be as nice if crowded.  I would stop if it looked quiet out front as the entry off street is not that spectacular.

2025/11/03

It was a rainy Culture Day. But the staff here warmly received me. This shrine is across the 21st Century Museum of Art. There are lots of cute charms here, and I also received a beautiful Goshuin as well.

It is said to have been founded during the Kofun period, making it the oldest shrine in Kanazawa. It has a truly sacred atmosphere. Visiting at night, the place felt solemn and even a little awe-inspiring.

We love dogs! I had high expectations of this temple before visiting. Very happy to see the dog sign and the cute little shrine. However the shop in the shed (not the one inside) left a bad taste at the end. I picked 2 lucky charms which had a clear sign of ‚Äú1000 yen‚Äù next to the box and handed 2000 yen, the lady said I need to pay 3000, because the little dog charm attached is charged for 500 yen separately. She asked if I wanted the doggie charms taken off. It‚Äôs such an obvious con towards tourists‚Ä¶ we walked away immediately‚Ä¶ first time to experience this in Japan. :(

Definitely worth a visit and bring water can it can be a hot hike depending on the weather. It can be crowded but the higher you go the less people there are and the more beautiful it gets. Worth a visit if you are in Kyoto.

name: Arashiyama Bamboo Forest
reviews:
The Beauty of the Arashiyama Bamboo Grove
‚ÄãA Vertical Cathedral: The towering stalks of bamboo create a sense of infinite verticality. In the second image, looking up toward the sky, the interlocking canopy filters the sunlight, creating a "Komorebi" effect‚Äîwhere light dances through the leaves like a natural stained-glass window.
‚ÄãA Palette of Natural Tones: There is a beautiful contrast between the cool, silver-green hues of the bamboo culms and the warm, earthy browns of the traditional "Take-gaki" (bamboo branch fences). These fences don't just mark a path; they ground the ethereal forest in Japanese craftsmanship and history.
‚ÄãThe Sound of Silence (and Movement): Even in a still photo, you can almost hear the "clacking" of the stalks and the rustling leaves. The third image, showing visitors wandering through the path, highlights the scale of the grove‚Äîmaking the humans look small against the majesty of nature.
‚ÄãA Path of Contemplation: The winding dirt paths and the rhythmic patterns of the bamboo create a meditative atmosphere. It is a place where the bustling modern world (represented by the tourists) meets an ancient, towering stillness that feels frozen in time.

Visiting Arashiyama Bamboo Forest was one of those Kyoto moments that really stayed with me. Walking between the towering bamboo felt surreal, almost like stepping into another world where everything slows down. The way the light filters through the tall green stalks and the soft sound of the bamboo swaying in the wind creates a calm, almost meditative atmosphere that‚Äôs hard to find anywhere else.

I went early in the morning, which made a huge difference. It was quieter, cooler, and felt more peaceful before the crowds arrived. Taking my time along the path, I found myself just looking up, breathing it all in, and appreciating how simple yet powerful the scenery is. The walk itself isn‚Äôt very long, but it doesn‚Äôt need to be ‚Äî the experience is more about the feeling than the distance.

What I loved most is how close it is to other beautiful spots. After the bamboo forest, wandering around Arashiyama, crossing Togetsukyo Bridge, and grabbing a coffee nearby made the whole area feel like a perfect day out. Yes, it gets busy later on, but even then, the bamboo forest still feels special. It‚Äôs one of those places that reminds you why Kyoto is so unforgettable and why slowing down while traveling really matters.

Arashiyama Bamboo Forest Review (Expert Traveler Insight)

If you want to know what silence looks like, open the photos first. This is one of those rare places where the pictures tell half the story ‚Äî and the experience tells the rest. As an experienced traveler and detailed reviewer, I can confidently say Arashiyama Bamboo Forest stands among the most breathtaking natural walks I‚Äôve ever taken.

This forest isn‚Äôt just famous ‚Äî it deserves the hype. The towering bamboo creates a cathedral-like canopy that feels peaceful, almost spiritual. But here‚Äôs the real insider tip: take a rickshaw. Yes, it sounds touristy, but it‚Äôs actually the smartest way to explore. Your guide brings you through special inner routes that the general public cannot access, helping you avoid the crowds entirely. They also take incredible photos for you ‚Äî shots you simply cannot get on your own.

Beyond the forest, the surrounding market area, fall colors, and side streets add even more to the experience. Plan for at least 4‚Äì6 hours to enjoy it without rushing, and make sure you dress for the weather as it can feel cooler under the bamboo.

This was one of the most unforgettable parts of our Japan trip ‚Äî peaceful, iconic, and absolutely worth every minute. Don‚Äôt leave Kyoto without experiencing this.

Quite crowded but a beautiful area. It is worthwhile also visiting the Snow Monkey Park as well to round off the trip. Local river is stunning with greater and lesser Egrets and cormorants. Also had fun hiring a kimono and walking around the temples and villages with the red maple leaves. I would say that if you wanted a quieter tranquil bamboo forest the side hike up to Mt Inari near Tori gates was more serene.

Best is to arrive before 10 am due to crowds.
If you want to do the train ride üöÇ you should book in advance and the boat ride üõ∂ we couldn‚Äôt do due to cold weatherü•∂

You can walk towards Otagi temple, it‚Äôs quite scenic neighborhood and also less crowded. On the way you‚Äôll have coffee/tea spots üçµ ‚òïÔ∏è see my other reviews to see which one i recommend!
address: Sagaogurayama Tabuchiyamacho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto, 616-8394, Japan

name: F≈´unji Shinjuku
reviews:
Very good tsukemen restaurant. My friend and I ordered the largest portion of noodles you can probably order in one sitting, and it seems like you can even add more later if you want. The noodles in the middle of the stack were a bit on the colder side, but the dipping sauce was extremely flavorful and made up for it.

The female staff member in picture who helped us was very kind, and watching the whole team work was honestly impressive. Everyone was professional, efficient, and clearly knew their roles, working together smoothly even in a small, tightly spaced restaurant. The food was great, but seeing how hardworking and dedicated the staff were made the experience even better.

You cannot go wrong ordering the dipping ramen here (tsukemen). Absolutely delicious. You can adjust the thickness/saltiness of the dipping broth with the hot water kettle provided in front of you. The line moves fast. Come 15 min early before opening if you want to avoid it.

Incredible tsukemen at F≈´unji in Shinjuku! The rich, savory dipping broth was thick and umami-packed, perfectly paired with chewy noodles. Toppings like tender chashu and a soft-boiled egg added extra depth, and finishing the broth with hot stock was a nice touch. So happy we had this as our last meal before rushing to the airport‚Äîrisky timing, but totally worth it! Tiny counter-only space with a short queue, but a must-visit for tsukemen lovers.

Authentic little ramen restaurant. Ramen is more delicious than Tsukemen(Dipping noodles)as the soup is a bit too salty for me.

Overall the ramen is not bad but just average quality no surprise.

We accidentaly came to this popular ramen shop. But to our taste buds, it is not good and broth too salty. We don't mind about about the atmosphere, it is small and giving authentic Japanese ramen bar vibes which is good. The service was also okay, there were about 3-4 staff when were there and they seem nice but always on a rush. We came when they just opened and we didn't know it was popular, there were already a line after 15 minutes. There are ony 4 items in the menu, 2 traditional ramen and 2 Tsukumen (dipping noodles).
There are 4 of us in the family and each got a ramen and none of us finished! We didn't liked it, as it was too salty. Maybe it is different on some other days? maybe it was the ambiance that made it popular? There are alot of ramen shops around Tokyo, maybe some are not so good, but definitely not too salty.

name: Gotemba Premium Outlets
reviews:
üìç Gotemba Premium Outlets
Âæ°ÊÆøÂ†¥„Éó„É¨„Éü„Ç¢„É†„Éª„Ç¢„Ç¶„Éà„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà @ Shizuoka, Japan üáØüáµ

We visited Gotemba Premium Outlets on 19 November 2025, and even though I‚Äôm not a big fan of shopping, the visit was surprisingly pleasant. The outlet is spacious, clean, and very well-organised, with wide walkways, rest areas, caf√©s, and plenty of food options.

The mall is separated into three main zones ‚Äî West Zone, East Zone, and Hill Zone ‚Äî each offering different brands and experiences. The layout is easy to navigate, and the walk between zones is comfortable, with clear signage throughout.

There are plenty of brands to browse, including sportswear, outdoor gear, fashion, lifestyle goods, cosmetics, and premium labels. Sizes were widely available, which is convenient for travellers. Families will appreciate the LEGO store, as well as several kids‚Äô wear shops. It‚Äôs also a good place to explore Japan-made brands like Onitsuka (Onitsuka Tiger).

The parking lot is huge and well-managed, making arrival and departure smooth. Although the outlet is known for its beautiful Mount Fuji views, the weather was cloudy during our visit, so we were unable to see Fuji this time.

A large, organised outlet divided into West, East, and Hill Zones ‚Äî offering plenty of brands, kids‚Äô stores, LEGO, Japan-made Onitsuka, and a huge parking area. Enjoyable even for non-shoppers. üõçÔ∏è‚õÖ‚ú®

A great shopping destination with an amazing view of Mount Fuji on a clear day. There are plenty of shops with a wide variety of brands, and it‚Äôs easy to spend half a day here without feeling rushed.

The outlet is spacious and well laid out, making it comfortable to walk around while shopping. Overall, a nice balance of shopping, dining, and scenery.

Definitely worth a visit if you‚Äôre in the area and want to shop with a Mt Fuji backdrop. üóªüõçÔ∏è

It's outlet mall. I just stopped by one part to buy a shoes, so I didn't check them all, but it seems like so huge. Anyway you can see the Fuji mountain from here and can shop. I think if you want to take a look all area then you may need whole one day.

This mall is one of the best outlet malls. It‚Äôs huge with more than two hundred stores including luxury brands. The luxury brands are a lot cheaper than other outlets which is why this mall is so popular. Since the mall is huge, I‚Äôd recommend getting a map for your shopping direction. I would say one day is not enough for this mall.
Moreover, there is an amazing view of Mount Fuji. You can see it clearly from the mall.
There is a lot of parking if you plan to drive there. It was easy to find a parking spot even though I got there in the afternoon.

A massive, beautiful mall with tons of stores‚Äîfrom high-end to casual‚Äîand fantastic sales. The shopping is great, but the view of Mount Fuji is unforgettable!

We arrived around 2 PM on a clear day and got perfect, bright photos of the mountain with no clouds. Do bring your passport for tax-free savings!

name: Iwatake Gondola NOAH
reviews:
We hopped on the ÁôΩÈ¶¨Â≤©Â≤≥„Ç¥„É≥„Éâ„É©„É™„Éï„Éà at the „Éé„Ç¢Â±±È∫ìÈßÖ during our stay in Hakuba, and it turned out to be one of those simple delights you don‚Äôt expect but absolutely enjoy. The station at the base feels cozy and modern, with friendly staff helping us load our bikes and gear for the ride.

As the gondola climbed, we were treated to sweeping views of pine forests, rolling valleys, and distant snow-capped peaks. It‚Äôs quiet and smooth, offering a moment to breathe in the alpine air and take in the calm beauty of the area. We went during a clear day, and those mountain vistas‚Äîpristine, green, and vast‚Äîfelt like a postcard come to life.

At the top, the platform offers great vantage points, easy trails, and plenty of spots to pause, stretch, or snap photos. We didn‚Äôt ride bikes this time, but watching others cycle down the slopes below added a fun energy to the experience.

The ride itself isn‚Äôt long‚Äîmaybe 10‚Äì15 minutes‚Äîbut it‚Äôs enough to lift your spirits and connect you to Hakuba‚Äôs dramatic mountain landscape. It‚Äôs a perfect balance of convenience and natural beauty, making it a must-do for anyone staying at the foot of Mount Iwatake.
The view from the top is absolutely beautiful, but you have to take a cable car to get there. It was raining on the day I went, so I didn't get to see much of the view.

A nice gondola ride up to the peak of Iwatake. At the top there‚Äôs a restaurant, cafe, and dog park plus the start of a bunch of ski slopes. I went around 11am and it was packed. Gave up on the cafe. Nice views and a scary ride up and down made the 2,400¬• round trip worth it.
Good place so beautiful on the top of mountain have a lot of activities
Best gondola in Hakuba valley, good views on way up until we were in the cloud.
address: 12056 Hokuj≈ç, Hakuba, Kitaazumi District, Nagano 399-9301, Japan

name: Guj≈ç-Hachiman Station
reviews: A historic station that has coin lockers and tourist information center that provides bicycle rental which I highly recommend. During the all night odori days mid-august, there are early morning trains you can take to Mino-Ota direction. Everyone managed to board. However, you may want to leave the festival just a bit earlier if you really need to sit or sleep during the train ride after a long and engaging night.

Gujo Hachiman Station exudes a nostalgic, vintage Japanese charm that transports one back in time.  In addition to being a train station, it features a welcoming caf√© where you may unwind or even rent bicycles to explore the charming town.  Small stores, hygienic restrooms, and useful signage are all present.  Additionally, the station is the starting point for two bus routes that conveniently link to important locations in Gujo Hachiman, particularly Jokamachi Plaza. It is a peaceful, practical, and friendly location that makes visiting this old town more enjoyable.
This small train station has a bus stop and a taxi stop right outside. There‚Äôs also a small restaurant, vending machines, and a clean restroom. Everything you need is conveniently located there.

A small station with a unique charm. A small gift shop is located inside the wooden structure which is close to most of the city being a small yet gorgeous place to visit. The station certainly helps that image.

Pretty cool wood station.
Local souvenirs available.
Friendly staff.

Eki stamps and Tetsuin for the Local train line available here!!

name: Zenk≈çji temple
reviews:
Beautiful temple! It‚Äôs a great area to visit and not far from Nagano Station. You can catch bus number 1 from the front of the station. There‚Äôs plenty of local food and souvenirs available. Don‚Äôt miss out on the Oyaki and Apple Pie

they are Nagano‚Äôs famous specialties

This is the most extraordinary Buddhist temple I have ever visited.
As soon as I checked into my hotel, I went for a walk around the city and eventually reached this temple. The moment I arrived, I was enveloped by an overwhelming feeling of happiness ‚Äî happiness of the highest kind. It was simply indescribable, unlike anything I have ever felt before. Such beauty and such purity.

I attended the morning services every day during my stay in Nagano. They were incredibly beautiful and deeply moving. I felt that I came into contact with something beyond words.

During the services, I met wonderful people who gently guided me and explained what to do. I received a morning blessing from the o-j≈çsama, when he touches you with prayer beads. It is believed that this touch can replace many hours of spiritual practice, as he passes on his accumulated merit to you.

Please take the time to read about this temple ‚Äî it is truly remarkable. You can feel the power of prayer there, along with the beauty of this world in its purest form.

It was here that I decided to begin collecting temple stamps (goshuin). I bought my first goshuin book at this temple, as well as several amulets for my loved ones.

Went here as an unplanned visit after arriving in Nagano and being told that the snow monkeys were not in the onsen after arriving at Nagano Station. It turned out to be a wonderful surprise, and the Zenk≈çji temple is definitely well worth a visit. Went in the afternoon around 2pm just as the sun was going down, which gave a special light to the area. There is both an element of gravitas as a place of worship and a memorial site. Several Japanese locals visited to pay religious respects, including many elderly Japanese citizens who likely have familial ties to the place.
The grounds are serene and well maintained and the walk up the cobblestoned path feels almost like a pilgrimage.

A lot of locals walk and carry dogs in prams. A pitbull in a pram/dress, a manicured sausage dog with knitted hats. A husky in a full dress. Many locals in kimono. The foodstalls felt a bit out of place on the walk up the hill, but the other stores selling prayer materials and small souvenirs did feel vibrant and not too heavily commercialized.

November is a good time of year to go. The Japanese maples start to turn red, the crowds are too great and the temperature is crisp. It felt like a very authentic visit and one I would highly recommend.

It is a very beautiful temple, the experience of going through the dark tunnel was something I would  remember by.

A place for enlightenment
In the pitch-black tunnel below Zenkoji's Main Hall, we come to realize that all people are completely equal.
While groping in the darkness for the key to Paradise, free yourself of worldly thoughts, engage in self-reflection and even experience a spiritual awakening.

Visitors are allowed to go inside the temple. It was a good experience.
The shopping street is worth visiting as well. A few shops selling oyaki which are quite tasty. Other street food was available.

name: Narai-juku
reviews:
üìç Narai-juku Â•àËâØ‰∫ïÂÆø @ Nagano, Japan üáØüáµ

We visited Narai-juku on 13 November 2025, and it was one of the most charming and beautifully preserved post towns along the Nakasendo Trail. The nostalgic Edo-period atmosphere is felt immediately ‚Äî traditional wooden houses, quiet streets, and beautifully preserved architecture that feels like stepping back into old Japan.

The village is long and enjoyable to walk through, filled with craft shops, small cafes, and local eateries. We tried a bowl of tempura soba, which was warm, flavourful, and perfect for the cool autumn weather. Do note that restaurants can have a waiting time of around 20‚Äì30 minutes, especially during peak hours ‚Äî so plan to spend a bit more time if you intend to dine here.

We reached Narai-juku by following the signs and crossing the underground trainline from the nearby main parking area. The route was clear, well guided, and easy to follow.

Narai-juku is peaceful and less commercial compared to other post towns, giving it an authentic, relaxed atmosphere. In autumn, the surrounding mountains create a beautiful backdrop, enhancing the charm of the wooden streets.

A wonderful destination for:
‚Ä¢ üçú Local dishes like tempura soba
‚Ä¢ üì∏ Traditional Edo-style street photos
‚Ä¢ üõçÔ∏è Handcrafted wooden souvenirs
‚Ä¢ üö∂ Scenic village walking
‚Ä¢ üç° Local snacks
‚Ä¢ üèØ Experiencing historical Nakasendo culture

Overall, Narai-juku is a must-visit ‚Äî calm, scenic, and full of old-town character. Just be prepared for a 20‚Äì30 minute wait if you‚Äôre planning to eat here. üçÅüèòÔ∏è‚ú®

Narai-juku in Nagano is one of the most beautifully preserved post towns along the historic Nakasendo Trail and our visit on 6 December 2025 felt like stepping directly into the Edo period. The moment you enter the village the atmosphere changes. The long street lined with dark wooden houses the quiet rhythm of local life, and the sense of history that lingers in the air create an experience that is both peaceful and deeply nostalgic.

Walking through the town is a pleasure in itself. Each building has been carefully maintained, offering a rare glimpse into Japan‚Äôs architectural past. Many small craft shops display traditional wooden items, lacquerware and handmade souvenirs. The village also has several cosy tea houses and cafes where visitors can rest and appreciate the scenery.

We stopped for a warm bowl of tempura soba, which was rich, comforting, and perfect for the cool autumn afternoon. However, it is worth noting that restaurants in Narai-juku can get busy during peak hours, and waiting around twenty to thirty minutes is quite common. Despite the wait, the food and atmosphere make the experience worthwhile.

Reaching the village from the main parking area was easy. Clear signs guide visitors through an underground passage beneath the train line, leading directly to the start of the historic street. The route is simple and well marked.

Compared to other popular post towns, Narai-juku feels more authentic and less commercialized. The surrounding mountains, especially in autumn, create a beautiful backdrop that enhances the charm of the old wooden buildings. For anyone interested in history, traditional craftsmanship, or calm scenic walks, Narai-juku offers a wonderfully preserved piece of old Japan. It is a destination well worth exploring at a slow and thoughtful pace.

It‚Äôs about an hour drive from Matsumoto Castle. Historical town with beautiful Edo era architecture.  Well preserved wooden houses.  Lots of restaurants and small cafe along the Main Street. Not many souvenirs shops. Most shops sell Japanese lacquerware.

We stopped by in the afternoon while driving through from Lake Suwa, en route to Nagoya.
We enjoyed strolling through this rustic historic town, superbly preserved since the Edo period. The souvenir shops, restaurants and minshuku are worth exploring.
We sampled some of the snacks and sake,  and walked along the river and enjoyed stepping onto the timber bridge -Kiso Ohashi
This bridge crosses the Narai River, which runs parallel to the main street. Extending 30 meters, it is one of the longest wooden bridges in Japan. It was built quite recently, in the 1990s.

Our only regret is that we were a bit early for the glorious autumn colours as we were there in mid-October.

Wonderful place to visit although the P&P crowd (photo and pee) who stops here between train hours from-to Nagoya and Nagano can make it too touristy certain times of the day. If your schedule allows, stay overnight in one the inns ( we stayed in one right in the middle of town and it was fabulous). This way you can stroll through town during peaceful times in the evening and early morning when everything is closed and quiet. During the day you can enjoy going in and out of the shops and enjoying various snacks. See the place before it turns into a total tourist trap, which it's rapidly headed towards.

name: Tsukesoba Kanda Katsumoto
reviews:
It was actually my first time trying soba-style tsukemen, and honestly, I wasn't sure what to expect since I‚Äôm used to the super thick, heavy ramen broths.

This was totally different in the best way. The broth is clear and refined, not oily at all, with a really nice hit of yuzu and dried sardines (niboshi).

The coolest part is that they serve two types of noodles in one bowl: one is thin and smooth like traditional soba, and the other is a thicker, flatter noodle.

Super chill atmosphere inside too, very clean and peaceful. I didn‚Äôt have to wait as I got there when it‚Äôs almost closed.
Staff was great and kind. Restaurant looked nice. Noodles were greasy and mediocre, and the soup wasn't clear or full of seafood flavor (both advertised on the site)

I highly recommend this amazing tsukemen restaurant. They use two different types of ramen noodles. The different diameters really create a unique dipping ramen experience. If you order the deluxe bowl, you get chashu, pork belly and shrimp wontons. The pork belly was succulent. I added a dash of chili powder and vinegar for my broth. They have an English written menu to order at the kiosk. Note this place is cash only.

Phenomenal tsukemen here where they serve two different types of noodles in each order. One is white, thinner, and has a little less chew while the other is a thick, yellow, chewier noodle. Both are amazing. The fish and pork dipping broth is amazing and comes with chashu pork that‚Äôs been slightly charred with a torch before being served which adds an extra smoky depth to the meat and the broth. A must try for tsukemen lovers.

This restaurant is located around a university and it gets very busy around lunch time, even on a weekday. The lineup wasn‚Äôt too long as we waited around 30 mins, and lineups kept on going even after we got inside. You first order the dish you want on a machine; and if you can‚Äôt read Japanese, they have an English menu. The server who greeted us was very friendly and was helpful when we had questions. After ordering through the machine and getting the tickets, you can choose your seat and give the tickets to the chef. I highly recommend getting their signature dipping ramen.

The food came fairly quickly and the chefs were very happy when they gave us our food. The dipping ramen comes in thick or thin noodles, but I think you could ask for just thin or thick (not sure since we couldnt read Japanese). The ramen noodles were made fresh and very chewy, and the broth was so flavorful, yet wasn‚Äôt too salty. Make sure to not pour the whole soup inside the noodle bowl, you‚Äôre supposed to dip the noodles a bit at a time in the broth.

After finishing, the chef let me try the soup with a zist of lemon which was also very refreshing. I had a great experience and highly recommend visiting! The lineups are worth it :)

IG: Ayenomz

name: Ch≈´kasoba Katsumoto
reviews: My wife and I stopped by Ch≈´ka Soba Kihachi for lunch and really enjoyed the experience. The small wooden shop has a warm, nostalgic atmosphere, with an open kitchen where the chefs prepare each bowl right in front of you. We both ordered the Ajitama Ch≈´ka Soba, featuring a fragrant niboshi-shoyu broth, tender chashu, marinated egg, and springy noodles. The flavors were balanced‚Äîrich yet clean‚Äîand the presentation was simple but elegant. Service was efficient, and ordering by ticket machine was easy. A perfect spot for classic Tokyo-style ramen done with precision and care.
Ramen was excellent. The waiter explained me how everything works. The food was very tasty, price was good and it was quickly prepared. Beware that they only take cash. 10/10

The sister shop of the immensely famous ramen shop Ginza Hachigo

This ramen shop is most famous for its clear broth tsukemen offering two types of noodles of varying thickness; the noodles are smooth and go well with the clear broth

But the chasiu is somewhat lackluster in contrast

In a city known for good ramen places, Ramen Katsumoto excels in being one of the best.

Good broth and fresh ingredients prepared by the most expert hands. This is a must try for everyone.

Tip for the visitor: you come in, turn to the right and find the machine you order through. Place the money and push the button of your desired dish and add ons. Egg is good, tho most ramen come with egg already.

There is an english menu for those who need it.

I will surely come again. Thank you Chef.

Perfect place for casual ramen. The ramen was tasty with a generous portion of pork and noodles given. The broth was also perfectly done, not too heavy. Credits to the staff were extremely friendly. As tourists, they immediately greeted us and gave us an English menu and run down on how to order. Much appreciated!

name: Jimbocho Book Town
reviews:
Jimbocho Book Town is a unique and charming district that celebrates the love of books and culture. The streets are lined with countless bookstores, many of them specializing in rare, vintage, and secondhand books, creating a nostalgic and intellectual atmosphere.

Walking through Jimbocho feels peaceful and inspiring, with the quiet charm of old bookshops mixed with cozy caf√©s and traditional eateries. It‚Äôs a wonderful place to wander, browse at your own pace, and discover hidden treasures.

Jimbocho Book Town is more than just a shopping area ‚Äî it‚Äôs a cultural experience that reflects Tokyo‚Äôs deep appreciation for knowledge, history, and literature. A must-visit for book lovers and anyone seeking a slower, more thoughtful side of the city. üìñ‚ú®

Jimbocho is a compact neighborhood with around 150 bookstores, most of them long-established second-hand shops run by the same families for decades. Books spill out onto the sidewalks in wooden crates and metal carts, each with handwritten price tags and category notes. People browse quietly, often standing outside for long minutes, as if the entire district operated on a slower, more thoughtful rhythm.

It‚Äôs not only books. Many shops also sell vinyl records, vintage magazines, and woodblock prints and illustrations displayed directly on the pavement. Several stands offer kokeshi dolls‚Äîtraditional wooden figurines from northern Japan, originally handcrafted as simple toys but now collected as folk art.

Jimbocho feels distinctly analogue and unhurried, a place where Tokyo‚Äôs usual pace eases for a moment and the culture of reading and collecting continues in its most authentic form.

I love the vibe here, but despite being a book lover, I struggled to really find anything that had me exploring for hours. Many of the stores are dedicated to older Japanese books which if you‚Äôre a collector of those, you‚Äôll be in the right place. Worth a stop if you‚Äôre nearby but I wouldn‚Äôt go out of my way to go here again.
long street of books and many are by the walkway. neatly arranged. selling old DVDs and vinyls as well. Mostly japanese books

Jimbocho Book Town awakened my inner book lover, making me feel truly alive. The scent of magazines and books lining the streets excites me, while the sight of rare old books and maps resting quietly on the shelves was an unexpected delight.
address: 2-ch≈çme-20-26 Kanda Jinb≈çch≈ç, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 101-0051, Japan

name: Tokyo City Flea Market
reviews:
Incredible amount of sellers. A good mix of clothes, shoes, accessories, Japanese goods (old and current), toys, etc. Food trucks too. It's almost overwhelming. You can bargain with some. I got some items below asking. The rule of thumb is to be nice and polite. They may do the same.
Sometimes walking away is good. It gives a moment to reflect, both for you and the seller. At times you will find similar items at a cheaper asking price! Sometimes the seller realizes he will lose the sale will call you back.
I think it's worth visiting if you like thrifting and finding a treasure rewarding.
Good luck on your hunt. Dont forget to just have fun browsing even if you leave empty handed. Cheers~

First visit. Loved the place. I was after some old, vintage items, Japanese or non-Japanese so had to go. I was not disappointed. Huge amount of stalls.A mixture and old vintage things, new things and mass produced things. Obviously you get alot of tourists there (I was one) and the prices reflect that, a bit higher than I wanted but I was able to negotiate, don't be embarrassed to ask. It does get VERY busy. Food stalls there, toilets as well. You want the best bargains then get there early. It's a bit of a trek to get there but it is worth it.

Such a treat! There were lines of insanely delicious looking food trucks along the crazy amount of gems from the different vendors. Expect crowds since it‚Äôs only open on weekends but do not be deterred by the crowd. Vendors were all so passionate in sharing about their goods. A great time!

We visit this flea market everytime we go to Japan. Over the years, we see more and more vendors but we have also seen the prices of various things go outrageously high.. you can probably still find "good deals" but most of them are overpriced. Some foreigners need to realize that just because their currency is stronger, doesn't mean they're getting a good deal. Most sellers here don't have standard pricing and just blurt out prices on a whim (I noticed some charge more if you don't speak Japanese).

Still cool for Vintage/Antique/2nd hand valuables but I prefer to visit different branches of Book off/Mode off/Hard off/Hobby off.

As an American visitor, the Tokyo City Flea Market is massive, must-see experience for thrifters. Size wise it reminds me of the Aquaduct flea market in NY.
You'll find an incredible array of unique vintage Japanese items like clothing, kimonos, vintage toys, cameras, and pottery‚Äîthat you can't easily find in the US.
Key things to know:
* Go Early ( 8AM) and Bring Cash. It's huge, so start early for the best finds. Most vendors are cash-only.
* Bargaining is possible and I personally suggest on doing, but not a given. Unlike some US flea markets, prices can be fixed. Some vendors mark their vintage items considerably high. You can try a simple, polite negotiation, but don't expect deep discounts on every item.
* Language is manageable: Even if you don't speak Japanese, you can usually get by with pointing, using the phone calculator, and knowing "how much is this" (ikura desu ka).
* Know what you are willing to pay and don't assume every item is a massive steal. I found a Japanese Back to the Future laser disk in mint condition for $14 dollars which I'm going to frame  and some 25 year old Macross kits in like new condition.
* The Food is Great: Don't skip the food stalls for some authentic Japanese snacks and meals!
* While at the flea market go ahead and buy an extra suitcase. They're fairly cheap-You're going to need it...

Addendum:
This next bit isn't about Tokyo Flea Market itself, but a recent event I needed to write down. I traveled to Japan a few months ago and my biggest regret is that I never got to take my brother with me. As kids growing up we've often talked about going to Japan together and as an adult I placed that trip on hold with him thinking we'd have another chance later on. Since unexpectedly losing him last week, I've learned in the hardest way that life is incredibly precious and the moments we share are not guaranteed.                   Unfortunately I've become so incredibly numb to a mondane, repetitious life, that I've overlooked one of the most important person in my life.
Don't take the moments you have for granted and if you're doom scrolling right now stop for five minutes and call a loved one, take a trip together, even if it's for a coffe or a burger, please, go do it now. Don't wait.

Alex 1979-2025 "Greatly missed, never forgotten".

name: JINS Tokyo Station Gransta Yaesu
reviews:
Best experience ever! I was kindly assisted by a staff who spoke basic english. The eye exam was free (!) and took only 10 mins!
I opt for basic lenses that slightly change color in the sun and they were ready within an hour. And it's way cheaper than what I pay in Canada. I will definitely recommend! ü©∑

Fantastic service and speedy glasses!

They do speak English and if not they have a translator device to help aid the language barrier.

I had ordered bifocals and it takes at least a week for them to make those special lenses, but they were able to get the glasses back to me within a week. Basic lenses can be made within the hour or day.

They do offer free eye exams and I tried it, but recently got my eyes checked by my optometrist at home who understands how precise I can be. The eye exam from JINS is basic in this instance, but I found the prescription from my optometrist was sharper and so I went with the prescription versus the JINS exam.

Would highly recommend this if you are looking for affordable glasses and quick turnaround compared to the US.

This is a fantastic place to get prescription glasses . They checked my eyes and prepared reading glasses in half an hour. You pick your own frames , and the type of lenses you want .  I got one pair with standard lenses and one blue light filter lenses.  They speak excellent English . Take your passport and receive the tax off at purchase . Depending on the frame you choose will depend on the price . I paid just over  $200 for two pair .  I chose 1 expensive e frame and one cheaper frame . They ranged from $55 aud to $150 aud .  Excellent service.  Find them just down from  Starbucks and Kanno coffee and gong cha at grandstand Yaesu end of station

It was great experience handing down the best quick service for prescription glasses. The store has many selection to choose from. Nomura speak English very well and patience and help with the selection and able to complete everything within 30 minutes after payment.

Lost my glasses and have one make here. Was rushing for Shinkansen and the friendly staff that is fluent in English tell me overall within an hour. The glasses was ready in 30 mins and self collect at locker with QR code. The eye test is state of the art using dial and quite an experience for me. The cost is also v affordable to my surprise. Walk away a happy man.
address: Japan, „Äí100-0005 Tokyo, Chiyoda City, Marunouchi, 1-ch≈çme‚àí9‚àíÔºë „Ç∞„É©„É≥„É´„Éº„Éï„Éï„É≠„É≥„Éà B1F

name: Hachimanyama Ropeway
reviews:
Very cool location that is not very well known. I went in early December and decided to visit here since the Biwako Valley ropeway was not yet open. The return ticket is around 2000 yen?, which is reasonably price. Just make sure to keep your ticket once you go up since they will ask for the same one when you go down. The ride runs every 15 minutes, and takes about 5 minutes to go up to the mountain top. You can see the entire town, as well as parts of lake Biwa from inside the cable car.
There is a temple at the top of the mountain. I believe it used to be part of the Hachimanyama castle ruins. There is also a bathroom facility. If you walk to the left for around 10 minutes, you will reach a lookout point where you can see the entire town below (very beautiful!). There are plenty of hiking tracks that you can take to go down, if you don‚Äôt want to take the cable car down.
The castle is completely demolished, only a few remnants remain like some stone walls, the moats, some signs that tell you where the castle once stood.
If you‚Äôre lucky, you might encounter the cats. There were two that I bumped into. Very friendly and let you pet them

Took the cable car to the top to see the hachiman castle ruins. Reasonably priced and frequent services up and down the mountain. Very smooth ride. Friendly and helpful staff. Great views from the top and well worth visiting if you're in Omihachiman. Little gift shop at the entrance to the cable cars and toilets available at the top of the mountain.

Beautiful views and a peaceful ride! Hachiman Ropeway offers a lovely perspective of Omihachiman and the surrounding hills. The ride is short but very scenic, perfect for photos and enjoying nature. Highly recommend for a quick escape from the city.

A small ropeway that takes you to a hill overseeing the whole area around OumiHachiman including the Biwa lake. Astounding views from the top. There's also a neat temple with some Tori and pleasant greenery and butterflies. Totally recommend, we were the only foreign tourists.
Soooo beautiful in the fall around sunset! It felt like a fairytale! There are also a couple of cats roaming around the temple üêà

name: Houkokuji
reviews: The most beautiful zen buddhist garden and temple we have seen so far in Japan. It is amazingly peaceful, with a tea ceremony experience after enjoying a walk through the bamboo forest. üôèüèª

I thought it is a very big forest but is not go in have a 5-10 walk can be done. But the bamboo quite nice to take photo n it have others nice tree to photo too... Entry normal 400yen and if u want to enjoy a cup of green tea u need to get the 1000yen ticket. Overall is OK.

Lovely little temple with a serene and beautifully designed garden. The bamboo forest is small but gives you a warm feeling. You can have matcha in the garden as well. A bit off the main attraction, so quieter but well worth it.

Our visit to Hokoku-ji Temple was a little bit of a consolation prize (and please know that when I say that, I am not demeaning this absolutely INCREDIBLE temple in ANY way); what I am saying is that, looking at our itinerary and realizing that a day trip to Kyoto (and by extension, the Arashiyama bamboo forest) was just not in the cards, but I still wanted to take my wife, sons, and myself, to see a magical bamboo forest.

Thankfully, Kamakura was already on our list of stops, and after learning that Hokoku-ji had a similarly impressive bamboo forest path, visiting here had become a foregone conclusion. Google Maps claims it's a 30-minute walk from Kamakura Station; in reality, it's closer to 20 minutes, but in the summer heat and humidity, it feels more like an hour. Even then, it was worth it.

There is an extremely modest entry fee to access the temple grounds (I believe it was around ¬•500/person, so $3 USD or so), but once you are through the gates, you are almost immediately treated to one of the most gorgeous, verdant emerald cloisters you will ever encounter. Claustrophobic (in a good away), this narrow winding stretch of walkway winds about through the grounds of the temple, eventually terminating with a view of cliffside caves containing statues and shrines, ponds filled with koi, and cool, comforting, quiet, serene shade from the pervasive heat and humidity. It's a short path, but it'll stick with you.

Sure, it's a little out of the way, in a semi-remote part of the Kamakura (there is a bus that runs from the station to the temple, so utilize those Suica cards, and save yourself the walk!), but as I mentioned, it's a more than adequate substitute for the overly-trafficked Arashiyama, much closer to Tokyo, and located in a city that has more than enough reasons to visit all by itself. If that's all you're looking to experience, you're in for a treat. But if you're ready to immerse yourself in all that Hokoku-ji has to offer, you'll find so much more here than you might suspect, and you won't want to be anywhere else.

Amazing forest so peaceful and quiet!
I read that some people were disappointed because it's little, we weren't! It's totally worth it!
We took also a matcha in the forest and it was a beautiful experience to do üçµ‚ú®üéç

name: komachi dori street
reviews: A main shopping street for food and Kamakura souvenirs. We arrived Komachi-dori quite late, around 5pm, and most of the shops are closing. Very less crowd at that time. Nevertheless, we still managed to have some grilled seafood and beef sticks at one of the shops. Managed to get some Kamakura souvenirs from here as well.

Nice shopping street with various themed cafes such as totoro and animal cafes (please dont go to animal cafes, its abuse!). Lots of specialty shops such as miffy and other things. Good spots to eat too, such as 'vintage island coffee' (great sandwiches). There is also a smoking area inside the building with a red carpet in front.

I am shocked thats there's so little review about this street.
There are many streetfoods on this street like grilled skewers, salted cucumber, traditional japanese snacks, drinks including beers, kakigori etc.
For the reference, I have been to nakamise dori. Compared to nakamise-dori, I like this place better because it is not as cramped by tourist as nakamise-dori, but the abundance of food is probably same or may be more. Like I think I would have to stay 2 or 3 days to eat all food that I want to eat here. There also various animal cafes.
This is the street leading to tsuruka ouga shrine, but I enjoyed the street more than the shrine itself.
In summary, this is the must go for those who come to kamakura who love foods like me.
very crowded but great place
A lot of stores, souvenirs and food places with many types of food
address: Komachi St, Ôºí‰∏ÅÁõÆ-Ôºó-8 Â∞èÁî∫ ÈéåÂÄâÂ∏Ç Á•ûÂ•àÂ∑ùÁúå 248-0006, Japan

name: Kotoku-in
reviews:
A timeless and powerful symbol of Kamakura.

Kotoku in, home to the Great Buddha of Kamakura, is one of Japan‚Äôs most iconic and historically significant sites. The bronze Amida Buddha stands over 13 metres tall and has watched over Kamakura since the 13th century. Originally housed inside a temple hall, the structure was destroyed by storms and a tsunami in the late 15th century, leaving the statue standing serenely in the open air ever since. This history adds to the quiet strength and presence of the site.

The approach to the statue is calm and well maintained, with a balanced flow of visitors that still allows moments of reflection. The setting, framed by trees and hills, creates a peaceful atmosphere that contrasts beautifully with the scale of the Buddha itself. On clear days, the natural light and open sky enhance the sense of stillness and gravity.

Visitors can also enter the statue for a small additional fee, offering a unique perspective on its construction and scale from within. Kotoku in is not just a photo stop but a place that conveys resilience, spirituality, and history in a very tangible way.

A must visit destination in Kamakura that feels both humbling and memorable, and one of the most enduring symbols of Japan‚Äôs cultural heritage.

Kotoku in is one of those places that just hits you the moment you walk in. The Great Buddha is massive and incredibly calming to look at, and the whole area around it has this peaceful vibe that makes you want to slow down and sit for a bit. I loved how easy it was to just find a quiet corner, breathe, and take in the atmosphere. Another big plus is that the Daibutsu hiking trail starts only a few minutes from the temple, which worked out perfectly for me since I was looking to hike right after. The whole visit felt grounding and serene. Absolutely a must see when you‚Äôre in Kamakura.

Kotoku-in is absolutely worth the visit, even if you‚Äôre not usually the type to chase tourist landmarks. The Great Buddha is breathtaking in person‚Äîfar larger, calmer, and more quietly powerful than any photo can prepare you for. The moment you step through the gate and see the Daibutsu framed by the trees, you feel a sort of stillness settle in, like the whole place is exhaling. That said, it gets very crowded, especially on weekends and around midday; tour groups come in waves, and you‚Äôll often have to wait for photos or shuffle through narrow walkways. If you want space to breathe, go early in the morning or closer to closing time. The grounds are smaller than you might expect, but well kept, clean, and easy to navigate. You can pay a small extra fee to go inside the statue‚Äîit‚Äôs a quick walkthrough and not essential, but interesting if you like history or structure. Despite the crowds, people tend to be respectful and quiet, adding to the atmosphere. There are drink machines and a few souvenir spots outside the temple entrance, but the real charm is the serene neighborhood surrounding it, with traditional houses, mountains, and a peaceful walk from Hase Station. Overall, it‚Äôs one of those places that earns its reputation: busy, yes, but unforgettable, and the calm presence of the Great Buddha makes the visit feel meaningful despite the crowds.

A must-visit place when you come to Kamakura. This temple is home for a Daibutsu bronze statue of AmitƒÅbha (searched and found that its meaning is ‚Äúmeasureless/limitless light‚Äù), seats outdoor, and seems calm and inviting.

With perfect weather, you can just sit on a large rock and marvel at this gigantic buddha. The place is clean and very well-maintained. Different kinds of trees and several plants surround the temple grounds. Even with lots of people, you can still find a spot to capture its greatness.

Easy and fast ticket purchase. Restrooms available on the left side. Have an ice cream after! After exiting, you can find the Cremia stand outside ‚Äî across the street, just beside the temple.

Kotoku-in (Great Buddha of Kamakura) is a nice place to visit and very iconic Buddha statue in Japan. Seeing the Giant Buddha in real life feels quite special, photos don‚Äôt really show how big it is.

The area is easy to walk around and not too complicated. There are souvenir shops inside and outside the temple area, selling Buddha statues in many size options, so you can choose based on your luggage space (important üòÖ).

If you visit in autumn, you can also see yellow leaves around the area, which makes the atmosphere more calm and beautiful. Not a very long visit, but very memorable.

Good place to stop by if you are exploring Kamakura and want to see one of Japan‚Äôs famous landmarks.

name: Tsurugaoka Hachimangu
reviews:
I came in through the side access from
Â∑®Á¶èÂëÇÂùÇÂàáÈÄö„Åó (Kobukurozaka Pass), and after the previous two temples THIS was the busiest, because it's also closest to the city center. And, there was a procession going on. Where I came through, it turns out that was the gift shop and you pay for prayers to grab a lucky fortune. It's not where you pay to enter. That's further inside the top building, where they have vending machines for a ¬•200 ticket, where you have to show it to a person inside. Nice displays of artifacts. Wonderful garden off to the side of the Temple grounds. And where you finally go down to the main entrance into the city, there's a series of street hockers selling things. Nice, sweet smell! üòã
I just didn't like the crowds of people trying to get their pictures and Instagram photos.

A truly beautiful and peaceful shrine in Kamakura, and definitely a must-visit.

The long approach leading to the shrine is stunning, especially with the surrounding greenery and seasonal scenery. Walking through the grounds feels calming and well-balanced, even though the area is quite spacious. The shrine itself is majestic and well maintained, with a strong sense of history and culture.

We enjoyed taking our time exploring the complex, from the main hall to the smaller shrines around the area. It‚Äôs a great place for photography, quiet reflection, or simply soaking in the traditional Japanese atmosphere.

Another plus point ‚Äî from here, it‚Äôs only about a 10‚Äì12 minutes walk to Houkokuji Â†±ÂõΩÂØ∫, making it easy to continue your temple-hopping itinerary.

Despite its popularity, it never felt overly crowded during our visit, and the overall experience was serene and memorable. Highly recommended if you‚Äôre visiting Kamakura.

It‚Äôs a nice shrine just like others. I like that it‚Äôs on the hill so you can see the view of dankazura. The temple itself is not really big but it‚Äôs surrounded with trees. The atmosphere is nice. But it was so crowded, so it doesn‚Äôt feel calm or peaceful. However, the temple is not far from the JR station. You can walk through the street food which makes this trip more enjoyable.

Tsurugaoka Hachimangu is one of those shrines that feels grand the moment you enter, with its long approach framed by ponds, bridges, and tall trees that guide you toward the main hall. Even if you‚Äôve seen countless photos, the scale and atmosphere hit differently in person‚Äîwide stone steps rising up to the bright red shrine buildings, the sound of drums or prayers drifting through the air, and the flow of people moving at an unhurried pace. It‚Äôs usually crowded, especially on weekends and holidays, with tourists, school groups, and locals all weaving through the paths, but the size of the grounds keeps it from feeling claustrophobic. There‚Äôs a lot to explore: smaller sub-shrines tucked into quiet corners, koi-filled ponds, seasonal flowers, and long, shaded walkways that are perfect for strolling. The shrine is active, so you‚Äôll often see ceremonies, weddings, or blessings happening, which adds to the cultural depth of the visit. The climb up the main staircase can be a bit tiring, but the view of Kamakura from the top‚Äîroofs, hills, and the long avenue stretching to the sea‚Äîis worth it. Around New Year and festival days, be prepared for serious crowds and lines, but on regular days it‚Äôs easy to find peaceful spots if you wander off the main path. There are plenty of caf√©s and shops nearby, and the whole area feels lively without being overwhelming. Overall, Tsurugaoka Hachimangu is a beautiful, vibrant, and culturally rich shrine that captures the spirit of Kamakura, and even with the crowds, it‚Äôs a must-visit.

Tsurugaoka Hachimangu in Kamakura is a stunning temple filled with elegance and history. We were lucky to witness a traditional wedding-related ceremony, adding a rare, magical touch that made the visit even more special and memorable.

name: Hasedera
reviews:
Hasedera Temple is a very beautiful and peaceful temple in Kamakura. The atmosphere here feels calm and relaxing, a nice break from busy places.

The temple is located on a higher place, so you can see beautiful sea scenery from above. The view is really nice and refreshing, especially on a clear day.

Inside the temple area, you will also find a beautiful garden/park with many Buddhist statues. Walking around this area feels very peaceful and spiritual, and it‚Äôs nice to take your time here, not rushing.

They also have unique souvenirs, much better compared to many other temples. Not just typical items. I bought a nice bracelet here, simple but meaningful.

If you visit Kamakura, Hasedera Temple is a place worth stopping by. Calm, scenic, and very memorable.

Beautiful place with an observation deck overlooking the coastline. It is important to be quiet and be respectful of your surroundings as it is a shrine where locals come to pray. You have to buy a ticket to enter that, as of now, is priced at ¬•400. There are ticket machines with English translations at the entrance and you get a paper ticket that can be kept as a souvenir. There are also information pamphlets in English for visitors to get to know the shrine. Best visited in the morning when there isn‚Äôt as many people so you can stroll in a calming atmosphere.

This was a trip in early December when we wanted to see autumn leaves during a day trip from Tokyo. Hasedera Temple was a really enjoyable visit with different things to see - a Buddhist temple cave with wall carved statues and many small relics figures. You can walk through the low and small tunnel of caves for a unique experience.

There was also a viewing area of the Kamakura coast and town and spacious garden to walk around with areas to pray.

From the train station you can take a 45 minute walk towards the coast to enjoy a seaside walk then towards Hasedera temple.

Largest and widespread beautiful temple complex in Kamakura. The many little buildings all carry different deities and are each worth a visit. The central 11 headed Buddha is a must see (no photographs!) as is drifted several years in the see before arriving here. The gardens with all the Jizzos are so nicely arranged and ponds with Kois of different sizes are everywhere. The views from the top of the hill over the town are also gorgeous. Don't miss the Benzaiten grotto with all here helpers where you can donate a statue for well wishes. Mind your head, the grotto has a low ceiling.

If you are in the area, stop by. It's a lovely temple and grounds. We made a day trip from tokyo to see the temple and the big Buddha and preferred the temple way more than the statue. The grounds are beautiful. There's enough space that you dont feel like you are tripping over others. Take cash.

name: Meat Master NAKATA main store
reviews:
From the moment I walked in, the service was warm, attentive, and genuinely thoughtful. The staff explained the menu clearly, checked on us at just the right moments, and made us feel truly welcome without ever being intrusive.

The food was exceptional ‚Äî the quality of the beef was top-tier, beautifully presented, and grilled to perfection. Every cut was rich, tender, and full of flavor, easily one of the best yakiniku meals I‚Äôve had in Osaka. You can really tell they take pride in both their ingredients and their craft.

The atmosphere is elegant yet comfortable, making it perfect for a special dinner or a memorable night out. Great food, great service, and a wonderful overall dining experience.

Highly recommended. I would absolutely come back again...

The best meal i had so far! Must visit. There are different types of wagyu served and they explain really well despite not so fluent in english. All the wagyu meats are superb, i even like the salad too.

Chefs and staffs are friendly, thoughtful and so attentive. Even to the smallest detail such as left-handed chopstick placement for left handed people. They will explain how to eat and what to eat with each type of meat.

Overall, really enjoy dining at this restaurant. Thank you so much.

From A to Z simply incredible! The quality of the food is outstanding. Fresh, perfectly seasoned and beautifully presented. You can see and feel how much love and care goes into every detail.

The teamwork appears very harmonious, professional and well-coordinated. The service is attentive, warm and always there at exactly the right moment without ever being intrusive. This is exactly what top-level hospitality should feel like.

The ambience is stylish, cosy and a place where you feel comfortable from the very first moment. I truly have only positive things to say. An absolute hidden gem and definitely a place I will recommend anytime.

Came here after a subpar omikaze sushi experience in Tokyo. We got sat at the bar with our own cook looking after us, table service was quick and punctual and we were not rushed between portions. Friendly to tourists with recommendations provided of which topping to pair with each beef cut. We went with the A5 chateaubriand course and if you‚Äôre entering the restaurant for a wagyu experience it doesn‚Äôt disappoint. Delightful to try all the various meat and dishes they prepared and I am very glad to have gotten the chance to experience such high grade meat. Learning potatoes aged in snow become delicious and sweet was a nice bonus! I would highly recommend.

The best yakiniku restaurant I‚Äôve ever had. This place completely changed how I understand and enjoy wagyu ‚Äî each cut is served with the right sauces and salts to bring out its full flavor. The chef and staff were incredibly warm, attentive, and made the whole dining experience truly special. Outstanding food and exceptional service. Highly recommended.
address: Japan, „Äí542-0076 Osaka, Chuo Ward, Namba, 1-ch≈çme‚àí7‚àíÔºëÔºñ Áèæ‰ª£„Åì„ÅÑ„Åï„Çì„Éì„É´ 5F

name: Age.3 GINZA
reviews:
The great reviews brought me here while searching for something sweet nearby. I see why there's a long wait but it's unfortunate that they don't have any space inside to sit or at least have multiple cashiers so that the line is much shorter.

I waited 20-30 minutes before it was my time to order. It was worth waiting. Ordered the creme brulee sandwich and it was very delicious!!! Not overly sweet. I would get it again!!

The Internet has not lied... This place is Soo amazing! We tried 6 different types and all of them are amazing in different ways! The lightest but still amazing is the standard whipped cream. In total we tried the whipped cream, creme brulee, hot cheesy Curry, regular Curry, ganache, Short rib. My two favorites are the whipped cream and the hot curry! The spice is just perfect! The staff was so friendly and helpful, English is flawless as well just in case your lacking Japanese.

We got to the location at opening and waited in line for an hour. I honestly was  skeptical about the reviews on this place.  HOWEVER, THE HYPE IS JUSTIFIED.  These sandwiches are delicious!!! I personally loved the creme brulee one!  My mom really loved the apple cinnamon one.  If you buy 3, you get a free to-go box.  The person managing the line was also very kind.  I'll definitely be back and will gladly wait in line again.

Just a heads up, the line starts on the sidewalk by the park, NOT in front of the store.  I recommend getting there before opening.

First taste-expectations were high, but honestly? Kinda mid. Just fried bread with random fillings, no real wow factor. The queue was long (of course), but it moved smoothly. Credit where it‚Äôs due: super well-organised. Staff come down the line with menus so you know exactly what you‚Äôre ordering before you even reach the counter. Efficient, yes. Life-changing? Nah. Oh you get 1 regular whipped cream sandwich for free if you review them.

I came to see if these sandwiches are as delicious as they look online. I came around 30min after opening and there was a long line already. The process was super organized. A staff member took care of the line and passed out menus so we knew exactly what to order. A crowd like this one could have been tough yo manage staff made the whole wait so much easier.

I ordered the creme brulee and regular cream sandwich. Both were so delicious but the creme brulee was my favorite and I see why it has first place in the menu.
Both sandwiches are made with a super buttery, toast. If you've ever had brick toast, this bread is just like the center pieces with a nice crisp outside but soft center.

I absolutely recommend this place. Don't let the line discourage you!
address: Japan, „Äí104-0061 Tokyo, Chuo City, Ginza, 1-ch≈çme‚àí24‚àíÔºëÔºë ÊùâÊµ¶„Éì„É´ 1Ôº¶

name: Ginza Kagari - Soba
reviews: A small but excellent ramen spot in the Ginza district. The process is a bit unique, with two lines. One for payment and another for entering the restaurant. I ordered the Chicken Paitan Truffle Ramen, which was incredibly flavorful and rich. The restaurant itself is quite small, seating around 18 guests, but well worth the wait. Highly recommended!

Arrived at 10:40am on a Sunday, we were second in line. Took order at 10:50am, and we were seated by 10:55am.

Got the Special Chicken Paitan Truffle Ramen for 3400 yen.

The soup was heavy and oily. It had a nice chicken flavour, but the truffle was a little too light. The ramen was cooked nicely and very filling. I was also given the raw chicken and cured meats, which I placed in the soup to cook. The raw chicken didn‚Äôt fully cook, but ate it anyway as I don‚Äôt think it was expected to by fully cooked with the soup not being scorching hot.

Overall, I was expecting more given the hefty price (3400 yen). Everything was minumum 3000 yen. Would not recommend going especially if the line is long. Truffle flavour could have been stronger.

I was looking for ramen options without containing pork, and found Ginza Kagari‚Äôs Chicken Soba, which uses a chicken-based broth with no pork or lard in the toppings. Visited during winter and the queue was fairly long, but very well organized, so waiting didn‚Äôt feel too tiring even while standing.

The highlight is the broth gently rich with a refined chicken flavor. Light but still layered, and especially comforting in cold weather. The noodles are thin with a nice bite, and the chicken topping is tender and juicy, clearly cooked with care.

Overall, it‚Äôs a well-balanced, subtle, and elegant bowl of ramen. A solid option for anyone who wants to enjoy ramen while avoiding pork. ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

The broth of the chicken ramen was so creamy it almost creamed me. The ramen here is definitely more of a fusion style rather than traditional, with ingredients such as bell peppers, pumpkin, truffle mushroom etc. I think the varying flavours and textures from the unorthodox ingredients definitely helped bring out the broth even more. The chicken itself was very tender and firm. Overall highly recommend.

Like a lot of other Japanese restaurants, this store is extremely narrow with very limited seatings around the counter. But the staffs are very professional and efficient so things move very smoothly. Still, expect to wait if you want to do walk-in

Infamous soba in Ginza that is paired with grilled chicken. It tastes just okay, not outstanding to my taste, as the broth is quite thick and oily.

There are only around 12 seats, and someone has taken the order whilst we‚Äôre waiting outside. It is pretty quick if you arrive early, and please note all the parties must present before they could let us in.

name: Menbaka Fire Ramen
reviews:
‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê 5-Star Review

Menbaka Fire Ramen offers a truly one-of-a-kind dining experience that goes far beyond ordinary ramen shops. The most unique highlight is their dramatic fire ramen presentation ‚Äî exciting, memorable, and unlike anything you‚Äôll find elsewhere. It‚Äôs not just a meal, it‚Äôs an experience.
