The service is impressively fast and well-organized, even during busy hours. The staff are attentive, professional, and clearly experienced in delivering this special style of dining while making guests feel comfortable and safe.

Most importantly, the ramen itself is absolutely delicious. The rich, flavorful broth, perfectly cooked noodles, and well-balanced toppings come together beautifully. Every bite feels thoughtfully prepared and satisfying.

If you‚Äôre looking for a ramen place that combines great taste, efficient service, and a unique, unforgettable dining experience, Menbaka Fire Ramen is a must-visit. Highly recommended! üî•üçú

Holy Cow I love this place!!! Never in my 44 years of life have I had a culinary experience like this. You must try it. We didn‚Äôt have reservations but got there shortly after the opened and I think we just got lucky as it filled up quickly and every other party had reservations. Multiple language options to lay out the rules to ensure everyone‚Äôs safety. Everyone person has to order something unless they are under 6 years old and they don‚Äôt seem to like substitutions given the discussions I heard from party next to me. Best to just go with the food the way it is. They know best. Only a short walk from Nij≈ç Castle. If you are going to be in the area make reservations and go!!! You will have a blast.

I was staying at the hotel right across the street and each night, I would see a long queue of diners there, waiting for their turn patiently. The evening before departing Kyoto, I decided to check it out for myself so I walked over and joined the queue. I had a fun time there. Dinner comes with a show. The food was very good and the team was very friendly and efficient. Everyone knows their part and things run like clockwork. Once you are seated and placed your order, they will walk you through the experience but nothing truly prepares you for what comes next. I was a bit excited to try it out and I am glad I did! One for the experience!

The ramen was pretty good and the staff really put on a show. If you wait outside you can see their capsule machine with some pin merch. Overall the staff was pretty enjoyable to interact with. They have a rig for phone mounting capture the fire ramen safely.

I got the chicken, gyoza, and ramen set. Overall, I take it that the price is to cover the popularity the place has and the show you get. Otherwise, it is quite on the pricier side of things if you dont value these things. Anyways the food was all okay. Pretty good but a bit on the salty side.

Food was very delicious! Didn't know about the show before hand but the food was so good and so worth it! Would def go back. We also got a bottle of delicious saki that was to die for. I would recommend making a reservation, we were a party of 4 and the only reason we got a seat was because we did an early dinner (around 5.15pm). Another group our size tried to come after us and couldn't because all the seats were reserved.

name: Ramen Sen-no-Kaze Kyoto
reviews: After seeing the instagram reels decided to come check it out. Had the Kyo no shio ramen and Yamato no pirikara miso ramen with a side of gyoza which was served with 3 sauces. All the sauces and gyoza were nothing special. I wouldn't be able to tell them apart from frozen ready gyoza and the sauces were just bottled sauces. The shio ramen was also meh just tasted like any other ramen but with a weaker broth, the char on the pork was a really nice smoky element of the dish though. The miso ramen was significantly better and was one of the only things we ate in japan with a decent spice level. For the price and quality you are getting if you want just a regular bowl of ramen I would suggest going somewhere else. If you want something spicy Yamato no pirikara miso ramen is an option

‚è∞ We first tried going in the evening, but the line was out the door with a 2 hour wait since the shop is small. We came back the next day for lunch before 1pm and got seated right away.

üç≤ Yamato Pirikara Ramen ‚Äì Creamy and rich, but surprisingly light. It didn‚Äôt leave me feeling heavy or overly full. The bowl is packed with noodles, so if you‚Äôre adding gyoza or a light eater, I recommend the half-portion noodles.

ü•ü Gyoza (side) ‚Äì A great complement to the ramen, flavorful and not greasy.

ü•© Chashu Pork ‚Äì Possibly the best pork I‚Äôve ever had: soft, flavorful, and not too heavy. I would come again, just for a side of the chashu.

üå± Bean Sprouts ‚Äì Loved that they were partially submerged, letting them absorb the broth‚Äôs flavor while keeping a slight crunch.

Overall, an excellent ramen spot ‚Äî absolutely worth planning your visit around the crowds because nothing is worth a 2 hour wait.

Quite overhyped on social media for what it is.  Only foreigners eating here (evidently from the waiting list and queue outside). We waited about 40min. Service was pretty quick once seated, the ladies took our orders and helped with water refills promptly. Gyoza was solid, good flavor and crisp texture. Ramen looked good, but was quite the let down in terms of flavor. I got the spicy miso, which was not really spicy, and the broth was honestly way too bland. The Egg was overcooked as well. I did like the Chasiu, that was quite yummy, but really not the best ramen in town and definitely not worth the wait. Cash only

Over 15 years of my visit this is the best ramen I have ever have and I tried a lot. Have visited this place many times since 2010. Still the best. Recommend ramen #18. Great music too.

I prefer ramen here to the famous men-ya inoichi. Highly recommend.

Waited a little over an hour during a busy time. The staff were so kind and out of 5 different bowls of ramen I enjoyed on my 2 week visit to Japan, this was the best one, and all the bowls I had were great! I believe I had No. 28 on the menu.

I would like to thank this restaurant for an outstanding meal and experience. This was recommended to me by a friend that traveled to Japan in the past, and so shall I pass the word on to anybody traveling here in the future. Do yourself a favor and eat here.

name: KYOTO ENGINE RAMEN
reviews: Engine Ramen was absolutely worth the wait. The line was very long, but it ended up being one of the best ‚Äî if not the best ‚Äî ramen experiences I had in Japan as a vegan. They also offer gluten-free options, which is a huge plus, and the gluten-free ramen was just as amazing as the regular one. We tried the Kyoto vegan beaning ramen with gluten-free noodles, the vegan zesty ramen with regular noodles, and the gluten-free dumplings, and everything was excellent. Portions were generous, flavors were outstanding, and despite the long wait, I would 100% do it again.

Visited here as a table for 2 on New Year‚Äôs Eve. We queued for around 10 minutes and were able to drink a beer whilst queuing.

This place is pretty good, albeit not our favourite ramen spot on our trip. The gyoza were meant to come in a soup but we asked for them to be without the soup at the thought of the being runny. They were quite overcooked and we‚Äôve definitely had better.

The ramen was good, again not the best but still very strong with great flavours, a really deep and spicy broth but nothing to shout home about.

Giving this four stars as it was nice but nothing special. Service was okay but if you‚Äôve been to other ramen spots you‚Äôll have experienced better.

Came here due to the well-regarded reviews and was not disappointed. Entering was wonderful, being greeted by the friendly and welcoming staff who sat us down upstairs. I had a wonderful vegan ramen with soup dumplings. The ramen was great however the soup dumplings led to the dumplings getting slight soggy and losing their texture. I do see why the reviews speak so highly of this place, wonderful food and a welcoming atmosphere, really enjoyable place.

Wowwowowoweeeee this is some GOOD ramen!!! Broth was soo very flavorful and noodles were perfectly fresh! It was so nice that they had such accommodating options like vegetarian and pork-free chicken ramen! ü´∂ü´∂ Really appreciated their quick service too! I will be thinking about that bowl of ramen for a longgg time.

Highly recommend going at opening time because the lines get long! As a couple with a vegetarian wife and non vegetarian husband we love places that have both options!

The ramen is tasty, flavourful and extremely filling! The staff is friendly and makes sure to ask about allergies and preferences.

We had the Vegan Zesty Ramen & Zesty Miso Ramen (Pork). We also had peach wine which was the best we had in Japan.

name: Shogun Burger Shinjuku
reviews:
First visit to Shogun Burger, and it was a great experience. The staff were friendly and helpful, and although the shop itself is small with pretty tight spacing, the food and atmosphere definitely made up for it.

The burgers were huge with generous portions. I also appreciated that they provided ketchup, mustard, and three types of their own branded hot sauces right on the table‚Äîsomething many burger places don‚Äôt do since they try to upsell their products. Their hot sauces were surprisingly good and felt like high-quality stuff.

Highly recommend stopping by to see what they have, and definitely give it a try if you‚Äôre passing by. We really enjoyed our meal here.

We pulled up multiple locations. This one was the smaller one in Shinjuku . But it opened late .

The burger I had was the double wagyu with onion . I loved it! Period.

She had the single cheesburger with ham and said the same .

We also other an assortment of fries , chicken and onion rings as a side. It was good however I didn‚Äôt like the skin of the fried chicken.

The smoky whiskey highball was interesting! But good .

After hitting nearly 50,000 steps in Shinjuku, we were definitely craving something filling, and Shogun Burger delivered. The fact that it's open late made it an easy win.

We ordered the teriyaki burger combo, a double cheeseburger with no mayo, and chicken nuggets. The burgers were excellent. Soft buns, juicy wagyu patties, and cooked perfectly. Adding mustard really elevated the wagyu flavor and took the burgers to another level.

The chicken nuggets were just okay and a bit greasy, but honestly, you come here for the burgers and they do not disappoint. Ordering was quick and easy, the food was delicious, and it was the perfect stop before heading off to our next destination.

Overall, a great late-night spot and a solid choice if you're in the mood for a quality burger in Shinjuku.

Presentation, amazing, food is very good taste quality, side sauces are pretty good, ranging from basics to some Japanese style side dipping sauces.
The fries were perfect, not too long or short, good crisp and crunch, good volume as well.
Every burger they serve comes stamped, in the photos below we had the bacon and egg wagyu beef burger and the teriyaki burger. Both meals, one vanilla and one Nutella shake.
And those shakes are very good. Smooth and slightly thick consistency, but not too thick to where you‚Äôre getting personal with your straw.

After the fact we ordered fried onion rings and those were just as good as you‚Äôd imagine.
Everyone was very nice, spoke English and Japanese, you order on entry on an electronic device which made it super quick.
Food came quicker than most spots in Shinjuku.

I‚Äôd give it a good try, but be aware that some of the burgers are actually massive.. jaw breaking..

A BURGER SO PREMIUM IT FEELS LIKE A LUXURY CAR

¬∑

THE BURGER LOWDOWN
this isn't just a burger. this is a shogun burger, meaning they use legendary wagyu beef for their patties. that's the whole flex right there.

THE TASTE TEST
the result is delicious, even for the price. the quality is immediately obvious. their signature hot sauces are also delicious, with options like hai-sai, yakiniku bbq, and extra hot to level up your meal.

THE VIBE
the space is clean with good seating, and the staff is very nice. they're kind enough to explain how to order on the ticket machine, which is a major help. plus, the cool branding extends to some seriously stylish merch.

FINAL VERDICT
for a next-level burger experience where the ingredient quality is the main character, this is a major yes. it's a splurge that actually feels worth it. a must-try for burger enthusiasts.

¬∑

peep the images for your ref; they‚Äôre worth a thou.

make sure to ‚ù§Ô∏è!

name: Ginza Itoya
reviews:
Amazing stationery destination in Ginza!

Ginza Itoya is one of the best stationery stores I‚Äôve ever visited ‚Äî a must-stop in Ginza for anyone who loves pens, paper, planners, and unique gifts. The store is beautifully designed and spread across multiple floors, each with a different theme. From elegant fountain pens and high-quality notebooks to cute stickers and practical office supplies, there‚Äôs something for every taste and purpose.

The selection here is huge, and you can find both luxury and affordable items. I especially enjoyed browsing the premium pens and the beautifully crafted Japanese paper. There are also original Itoya items that you won‚Äôt find anywhere else, which makes great souvenirs or thoughtful gifts.

The staff were helpful and polite, offering recommendations without being pushy. The atmosphere is calm and inspiring ‚Äî perfect if you want to take your time exploring. There‚Äôs even a caf√© area where you can sit and plan your purchases!

It‚Äôs easy to see why both locals and tourists love this place; I noticed many people taking photos and leisurely shopping, especially on weekends. Whether you‚Äôre into journaling, drawing, or office supplies, Ginza Itoya is a stationery lover‚Äôs paradise!

Excellent stationery shop with a wide variety across many levels. I was delighted to buy really special Christmas cards as well as unique and beautiful stationery items. Could have spent many more hours browsing! Some areas get a little congested with shoppers but still easy to select items. The cafe on the top floor was lovely too.

Excellent stationary shop with probably the most variety I've seen. The prices are average though(at least for the fountain pens and inks), but that's fine because the service and testing of pens is really valuable. Everything is presented well too. Although, the queues for staff assistance on fountain pens is quite long(20-45 min), which is troublesome especially if you're a tourist tight on time.

Ginza Itoya is a stationery lover‚Äôs dream.

Massive, beautifully organized floors packed with everything from premium pens and notebooks to a serious art section (brushes, paints, sketchbooks) and an incredible selection of seasonal greeting cards‚Äîespecially the Christmas cards and displays. The store feels clean, calm, and thoughtfully laid out, so even with how big it is, it‚Äôs easy and fun to browse.

Staff were polite and the overall shopping experience felt very ‚ÄúGinza‚Äù‚Äîhigh quality, tasteful, and inspiring. Easy place to lose track of time in the best way.

I was really happy to see that they have a good range of fountain pens, including some special ones from Sailor. I picked up a few inks too. My favorite part was the craft section because I loved seeing all the stamps and punchers. The only thing to watch out for is the area with the regular gel pens. It gets extremely crowded after 12 noon, so it is better to go earlier. There is barely any space to move around once it gets busy.

name: MUJI Ginza
reviews: MUJI Ginza is a flagship store that offers a complete MUJI experience in the heart of Tokyo. The store spans multiple floors, featuring clothing, stationery, household items, skincare, and food products. The layout is clean and minimalist, making it comfortable to explore each section. The quality of the products is excellent, with simple and functional designs. The location is very convenient, near Ginza Station, and the building also includes a caf√© and hotel, making it a great place to visit even if you‚Äôre not planning to shop.

This MUJI flagship store has a huge selection and much to explore.

They have a bakery on the first floor, skincare to sample (including solid perfume), dishware, stationary, storage, snacks, clothing etc. We enjoyed browsing the racks of reMUJI items like jeans and multi-paneled/patterned shirts. This store even carries fire extinguishers, pet accessories, and live plants.

The tax free counter closes early, and staff help you prep for smooth flow as the line can get long. If you're not needing tax free, there are self check out kiosks on every level (w/ staff available to assist).

I was looking for pants they used to carry that had an extra back pocket perfect for putting my phone. Hope they consider restocking in the future. Staff tried to help look.

a lot of items to pick! yet so cheap.. a pen costs 150yen and it‚Äôs multi functional. the surrounding is very nice and the music they play is calming. Hm their product quality is very good! I love their skincare and clothing. staff is very nice and very friendly. not to mention i like how they dress. That‚Äôs all.

Kindly reviewed by me:)

I tried the bakery inside, had the chicken curry bun. Loved the crust on the outside. The curry inside was delicious. The store had a food level on the ground floor. There were frozen food and ready to eat food available. There was also cafe dining as well.

They have great selection of quality items ranging from notebooks, pens to mugs and small bags

I visited the cafe to rest from a long walk around Tokyo and Ginza. Coffee was reasonably priced and bought mixed nuts on the side. Very good atmosphere, I would comeback if I am in Ginza area again

name: Ginza Loft
reviews: Very cool store. Lots of things and stuff in stock. I bought a very nice collector's edition watch. The employees were nice but when adjusting the fitment, they kept the adjustment tool that came with my watch. While the tools are not expensive, it is the special one that comes with the watch and when you buy something new and that is special, you expect them to include all the original contents. It was probably an accident, and I don't think they stole it. It is just unfortunate. Also, they will only sell you the display models which is a bit disappointing to have no choice but to buy something that has been handled an unknown number of times. They say they only have the display models in stock. We went back the next day to buy a second watch and learned this was a lie. So I gave them 2 stars. Nice store and lots in stock. But the employees at best were slightly lazy and at worst politely dishonest.

Spread across 5 floors and may occupy a few hours of your day if you decide to really look through every home product that they sell. Most of the products are designed and made in Japan, some of them are made in China. Good product concepts and quality control. Clear organization in store. Tax free check out line could take around 10-20 minutes though.

I felt like an Ikea but Japanese. The top floor is a different store so be careful. Don't bring the wrong product to the cashier. Also they didn't let me take pictures of some of the stuff but I took it anyways. Here are the pics they stop me from taking. I don't know why

Very cool store. I enjoyed this one more than the Shibuya one. But, Shibuya had way more paper/journal/notebook options than here.

Random toys, cameras, vintage papers and crafts, cards, home goods. Really enjoyed spending time here. A bit crowded on a Wednesday afternoon.

Loft had a lot of products. I was honestly confused which floor to stay in because there were too many items to viewüòÇ The lines were fast too because each floor had its own counter. The building is also wheelchair friendly, it has an elevator.

name: Ginza Sushi Bar- ◊í◊ô◊†◊ñ◊î ◊°◊ï◊©◊ô ◊ë◊®
reviews: Overall it was lovely. We enjoyed the gioza with asado and the tuna tartar as starters. With negroni and two rolls of sushi and a tip it cost 225 each.

A very good Sushi bar at Herzelia business center. Great place for lunch, dinner or drinks in the evening.
There's a 15% discount for lunch on weekdays, and a happy hour for drinks in the evening.

The sushi is high quality and the side dishes are also great.
I recommand the Nams roles and the seafood misu soup.

I went to eat with my partner dinner and she ordered a veggie roll - she got the roll with too much avocado to her liking (mixup in the menu) and she asked to replace.
After the waiter talked with the shift manager we overheard her trash talking about my partner and about her food choices‚Ä¶ when confronted she started yelling at us‚Ä¶ we didn‚Äôt have anyone to talk to here, we hope someone higher up will see that and reach us so we can complain about her.

We have been going to Ginza for quite some time, and the service level has completely deteriorated. We are a nice family and generally give people in Israel extra compassion in light of the challenges surrounding the war. I do not need to pay a premium for crapy service. I even asked to speak to the manager, and he never came to the table. Restaurants are customer-service businesses, and our most recent wait staff are killing the owner‚Äôs business. We will not return.
All the food was very good except the Ramen which wasn't really Ramen in my opinion.

name: Osaka Aquarium Kaiyukan
reviews:
A tip to other people visiting:

Buy your tickets at the start of the day or better yet the day before ONLINE IF POSSIBLE - I don't care what google says in terms of traffic flow, whatever people say in terms of 'walking in' it is simply not true

Buy them online especially if weather predictions state that there could be any chance of rain - everyone has the same idea of visiting this place as a rainy day event

Otherwise you will have to buy your ticket to reserve your time slot to enter when you get there - they won't even let you in five minutes early. Then you have to pretend you're interested in buying stuff at the marketplace next door to the aquarium to kill both your feet and your time for the next three hours.

But aside from the hassle of buying your entry ticket, the aquarium itself is wonderful. Its streamlined, super tidy, well ventilated with lots of information littered around the aquarium. All the staff speak english and very willing to answer all your questions.

The way the aquarium is designed, you start at the top of the building and make your way down in a cyclical fashion - the aquarium revolves around one gigantic tank. However, I spent a good two and a half hours without realising it - I don't know how they managed to get two baby whale sharks in there.

There is a wide range of animals to see, I particularly liked the jellyfish section and I'm happy I got to see my favourite fish - the garden eel.

There are plenty of toilets and one cafe. I recommend eating before arriving to the aquarium in general, the prices of food in the marketplacs next door is expensive imo even by tourist standards

The aquarium is accesible friendly, wide, with guide lights and gently sloped floors with elevator access if needed. Though it can difficult for those who struggle with seeing in the dark at times.

TL:DR - Yes I would recommend this aquarium, I implore to book tickets advance and online - save yourself the grief of turning up on the day and then having to wait three hours. Eat beforehand and make sure to have a good time :)

To avoid crowds, go on a weekday where its super sunny, otherwise prepare for congestion on rainy days and on weekends

we had a really nice visit at the osaka aquarium. we were soooo excited to see the beautiful whale sharks!! they had so many different kinds of fish and sharks and the penguins were adorable. there are a lot of educational signs and information in the aquarium. the aquarium is tourist friendly. all exhibits are clean, natural looking, and not overly crowded. unfortunately the antarctic exhibit was closed but we still got to see different penguins. we are very particular in only visiting ethical zoos and aquariums, so i was pleased to learn this aquarium maintains their exhibits well, and contributes to education, research, and marine conservation awareness, and runs scientific programs. the aquarium is. short walk from the train station and is next to stores and restaurants. no need to purchase tickets in advance, you can buy them there and the wait is not long.

The aquarium was great. The displays are modern and there's decent viewing areas throughout.
The Antarctic display was partially closed during our visit.
A little more variety or interactiveness would've made it better. We went on a Tuesday and so the crowds weren't overwhelming.

The Osaka Aquarium Kaiyukan is impressive and very well done. The layout is easy to follow, and the tanks are huge, allowing you to see marine life from different angles as you move through the building.

It‚Äôs very easy to get there by public transportation, which makes the visit convenient. I visited on a weekday on Christmas Day, and even then it was very crowded, so I highly recommend buying tickets in advance through their official website.

The highlight for me was definitely the whale shark‚Äîseeing it up close in such a massive tank was unforgettable. Next to the aquarium, there‚Äôs also a shopping and dining complex with restaurants and stores, which is nice to explore before or after your visit.

Despite the crowds, it‚Äôs still worth visiting, especially if it‚Äôs your first time. Just plan ahead and be prepared for a lot of people.

This aquarium lives up to its fame. We paid ¬•2700 for the base ticket + additional ¬•1500 for the backstage viewing. Once you enter the building my, you take a very long escalator to the top 8F and we started our journey by going into the back stage area at the top floor. No photography was allowed in the backstage area which was a shame and you need to take off all accessories and store them in the provided lockers. We were then ushered into the backstage where you can see down into the 9 meters deep tank. The duration for this is 20 minutes and there were brief introduction in Japanese and English on the 2 whale sharks. After the backstage viewing, we started descending the building where there are exhibits from many regions. The path down is wrapped around the main tank with many viewing areas so you can see the whale sharks from multiple angles. All up, I think they have done a really good job of re-creating the habitats of the animals/fishes and it was a very enjoyable day.

name: teamLab Botanical Garden Osaka
reviews:
Went to TL Botanical around 7pm on a warm November evening.

I will start this review by saying that this is my first TeamLabs experience, so I'm very much treating it on its own merits.

You're essentially doing a night time walking tour of a park with illuminated sculpture installations and music/sound. So set expectations accordingly. It takes around an hour to hour and a half to get all the way round the handful of exhibits, and is generally a pleasant experience with some nicely thought out installations.

Crowds were minimal, so I'd say the winter on a weekday is a good time to go. Zero queuing and ample space to see and photograph the installations.

At time of writing, it's priced fairly reasonably for what it is, just over ¬£10. Compared to the cost of attractions in the UK I feel like this represents fairly decent value, though possibly feels slightly expensive in the context of Japan overall as most attractions are very cheap really.

My only real criticism is that it's very, very easy to trip over things as your night vision is almost non existent from continuous viewing of lit up objects, and the illumination around the paths is kept to the absolute bare minimum - so watch your step.

If you're keen on night time photography you'll be able to get some great shots, I feel like this absolutely adds some value if you're into taking photos.

Go in with an open mind and reasonable expectations, and you should have a nice hour or two.

Quite nice for a relaxing evening experience, especially not when many other people are inside. Lights changing colors and ambient music all around, great for memorable photos. Got tickets the day before, you get to enter any time it's open (18 to 20:30), there was almost no people at the ticket holder line so didn't have to wait. Free app provides a map and description of the light-up instalations.

There's around 8 slightly themed areas, most of these react to people passing through or interacting, so the experience is somewhat unique to everyone. I walked very slowly and took a bunch of photos everywhere, and it took me just over 1.5 hours; if you just walk through it might take 15-20 minutes or less. Overall, liked the concept a lot, but going in blind I expected there to be more different stuff, the journey through felt rather short.

This place is MAGICAL. Fair warning, this is a night activity at a nature park. So there's gonna be a lot of walking on uneven terrain, natural paths and slopes. But it's worth the extra 5000 steps in your step counter. The lights and art installations in nature at night brings you back to your childhood imagination of a fairytale world. You can't help but run and frolick, interacting around the installations. There's a lot of people visiting the place, but due to the wide open spaces, you don't feel that your space is encroached. I do recommend you come in spiring or summer. I went as winter hits, and its COLD. A must visit.

Nice 6 areas but underwhelming versus the other two I saw in Tokyo. The one in Odaiba is by far the best. The only one si found very interesting is the section with the wind turbines throwing air in the plastic tubes.. that's impressive.

At the same time a nice excuse for a long walk around the park at night away from the crazy Osaka rhythm and people.

A few illuminiscent arrows on the grounds would help clients inside the installation navigate better.

Suggest you arrive later than 6pm as it was super busy as opening but at 7pm super fluid.

this place is really not bad at night. there was various different spots of light such that you wouldn't feel bored, it ranges from colourful trees to some kind of eggs to a small light show in the forest. I feel like the Tokyo one is maybe better tho.. but this is still something decent. the place was relatively big, I would recommend to go to this place with a group of friends. I would say that this place is very good for dates and pictures! it is a 10 minute walk away from the station too, so it's convenient. there was also relaxing music playing which fits the ambience.

name: PC and Retro Bar Space Station
reviews: We had some great themed cocktails, they're really strong and tasted great, (800 yen each drink so possibly more expensive than some other bars in the area). Great array of gaming consoles available. You can play for as long as you like as long as you're buying drinks, which is fair enough. We had great fun playing some 80's arcade games, would definitely go again.

PC and Retro Bar had great drinks at great prices. There is no seat fee to play the games, which is a huge plus.

The game selection is excellent. There is a nice mix of single-player and multiplayer classics, along with plenty of nostalgic favorites. It is easy to lose track of time here.
The owners are very friendly, and you can tell they genuinely care about the bar and the people who visit. That personal touch really stood out to me (probably the Canadian in me, lol).

There are stairs to get inside, so keep that in mind. Overall, I had a fantastic time and would highly recommend this spot for a solo visit or a night out with friends.

Such a cool spot ‚Äî a retro gaming bar that‚Äôs pure nostalgia in the best way. Tons of classic games to play, fun cocktails, and a super relaxed atmosphere. It‚Äôs the kind of place where you instantly feel at home if you grew up with old consoles or arcade games. !

Gamers delight , come for the Games stay for the atmosphere and drinks . Great host and fun place to hang out for a few drinks . They do ask everyone to buy a drink to play the free games but that‚Äôs not even an issue, it is a bar after all!

Nostalgic retro place in Osaka! If you‚Äôre into old school gaming then this place is for you.

Nice vibes in here and people are so friendly! Order a drink and play or just vibe!

name: Dotonbori
reviews: Very lively place with many interconnecting shopping areas, mostly sheltered. It is very easy to explore and has many eateries around. Love the place and am really glad our hotel is just nearby. Gets really crowded on weekends but you can always walk through another parallel lane to get to where you want. Most of the restaurants only open from 11am but a few fast food do open early.

Dotonbori is one of the most iconic and energetic districts in Osaka, and it perfectly captures the city‚Äôs lively spirit. From the moment you arrive, you‚Äôre surrounded by bright neon lights, huge animated signboards, and a constant buzz of activity that makes the area feel alive at all hours.
Shopping options are everywhere. The streets are lined with popular fashion stores, souvenir shops, cosmetics outlets, and small specialty stores, making it easy to shop casually or seriously hunt for unique finds. You can stroll without a plan and still end up with bags in your hands.

Food is the real star of Dotonbori. There are countless restaurants, casual eateries, and street food stalls serving Osaka classics like takoyaki, okonomiyaki, ramen, sushi, and grilled seafood. The variety is impressive, and many places stay open late, perfect for night cravings.
Be prepared for crowds. Dotonbori is almost always busy, especially in the evenings, with locals and tourists filling the streets. While it can be overwhelming, the lively crowd adds to the excitement. Dotonbori is chaotic, colorful, and unforgettable. It‚Äôs a place where people watching, spontaneous photos, and late night snacks come together to create memories you‚Äôll probably talk about long after your trip.

Dotonbori is lively, colourful and packed with energy ‚Äî neon lights, giant signboards screaming for attention, and endless (though often repetitive) food options. It‚Äôs definitely an iconic spot to check in and experience at least once. I went mainly for the snow crab restaurant; otherwise, it‚Äôs a place I might skip simply because of the heavy crowds.
At peak hours, it gets extremely congested, making it hard to explore shops, take photos, or even walk comfortably. Buying things or queuing for food takes patience due to the sheer number of people.
Still, the bustling atmosphere is part of the charm. If you enjoy vibrant streets and don‚Äôt mind moving at a slow shuffle, it‚Äôs an exciting way to soak in Osaka‚Äôs city vibe. Best visited during off-peak hours for a more pleasant stroll.

A must see when in Osaka obviously! We came during the day. Most of the canal businesses weren‚Äôt open, I assume it‚Äôs big in the evening. The surrounding shops and eateries were great! The street vendor food was great. The Japanesey of it all was great.  Thoroughly enjoyed wandering around here and well worth spending time here

Personally feel like social media made the place feel overhyped. The area felt a lot smaller than I thought. All the crowds are centered along Ebisu Bridge and the shopping streets around it. Glico sign is just how you imagine it, nothing to special.

Recommended to visit both day and night if you have time. Vibe of the place is entirely different. The neon lights at night are really neat.

In the end, I still feel like an hour around the area would suffice. If you're not into touristy activities like boat riding or heavy shopping, there's not much to do except for soaking in the vibe.
address: 1 Chome-9 Dotonbori, Chuo Ward, Osaka, 542-0071, Japan

name: Minoh Park
reviews:
Minoh park was such a lovely place even in the middle of winter. It was quiet with just the river, birds, and occasional footsteps of locals. The hike is easy, but if you want to take a more natural route, once you reach the first split, there is a cafe to the right along with a small village across the bridge, that path is gorgeous but ensure you wear appropriate footwear.

Unfortunately some of the stores at the waterfall have burnt down, but hopefully they get rebuild or cleared out soon.

A tranquil walk up to the waterfall. There's a trail and a flat road path to the waterfall. For the trail, aim for the Âú∞ÁçÑËÉ° sign. There are stairs to climb and the views are amazing. There's a small stall that sells ice cream and red bean soup at the waterfall that taste great as well. Toilets are everywhere, no worries.

This park was a beautiful calming walk- we visited Katsuoji temple, took a taxi to the fountain and walked from there to the station. It wasn‚Äôt a difficult walk at all with options for slope or steps. The autumn foliage was beautiful and the park allowed for amazing scenery with great lighting through the foliage. There are toilets dotted throughout the route with several cafes, stalls and restaurants also spread out along the route. Very peaceful day

Overrated.  Don‚Äôt get me wrong, the forest is beautiful especially during autumn season, but there‚Äôs far too many people both at the falls and along the trail for this to be a truly relaxing activity in my opinion. The falls itself is not impressive relative to other hikes I‚Äôve done.

There are many other hikes that I‚Äôd rather do than this one. It‚Äôs suited for a family walk since the trail is easy.  Otherwise you‚Äôll find better views, the autumn colors, and a more peaceful experience on other hikes that has less people along the path.

Beautiful trip from Osaka. After a week in a big city, it's nice to relax in nature for a while. The advantage is that you can get there from the city in no time. I recommend exploring the area around the station as well.

name: Expo '70 Commemorative Park
reviews:
Visiting Expo ‚Äô70 Commemorative Park is a unique experience that blends history, art, nature, and relaxation beautifully. The park itself is expansive and green, with wide lawns, gardens, and trees ‚Äî a perfect escape from the city bustle and a great spot to unwind or enjoy a stroll.

The Tower of the Sun is the crown jewel of the park. Standing about 70 meters tall, with its bold arms and three symbolic ‚Äúfaces‚Äù representing past, present, and future, it‚Äôs a striking piece of public art ‚Äî powerful, memorable, and instantly recognizable.

Inside, the tower reveals more than just its dramatic exterior. The restored interior exhibits include the ‚ÄúTree of Life,‚Äù a massive installation illustrating the evolution of life, from primitive organisms to humans ‚Äî a rare chance to see such a bold artistic and conceptual statement in a public space.

Access is easy via public transit, and park hours are well defined (typically 9:30‚Äì17:00; entry until 30 minutes before closing).  Admission is quite reasonable ‚Äî the park itself is inexpensive (or free, depending on area), with a small fee to enter the Tower of the Sun or additional exhibits.

A stunning huge park great for relaxing and spending time with family and friends. The Tower of the Sun is super cute on the day and the light show in the evening give it extra dimension. There is also a large Japanese Garden inside which is simply beautiful - well designed and mesmerising even in autumn and winter. There is also a museum and other areas in the park that are worth visiting. We happened to be when there was Ramen Expo, which we had so many delicious ramen across the country. Overall, a super nice park that I will be happy to visit again and again.

Expo ‚Äô70 Commemorative Park is one of Osaka‚Äôs most spacious and rewarding urban green spaces, blending history, nature, and culture in a beautifully maintained setting.

Built on the grounds of the 1970 World Expo, the park still carries the spirit of innovation and optimism from that era, most famously represented by Taro Okamoto‚Äôs iconic Tower of the Sun rising boldly from the landscape. Wide walking paths, peaceful lawns, and seasonal flower gardens make it an ideal escape from the city‚Äôs bustle, whether you‚Äôre strolling through cherry blossoms in spring, sunflowers in summer, or autumn foliage in fall.

The Japanese Garden is especially striking, offering a calm, traditional atmosphere with ponds, bridges, and manicured plants that feel worlds away from nearby urban life.

This park is a hidden gem! It's beautifully maintained and full of lush greenery, with a wide variety of trees and plants that make it feel like a natural escape right in the city. Whether you're walking, jogging, or just relaxing, the fresh air and shade from the trees make it an ideal spot. There are plenty of quiet corners to sit and unwind, and the landscaping is clearly well cared for. A perfect place for nature lovers or anyone looking for a peaceful break outdoors.

Visited during last summer September 2025.
The park is large. Went there mainly to visit the expo 70 museum and the signature tower. Maybe we visit during weekend and without any booking, tickets all sold out!  It's a long queue to the tower of sun souvenir shop (which is a little shop).

It's a good experience to visit the expo 70 museum. It's an amazing experience to visit the ethic museum!! A large collection from all over the world and I wish I have enough time for it. Definitely worth to spend a half day inside the museum.

name: Namba Yasaka Jinja
reviews:
If you‚Äôre visiting the Namba or Dotonburi area, you absolutely have to make a pit stop at Namba Yasaka Jinja. It‚Äôs tucked away in a quiet neighborhood, but once you walk through the gates, you can‚Äôt miss it.

‚ÄãThe star of the show is definitely the Shishiden (Lion Head stage). I‚Äôd seen photos online, but honestly, they don't do it justice as it was so much bigger than I expected! Standing in front of those massive teeth and wide eyes is a bit surreal. It‚Äôs supposed to swallow evil spirits and bring you good luck, and it definitely feels powerful (and makes for an incredible photo).

‚ÄãI visited first thing in the morning, and it was the perfect call. There weren't many people around, so I could really take in the atmosphere without the crowds.

‚ÄãThey have a really cool variety of omikuji (fortune slips). I ended up getting one that comes inside a beautiful carp-shaped case. It‚Äôs super high quality and makes for a great little souvenir to bring home and display on a shelf.

‚ÄãOne of the sweetest things I saw was their selection of amulets. They have these adorable tiny schoolbag charms (randoseru). They‚Äôre designed to protect little ones on their daily journey to and from school. It‚Äôs such a thoughtful gift if you have kids or younger siblings back home.

‚ÄãIt‚Äôs only about an 8-minute walk from Namba Station, making it an easy detour before you head off for some Dotonbori street food.

Namba Yasaka Shrine is a unique and memorable shrine in Osaka, best known for its massive lion head stage, which is both striking and symbolic. Despite being located near busy Namba, the shrine grounds are small, mostly flat, and easy to walk, making it very accessible. It‚Äôs usually not too crowded, so you can take photos comfortably, especially of the lion head from the front. A quick but worthwhile stop for visitors interested in something different from traditional shrine architecture. I spent around 5 minutes just to take photos here. And there is no entrance fee.

This is a shrine for worship and it is famous for its main structure, a giant lion with its mouth wide opened. It was impressive seeing it in person. We were there around 9am and the sun was gleaming through. It was busy even early in the morning.
They have all kinds of amulet, even Hello Kitty ones.

Namba Yasaka Jinja (Èõ£Ê≥¢ÂÖ´Èò™Á•ûÁ§æ) is one of Osaka‚Äôs most visually striking and atmospheric shrines, famous for its enormous lion-head stage that seems to watch over the grounds with a fierce, protective gaze. Tucked away in the energetic Namba district, this small but powerful shrine offers a surprisingly calm and spiritual break from the nearby crowds, noise, and shopping streets.

The massive lion structure is said to swallow evil spirits and bring good fortune, especially in business, examinations, and personal success, making it a meaningful stop for both locals and visitors. Despite its unique design, the rest of the shrine remains traditional and peaceful, with prayer areas, stone lanterns, and shaded spots that invite quiet reflection.

For photographers, Namba Yasaka Jinja is a must-visit. The angle, scale, and dramatic expression of the lion‚Äôs open mouth create a dynamic subject that changes beautifully with different light throughout the day. It‚Äôs equally captivating in bright sunlight and soft evening glow.

Easily accessible and never overly commercial, Namba Yasaka Jinja is a hidden gem in Osaka that blends tradition, symbolism, and unforgettable visual impact in a compact, tranquil setting.

A unique and memorable shrine in Osaka. Namba Yasaka Shrine, located in Naniwa Ward, is famous for its striking design and long history, especially known for warding off bad luck and bringing good fortune.

The highlight is the massive lion head hall at the entrance. It‚Äôs incredibly impressive in person and is believed to ‚Äúswallow misfortune and bring victory.‚Äù Definitely a must visit if you‚Äôre hoping for a bit of extra luck.

Remember to prepare a 5 yen coin for the offering box, as the pronunciation of 5 yen (go-en) symbolizes good connections and blessings.

After praying, you can browse a variety of omamori charms. The schoolbag shaped charm is especially cute and popular for students wishing for academic success. You can also write your wishes on an ema plaque with twin lion heads and hang it up at the shrine.

The shrine is fairly small and easy to visit about 30 minutes is enough for praying, buying charms, and taking photos. A great stop if you‚Äôre exploring the Namba area and want something culturally meaningful yet quick to visit.

name: Shitenn≈ç-ji
reviews:
Visiting Shitenn≈ç‚Äëji during a light drizzle was incredibly calming and refreshing. The cool air and gentle rain gave the entire temple a peaceful, almost meditative mood. The stone paths, wooden halls, and garden areas looked beautiful with the soft sheen of rain, making the whole place feel quiet and chill.
Even with the drizzle, walking around the grounds was soothing ‚Äî the sound of raindrops, the cool breeze, and the tranquil atmosphere made it easy to slow down and enjoy the moment. It‚Äôs one of those places where you can just breathe, wander, and feel a sense of calm settle in.
Shitenn≈ç‚Äëji is already a serene temple, but visiting it in cool, drizzly weather made it even more special. A perfect spot for anyone looking for a peaceful break in Osaka.

I visited Shitenno-ji yesterday, and honestly, I was surprised I had never been here before.

I studied Japanese more than 20 years ago, lived in Kyoto, and have visited Osaka many times over the years‚Äîbut this was my first time at Shitenno-ji. If I had known how special this place is, I would have come much earlier.

The main hall is absolutely beautiful, featuring Buddhist life stories depicted in an art style that feels subtly Indian-inspired, very different from what you usually see in Japan. The hall at the back, illustrating the journey of Xuanzang (the monk behind Journey to the West), is equally impressive, with delicate and expressive murals.

A hidden gem is the Dragon Reflection Well‚Äîmany visitors only notice the coins at the bottom, but if you look carefully, you‚Äôll see a dragon image reflected in the water, created by the dragon carving on the roof above. A quiet, poetic detail.

What moved me most is the temple‚Äôs deeper meaning. Shitenno-ji is known as a ‚Äútemple of the setting sun.‚Äù In ancient times, the elevated ground here allowed people to watch the sun set into the sea. It was a place for reflection‚Äîreminding visitors that life, too, moves toward its own sunset, and that awareness brings clarity, humility, and peace.

A truly underrated temple in Osaka‚Äîrich in history, art, and quiet wisdom. Highly recommended.

Visiting Shitenn≈ç-ji ÂõõÂ§©ÁéãÂØ∫ was a very good experience. As one of the oldest temples in Japan, it has a strong spiritual atmosphere, and it is known as a place related to K≈çb≈ç Daishi. Walking through the temple grounds feels peaceful, and you can really sense the history and religious importance of the site.

One of the nice things about Shitenn≈ç-ji is that the surrounding area is quite calm and not crowded with tourists. This makes it easier to enjoy the space, take your time, and appreciate the architecture and the quiet environment. The layout of the temple buildings, pagoda, and gardens creates a pleasant space to walk around and reflect.

Overall, it‚Äôs a lovely place for worship and a gentle escape from the busy parts of Osaka. The calm surroundings and spiritual atmosphere make Shitenn≈ç-ji a meaningful and relaxing visit. üåø‚ú®

Shitenn≈ç-ji greets visitors with a calm, expansive presence‚Äîneither cloistered like Kyoto‚Äôs temples nor grand in the way of Nara‚Äôs ancient shrines. Instead, it embodies a uniquely Kansai kind of serenity, a quiet confidence shaped by centuries of history. Passing through the weathered wooden gate and stepping onto the stone pathway, you feel as if each step draws you deeper into a living timeline.

The temple‚Äôs layout is dignified and symmetrical. From the lecture hall to the central gate, and finally to the five-story pagoda, the red-and-white structures stand out beautifully beneath the wide blue sky. The pagoda in particular shines with subtle touches of gold, its lines graceful and composed‚Äîsolemn, yet approachable. It does not overwhelm with grandeur; rather, it invites you to slow down and appreciate its quiet harmony.

The pond at the front adds a soft rhythm to the space. Walking along the water‚Äôs edge, you see the reflections of the pagoda and drifting clouds ripple gently across the surface, as if time itself is breathing in slow motion. The warm tones of the autumn leaves along the stone railing echo the temple‚Äôs deep red beams, creating a tranquil and cohesive scene.

What makes Shitenn≈ç-ji truly captivating is its balance between the sacred and the urban. Despite being surrounded by modern buildings and steady foot traffic, once you step onto the main axis of the temple grounds, a peaceful clarity settles in. This is not a place where you must sit still to find calm; simply walking, pausing, and observing naturally brings your mind into a quieter rhythm.

Whether you‚Äôre drawn to historical architecture, searching for a pocket of tranquility within the city, or simply wishing to stroll through a space where past and present coexist gracefully, Shitenn≈ç-ji is one of Osaka‚Äôs most worthwhile destinations. It is a temple that has endured for over a millennium, yet continues to offer the same gentle, unadorned beauty to everyone who visits.

I had not done any prior research and arrived at the temple in the late afternoon, when it was already closed. What a pity! I was unable to access the main hall, but the exterior is already remarkably beautiful - striking architecture, small ponds, and lovely trees. Everything was very clean and well maintained. The outer grounds are free to visit, while entrance to the interior requires a paid ticket. The site is large, with several access points, and I ended up getting lost and entering through an adjacent cemetery. Upon arrival, I noticed a few local vendors packing up their stalls into their vehicles, suggesting there may be a small local market nearby. I imagine it is connected to the temple and to the historical heritage of Tokyo and Japan. If I return to Osaka, I will definitely plan to visit the interior area as well!

name: Osaka Tenmangu Shrine
reviews:
Osaka Tenmangu Shrine, dedicated to Sugawara no Michizane‚Äîthe revered deity of learning‚Äîoffers a rare moment of serenity within the fast-paced rhythm of the city. The moment you pass through its stone torii gate, the noise of the streets begins to fade, replaced by the stillness and gentle gravity unique to ancient shrines. Under the soft, overcast sky captured in your photos, the entrance feels even more solemn, inviting visitors to slow their steps.

Inside the grounds, the space opens wide yet remains intimate. Buildings under restoration stand beside beautifully preserved wooden structures, creating a striking contrast between old and new‚Äîa reminder of how this shrine has quietly watched over Osaka for centuries. Footsteps on the sandy courtyard sound crisp in the cool air, adding to the meditative atmosphere that naturally draws you inward.

The small sub-shrines, wooden gates, and traditional rooftops carry the charm of craftsmanship shaped by time. The purification pavilion and prayer hall feel welcoming, attracting visitors who come to seek blessings, express gratitude, or simply reconnect with themselves amid travel.

The omamori you hold‚Äîa black charm adorned with gold, pink, and white plum blossoms‚Äîbeautifully reflects the elegance of Tenmangu. It is more than a souvenir; it is a small piece of the shrine‚Äôs protection and warmth, carried back into everyday life.

Overall, Osaka Tenmangu is a place where the heart naturally settles. Even with modern buildings rising just beyond its borders, the shrine maintains its own timeless rhythm. Whether you visit to pray for success, enjoy a quiet walk, take photos, or find a moment of peace during your journey, Osaka Tenmangu offers a gentle, enduring sense of calm that lingers long after you leave.

Beautiful place to visit and reflect!
Dedicated to Sugawara no Michizane the god of learning and art, Osaka Tenmangu is a historic shrine that offers a serene atmosphere and hosting one of Japan's most spectacular festivals . It's a wonderful place to experience both the spiritual and local everyday life of Osaka

When I was there, it seems to have a night event with busy staff working on setting up a few structures.

Still, as an important religious center for the locals, it also has the venue for wedding ceremony and other important events. A significant shrine with magnificent history.

The shrine was gorgeous. A bit of repairing did slightly ruin its image, but not to worry. In summer months it gets very hot and very bright so maybe consider bringing a cap or some sunglasses. I‚Äôd also cover your shoulders if possible, knees didn‚Äôt seem so much of a problem. The smaller shrine near it is the centrepiece in my opinion though. Great for pictures under the line of Torii gates and also a quiet place to respite from the city life.
For now, you may want to skip this visit as they are undergoing some renovations. I hope to pop by when they completed the renovation. Locals still come by and do their prayers as per normal.

name: Osaka Castle Park
reviews:
We visited Osaka Castle Park in early January 2026, and it was absolutely beautiful. The park is very spacious with plenty of garden clusters, making it perfect for a relaxed walk while enjoying nature in the middle of the city.

There are many food stalls scattered around the park, which adds to the lively atmosphere. The view of Osaka Castle is stunning, especially with the castle surrounded by ditches and canals that make it feel even more majestic and historic.

What we loved most were the hidden gems inside the park, including a figurine museum and various spots that explain the history of Japan and Osaka in an engaging way.

A must-visit place if you are in Osaka. Highly recommended and thumbs up!

Walking around the castle grounds with my wife and kids was very enjoyable. The park is spacious, clean, and family-friendly, perfect for slow walks, photos, and letting kids move freely without feeling cramped. The scenery alone already feels worth the visit, even without going inside the castle.

That said, a small constructive note: the walk from the nearest station to the main castle can feel quite long, especially with kids or strollers. Also, the interior museum experience inside the castle is more educational than immersive‚Äîsome interactive elements could make it more engaging for children.

Overall, a must-visit historical spot in Osaka with beautiful seasonal views. Come for the scenery and atmosphere, take it slow, and enjoy it as part of a relaxed family day.

Osaka Castle is one of the most iconic spots in Japan, and it truly lives up to the hype. The castle sits beautifully in the middle of a large park, surrounded by moats, stone walls, and peaceful walking paths that make the whole place feel grand but relaxing at the same time. The castle itself is stunning up close, with its white walls, green roofs, and golden details that look amazing in photos.

If you can, visit both during the day and at night. During the day, you get the full scenery and lively atmosphere, but at night the castle lights up beautifully and feels much quieter, almost magical. It‚Äôs a completely different vibe and perfect for photos or a peaceful evening walk.

Overall, Osaka Castle is a must-visit‚Äîrich in history, beautiful to explore, and even more special if you experience it both day and night.

Walking through Osaka Castle Park Â§ßÈò™ÂüéÂÖ¨Âúí in autumn was an amazing experience. The park is filled with many trees turning beautiful shades of red, yellow, and orange, creating a colorful scenery all around the castle area. It feels very refreshing to stroll along the wide paths while enjoying the seasonal colors.

The contrast between the autumn leaves and the impressive castle tower makes the view especially memorable. There are many nice spots to stop, take photos, and simply enjoy the moment. Even though it‚Äôs a popular place, the park is large enough that you can still find quiet areas to relax and take in the atmosphere.

Overall, Osaka Castle Park during autumn is a wonderful place to experience nature in the city, enjoy the changing leaves, and have a peaceful walk surrounded by beautiful colors. üçÅüåø‚ú®

The area around Osaka Tower is filled with beautiful gardens and flowering trees. There‚Äôs also a pond-like section surrounding the tower, which creates a very scenic atmosphere. It‚Äôs a lovely place to visit for both local and international visitors.

When I visited during autumn, the trees were especially gorgeous with their seasonal colours. Inside Osaka Tower, you can also enter with a ticket to explore exhibits about the ruler connected to the tower‚Äôs history. You can then climb up to the observation deck at the top floor for a stunning view of the surroundings.

Overall, I highly recommend visiting this place. It‚Äôs a peaceful, beautiful spot that offers both nature and history in one location.

name: Osaka Castle
reviews:
Incredible site to see, especially for a non Japanese tourist, just a wonderous place to visit, full of history, we also took the Aqualiner cruise ride that takes you around the castle.

One of Japan's most famous landmarks and a significant symbol of the unification of Japan during the sixteenth century. Today, the castle's main tower serves as a modern museum set within a vast municipal park.

Museum & Observation: The interior of the main tower houses a museum dedicated to the history of the castle and the life of Toyotomi Hideyoshi, while the top floor offers panoramic views of the city.

Imposing Architecture: The site is renowned for its massive stone walls, impressive moats, and the iconic white, green, and gold aesthetic of the central keep.

Castle Park: The surrounding park covers about two square kilometers and features the Nishinomaru Garden, which contains approximately 600 cherry trees, making it a premier spot for cherry blossom viewing.

Toyotomi Era (1583): Construction began under the orders of Toyotomi Hideyoshi, who intended it to be the center of a newly unified Japan. It was the largest and most formidable castle of its time.

Destruction and Rebirth: After Hideyoshi's death, the castle was destroyed by Tokugawa forces during the Siege of Osaka in 1615. The Tokugawa shogunate rebuilt it in the 1620s, only for the main tower to be struck by lightning and burn down in 1665.

Modern Reconstruction: For centuries, the castle remained without a main keep until the current concrete structure was built in 1931. Miraculously, it survived the air raids of World War II, though many other parts of the grounds were damaged.

Major Renovation (1997): A comprehensive restoration project was completed in 1997, which modernized the interior and restored the exterior to its former Edo-period glory.

This place is amazing for any traveler looking for things out of the ordinary. The exhibit is really well done and the outside of the castle is free. Beautiful scenery and a rich history. You can also dress up as a samurai and take a photo. I would recommend.

Osaka Castle really surprised me in the best way. I‚Äôm not even someone who‚Äôs usually into historical sites or museums, but this place pulled me in fast. The castle itself is ridiculously pretty up close with that mix of traditional architecture and bold colors that makes it look almost like a painting. The huge park around it adds to the whole vibe really peaceful, lots of open space, and since I went in January the cold kept the crowds light, which honestly made the whole experience even better. It felt calm instead of chaotic.

Walking around the castle grounds and then exploring the inside gave two totally different perspectives. The museum was way more interesting than I expected, with clear stories about the wars, rulers, and how the castle came to be. It was easy to follow even for someone who isn‚Äôt a history person. Overall, it‚Äôs an absolute must-visit in Osaka. You get beauty, calm, and a deep sense of the city‚Äôs past all in one stop.

Osaka Castle is a very big and impressive place that many visitors enjoy. The castle itself is large, beautiful, and looks very grand. With its white walls, green roof, and golden decorations, the castle stands out clearly and feels strong and powerful. It is one of the most famous landmarks in Osaka.

The area around Osaka Castle is also very wide. There are large parks, open spaces, trees, and walking paths, so visitors can walk for a long time and still feel comfortable. In spring, many people come to see cherry blossoms, and in other seasons, the view is still calm and pleasant. The size of the area makes the castle feel even more special and important.

Inside the castle, there is a museum where visitors can learn about the history of Osaka and the castle itself. From the top floor, you can enjoy a nice view of the city, which shows how big Osaka is.

Overall, Osaka Castle is a beautiful and powerful place. It is big, well-known, and very impressive. Visiting Osaka Castle gives you a strong feeling of history, beauty, and greatness all in one place.

Beautiful place, totally free to visit. A lot of historical value where we can learn many things but also see the grand and majestic castle of osaka. A little bit of trekking and incline walking here, fits perfect with autumn / winter weather. You can also see the beautiful sky from there.

name: By≈çdo-in Temple
reviews:
I visited this place a few days ago during my stay in Kyoto, and it was absolutely beautiful even in winter. Every corner was full of charming details that made me stop and admire it. They also have a museum inside but photos aren‚Äôt allowed, which honestly makes the experience feel more special but you can pick up some lovely souvenirs at the end to bring the memories home with you ü§ó.

I would happily come back here again, especially for the incredible matcha in Uji. It‚Äôs the kind of place that stays in your mind and makes you want to return.

The Harmony of Byodo-in
‚Äã1. Architectural Elegance
‚ÄãThe Phoenix Hall is designed to resemble a celestial palace from the Pure Land (Buddhist paradise). Its symmetrical structure consists of a central hall flanked by two wing corridors and a tail corridor, mimicking the shape of a bird spreading its wings. The vermilion-colored pillars and the sweeping curves of the tiled roofs create a sense of lightness, as if the entire building is about to take flight.
‚Äã2. The Mirror Effect
‚ÄãOne of the most striking features in your photos is the "Amida Pond." The temple was intentionally built on an island in the middle of this pond to create a perfect reflection. On a calm day, the water acts as a mirror, doubling the temple's beauty and blurring the line between the physical world and its spiritual reflection.
‚Äã3. Spiritual Symbolism
‚ÄãPerched on the roof are two golden Phoenixes (H≈ç≈ç), which represent grace, virtue, and rebirth. This temple is so significant to Japanese culture and beauty that it is featured on the back of the 10-yen coin and the 10,000-yen note.
‚Äã4. Seasonal Serenity
‚ÄãThe composition of your photos‚Äîframed by pine branches and set against a dramatic, moody sky‚Äîhighlights the Wabi-sabi aesthetic. There is a profound sense of peace and "impermanent beauty" in the way the ancient wood and bright paint stand against the natural landscape.

Visiting By≈çd≈ç-in Temple Âπ≥Á≠âÈô¢ was a very beautiful and memorable experience. The moment you see the Phoenix Hall reflecting on the surface of the pond, it feels like a classic scene from a Japanese painting. The elegant architecture and the calm water together create a peaceful atmosphere that is easy to enjoy.

Walking around the temple grounds feels very relaxing, with well-kept gardens and gentle pathways that invite you to slow down and appreciate the surroundings. The combination of nature and history makes the visit enjoyable, and every angle offers a different, picturesque view.

The museum inside is also interesting, and it helps you understand more about the temple‚Äôs history and its cultural importance. The detailed artwork and the Phoenix ornaments are especially impressive and show the fine craftsmanship of the period.

Overall, By≈çd≈ç-in Temple is a wonderful place to visit if you appreciate quiet, beautiful scenery and traditional Japanese architecture. It leaves a calm and lasting impression. üåø‚ú®

Byodoin Temple is truly breathtaking and is my favorite temple in Japan.
I visited during the autumn night illumination season, and the atmosphere was incredibly calm and peaceful. The temple manages visitor flow very well ‚Äî entry requires advance reservations and visitors are admitted in time slots. This arrangement works wonderfully. Unlike other temples that feel overcrowded, Byodoin allows you to experience its beauty in a much more serene and relaxed way.

The reflection on the water was so beautiful that it felt like another world. We spent about 90 minutes slowly walking through the entire route.

It was truly a worthwhile and unforgettable experience!

A stunning and one of the famous Buddhist temple in Uji, Kyoto. famous for its iconic Phoenix Hall featuring golden phoenixes and housing Amida Buddha, symbolizing the Buddhist Pure Land, with its architecture and beautiful garden designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site. You can find also on the 10-yen japanese coin. A breathtaking view of temple in the middle of pond

name: Mimuroto-ji
reviews:
Peaceful hilltop temple. In early October, unfortunately we missed hydrangea garden which was completely closed, and lotus season had passed though you could see the plants in front of the main temple. There is a lovely view over lots of greenery which was just starting to turn yellow, would be lovely in a few weeks when leaves are red.

¬•1000 entry fee charged at the bottom of the hill. Note that there are approximately 40 large steps to reach the top. Located in a quiet area of Uji, it is about a 30 minute walk through residential areas from JR Uji station.

I visited in early June 2023 ‚Äî a great time to see Japan‚Äôs hydrangeas in full bloom. Tickets are available at the entrance and they‚Äôre pretty affordable. The garden is spacious, filled with blooming flowers, and the ones along the stairs were especially lovely. I had such a nice time here.

Mimuroto-ji and hydrangea garden - a beautiful temple and garden full of hydrangea. We were there at around 9:30 am and the garden was already filled with people. There is an entrance fee for adult 1000 ¬• and children 500 ¬•. There is a 5 to 10 minutes walk from the gate to the garden. You can probably easily spend an hour or two to enjoy the hydrangea garden. Once you are done with the garden, there is another 10 to 15 minutes walk up hill steps to the Mimuroto temple.

Although the entry fee is quite expensive (1,000¬•), it's worth it. This beautiful temple is surrounded by a garden of hydrangeas blooming in many colors. The majority of visitors are local people, so not many tourists visit this place. Highly recommended to visit during June in Hydrangea season.

One of the main component of tourist attraction in Uji, Kyoto. I visit during the hot sunny day, yet many visitors still come to enjoy the beauty of this temple. You can pray here by buying the 100Yen incense. More, you can try to touch the egg in the rabbit stomach or cow's mouth. You can enjoy and have a bit walk around this place to observe the beauty.

name: Amanohashidate Chairlift and Monorail
reviews:
Riding the Amanohashidate Chairlift and Monorail Â§©Ê©ãÁ´ã„Éì„É•„Éº„É©„É≥„Éâ „É™„Éï„Éà„Éª„É¢„Éé„É¨„Éº„É´Â±±È∫ìÈßÖ was a fantastic and very enjoyable experience. The ride itself feels relaxing, and slowly going up the hillside gives you a beautiful chance to take in the scenery. Looking out over the mountains, the ocean, and the famous sandbar all at the same time is really impressive.

We visited during the red-leaves season, and the colors made the view even more amazing. The bright autumn foliage, the blue water, and the gentle coastline all come together to create a picture-perfect scene. It feels like watching nature from above, almost like floating through a landscape painting.

The chairlift has a fun open-air feeling, while the monorail is comfortable and easy, so both options are great depending on what you prefer. Overall, the ride up to View Land was a wonderful and memorable part of the visit, with some of the most beautiful views in the area. üåøüçÅüåä‚ú®

Wow! The chair lift ride was a breathtaking experience, offering stunning views of Amanohashidate's picturesque sandbar and the Sea of Japan. The serene atmosphere and majestic scenery made it a memorable experience. Once you reach the top, there's even more to explore - try the sky bike, merry-go-round, or simply unwind at the cafe while taking in the views.

The chairlift itself is very very good! The views are magnificent! I didn‚Äôt have any wait at all. The staff is very friendly. At first it was a bit scary, but if you sit properly you‚Äôll definitely be okay. In winter the staff even put some sack on the seats, presumably to make the seats not too cold I guess.
Great place with great views! We made it to the chair lift at 4:30pm on the dot. Fee is 1,000 yen per person if I remember correctly.

What an awesome place, clearly one of the best views in Japan. Get out of Tokyo, Osaka and Kyoto and explore a bit, Japan has these gems. We cycled through the park before going to the view land. It was like meditation, all our stress gone.

name: Amanohashidate Viewland
reviews:
Stunning views and light‚Äëhearted fun! We took the chairlift up to the top and were rewarded with breathtaking panoramas of the Amanohashidate sandbar ‚Äî especially the famous ‚Äòmatanozoki‚Äô view where it looks like a dragon soaring into the sky when you look at it upside down.

The scenic lookout itself is worth the trip, and there are a few small rides and attractions like a Ferris wheel, merry‚Äëgo‚Äëround, and pedal cars that are perfect if you‚Äôre visiting with kids.

It‚Äôs a great stop for photos and relaxing with the view of one of Japan‚Äôs ‚ÄòThree Scenic Views.‚Äô If you‚Äôre short on time, even a quick visit for the views alone is rewarding. A fun and memorable part of our Kyoto trip!"

It is a very beautiful place with stunning scenery. The view from the top of the mountain is breathtaking. The cable car ride from the base station to the summit is fun and feels very safe. At the top, there is a small theme park with a train and a Ferris wheel, which adds to the overall experience. A must come if you are around!

Visiting Amanohashidate Viewland Â§©Ê©ãÁ´ã„Éì„É•„Éº„É©„É≥„Éâ was a very good and enjoyable experience. The viewpoint offers a wonderful panorama of the famous sandbar, surrounded by mountains and the ocean on both sides. The scenery is beautiful and gives a clear idea of why Amanohashidate is known as one of Japan‚Äôs famous views.

Walking around the area at the top is pleasant, with different spots where you can stop, take photos, and enjoy the landscape from various angles. The atmosphere is relaxed, and it‚Äôs easy to spend time here just looking out over the bay and the long stretch of pine trees below.

It‚Äôs a great place to appreciate nature and take in the impressive scenery, especially on a clear day. Overall, Amanohashidate Viewland is a lovely spot to enjoy beautiful views and a memorable moment in the area. üåøüåä‚ú®

Amanohashidate View Land Park is absolutely worth the visit. The views are stunning, especially from the famous ‚Äúupside-down‚Äù viewpoint, offering a breathtaking perspective of one of Japan‚Äôs most iconic landscapes.

The park itself is well-maintained and family-friendly, with simple rides and open spaces that make it enjoyable without feeling overly commercialised. The atmosphere is relaxed and pleasant, making it a great place to spend time rather than just a quick photo stop.

Highly recommend trying the pudding and ice cream at the park - both are excellent and surprisingly good quality. Simple, fresh, and perfect after walking around while enjoying the view.

A well-rounded experience combining scenery, leisure, and good treats. Definitely a must-visit in Amanohashidate.

What a fab idea to combine an amusement park with a grand scenic lookout - great for families with kids and even for couples and adult groups alike!

Really fun rides that give a higher vantage viewpoint - cycle ride and the Ferris wheel. But there are also other rides, like go-kart, carousel, shooting gallery, archery. Tickets are ¬•400 per person per ride, regardless of the ride type, and can be purchased at the ticket self-service machine at the souvenir shop next to the Ferris wheel ride.

There is also a restaurant here the serves ice cream and hot food (rice and hot noodles soup). Ample toilets are around and they also provided a tent with a heater placed inside to take shelter from the rain (we visited early Dec, and when we came, it was raining, so the tents were very useful, temp was 8 degrees Celsius).

name: Philosopher's Path (Tetsugaku no Michi)
reviews:
Strolling along Philosopher‚Äôs Path in autumn feels like walking through a quiet painting.

The canal reflects red and gold leaves, and the gentle path lined with temples and old houses brings a calm that settles in instantly. A simple, peaceful walk, yet one that lingers long after.

Serene walk in December, away from the hurly-burly of life and away from the hustle and bustle of Kyoto.

The path was pretty deserted and the trees almost leafless but the air was crisp and the sky clear leading to an unforgettable afternoon stroll in a very historic city

To avoid the crowds, I did the walk south onto the Philosopher‚Äôs Path. From H≈çnen-in, you walk downhill toward Nanzen-ji direction. You‚Äôll follow the canal ‚Äî this is the Philosopher‚Äôs Path proper. Go off path, explore, take your time. Travelling in Autumn was a bonus as was late afternoon light.

Well that's odd: Google decided to place this review for a place in Kyoto when in fact it was entered for a place in Heidelberg, Germany. Someone apparently noticed it and that helped me to notice it. Let's see if I can sort this thing out as Google's clearly not up to the task.... I should I should add, of course that Kyoto is a simply awesome place to visit and now that I know that there's also a philosopher's walk there. I'm definitely going to visit there next time I'm in town.

A very nice place to visit with exquisite views of the old town and castle in Heidelberg. Parking is a little bit of a challenge in this area so if you can't secure parking at the local garage then you may have to walk much further. On this note I should mention that the closest garage has been remarked by some to be extraordinarily claustrophobic but I had no problems navigating two in or from it.

Good place to stroll around Kyoto. It would be very beautiful during autumn and cherry blossom season. Nothing fancy, just a nice area to walk and to enjoy environment including seeing and being seen by others.
address: Shishigatani Teranomaecho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto, 606-8426, Japan

name: Murin-an Garden
reviews:
This intimate yet thoughtfully designed space packs all the essential elements of a traditional Japanese garden into one compact experience. The main tatami-floored viewing room offers comfortable seating where you can enjoy seasonal sweets while contemplating the view.

Step outside to discover their specialty - an exquisite moss garden featuring remarkable biodiversity. The carefully curated varieties create a lush green tapestry that changes character with the seasons.

Photography enthusiasts will appreciate that landscape shots are freely permitted (though portrait photography requires an additional fee). For convenience, tickets can be purchased online or with cash on-site.

This hidden gem beautifully distills the essence of Japanese garden design into an accessible, rewarding visit. The attention to detail in both the architecture and horticulture makes it well worth including in your Kyoto itinerary.
Zen was an understatement when visiting this beautiful garden in early November. The crowd was very very small still. Not sure how it‚Äôs like during peak travel seasons.

My husband and I visited this hidden garden in June 2023, and it was truly a wonderful experience. We purchased our tickets on-site, which included tea and a cookie‚Äîa lovely touch. The place was peaceful and not crowded at all, making it even more enjoyable. We would definitely love to visit again!

Pretty garden, not as manicured as most Japanese gardens, interesting history. This is why I gave it only 3 stars- when booking, they stressed that they only allow small groups in so you can have a calming experience and enjoy strolling the garden at your own pace. When we entered, there were at least 12 people waiting and there were at least 20 others milling about. I‚Äôm glad we didn‚Äôt opt for the tea and sweets as we probably wouldn‚Äôt have enjoyed it much with people walking around us, talking into their smartphones while narrating videos, and taking selfies. It is not a large building or garden so it seemed congested to me. I guess that‚Äôs to be expected now that Kyoto is one of the biggest tourist destinations in all of Japan. Too bad.
A beautiful garden, we visited when leaves just started to get red. The staff was lovely.
address: Nanzenji Kusakawacho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto, 606-8437, Japan

name: Arashiyama Bamboo Forest
reviews:
The Beauty of the Arashiyama Bamboo Grove
