‚ÄãA Vertical Cathedral: The towering stalks of bamboo create a sense of infinite verticality. In the second image, looking up toward the sky, the interlocking canopy filters the sunlight, creating a "Komorebi" effect‚Äîwhere light dances through the leaves like a natural stained-glass window.
‚ÄãA Palette of Natural Tones: There is a beautiful contrast between the cool, silver-green hues of the bamboo culms and the warm, earthy browns of the traditional "Take-gaki" (bamboo branch fences). These fences don't just mark a path; they ground the ethereal forest in Japanese craftsmanship and history.
‚ÄãThe Sound of Silence (and Movement): Even in a still photo, you can almost hear the "clacking" of the stalks and the rustling leaves. The third image, showing visitors wandering through the path, highlights the scale of the grove‚Äîmaking the humans look small against the majesty of nature.
‚ÄãA Path of Contemplation: The winding dirt paths and the rhythmic patterns of the bamboo create a meditative atmosphere. It is a place where the bustling modern world (represented by the tourists) meets an ancient, towering stillness that feels frozen in time.

Visiting Arashiyama Bamboo Forest was one of those Kyoto moments that really stayed with me. Walking between the towering bamboo felt surreal, almost like stepping into another world where everything slows down. The way the light filters through the tall green stalks and the soft sound of the bamboo swaying in the wind creates a calm, almost meditative atmosphere that‚Äôs hard to find anywhere else.

I went early in the morning, which made a huge difference. It was quieter, cooler, and felt more peaceful before the crowds arrived. Taking my time along the path, I found myself just looking up, breathing it all in, and appreciating how simple yet powerful the scenery is. The walk itself isn‚Äôt very long, but it doesn‚Äôt need to be ‚Äî the experience is more about the feeling than the distance.

What I loved most is how close it is to other beautiful spots. After the bamboo forest, wandering around Arashiyama, crossing Togetsukyo Bridge, and grabbing a coffee nearby made the whole area feel like a perfect day out. Yes, it gets busy later on, but even then, the bamboo forest still feels special. It‚Äôs one of those places that reminds you why Kyoto is so unforgettable and why slowing down while traveling really matters.

Arashiyama Bamboo Forest Review (Expert Traveler Insight)

If you want to know what silence looks like, open the photos first. This is one of those rare places where the pictures tell half the story ‚Äî and the experience tells the rest. As an experienced traveler and detailed reviewer, I can confidently say Arashiyama Bamboo Forest stands among the most breathtaking natural walks I‚Äôve ever taken.

This forest isn‚Äôt just famous ‚Äî it deserves the hype. The towering bamboo creates a cathedral-like canopy that feels peaceful, almost spiritual. But here‚Äôs the real insider tip: take a rickshaw. Yes, it sounds touristy, but it‚Äôs actually the smartest way to explore. Your guide brings you through special inner routes that the general public cannot access, helping you avoid the crowds entirely. They also take incredible photos for you ‚Äî shots you simply cannot get on your own.

Beyond the forest, the surrounding market area, fall colors, and side streets add even more to the experience. Plan for at least 4‚Äì6 hours to enjoy it without rushing, and make sure you dress for the weather as it can feel cooler under the bamboo.

This was one of the most unforgettable parts of our Japan trip ‚Äî peaceful, iconic, and absolutely worth every minute. Don‚Äôt leave Kyoto without experiencing this.

Quite crowded but a beautiful area. It is worthwhile also visiting the Snow Monkey Park as well to round off the trip. Local river is stunning with greater and lesser Egrets and cormorants. Also had fun hiring a kimono and walking around the temples and villages with the red maple leaves. I would say that if you wanted a quieter tranquil bamboo forest the side hike up to Mt Inari near Tori gates was more serene.

Best is to arrive before 10 am due to crowds.
If you want to do the train ride üöÇ you should book in advance and the boat ride üõ∂ we couldn‚Äôt do due to cold weatherü•∂

You can walk towards Otagi temple, it‚Äôs quite scenic neighborhood and also less crowded. On the way you‚Äôll have coffee/tea spots üçµ ‚òïÔ∏è see my other reviews to see which one i recommend!
address: Sagaogurayama Tabuchiyamacho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto, 616-8394, Japan

name: Okochi Sanso Garden
reviews: A very beautiful place to admire nature and the views of the city. Another attraction (included in the ticket price) is tea tasting. I suppose that in the summer, when everything is in bloom, you can truly appreciate the charm of this place. I highly recommend this place.

Well worth a visit! I believe it‚Äôs 1000 yen to enter, but it‚Äôs much quieter than at the bamboo forest and it‚Äôs very pretty.
You‚Äôre starting to see some autumn colours (mid October), and the garden is just wonderful. The views of Kyoto from the top are also lovely as you can frame the vistas with the surrounding foliage.
You walk most of the time through isolated stones that can be a tad slippery if their wet (it rained this morning) so be careful and bring adequate shoes.
Not suited for wheelchairs or strollers.
You‚Äôll also be able to hear and possibly see some beautiful birds ‚ù§Ô∏è

Well worth to visit this beautiful garden estate, in my opinion even more than the garden of a hundred flowers. Incredible scenery and perfectly cared for plants. The Zen garden part should not be missed. We probably spend 30 minutes there relaxing and taking it in.

Worth to visit here!! I never known this place before , just walked through Arashiyama bamboo and found this stunning place.
The garden is very big, entrance fee is just 1000 yen. Inside , there is a relaxing place with tea free of charge.
The atmosphere is superb !!

Beautiful gardens with amazing views. I was disappointed though that on my visit the tea house had closed down ( it was removed from the signage too). The price at 1000Y was high when compared with the most famous gardens in Japan. If you are in the bamboo forest, a walk through the free park there is equally rewarding.
address: 8 Sagaogurayama Tabuchiyamacho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto, 616-8394, Japan

name: Izu Panorama Park
reviews:
We were in the area for a family weekend onsen trip and noticed cable cars while driving on the highway. We came back the following day as weather was clear and Mt. Fuji was fully visible.

At 3,500 yen per adult, ticket price is steep. Having said that, if you plan to spend at least a few hours here and enjoy amazing views, into photography, or spending it with a special someone, it could be worth it. The viewing area above is well-maintained and seems to have received recent upgrades. If you have a stroller, which we had, you won't be able to see/access every area.

In terms of food and drink, coffee was disappointing but the black curry was pretty good! We also enjoyed the dango, and while youkan was too sweet for our liking, we couldn't resist getting them for the photo opp.

There is a very nice view of Mount Fuji from here. The round-trip ropeway fare on this day was ¬•3,500. The black curry they served was very delicious; however, the coffee was disappointing. I ordered a chocolate latte, but it tasted watered down and stale‚Äîand I‚Äôm not even a coffee snob.

The garden looks especially nice at night. On this day, there were no clouds, so Mount Fuji was clearly visible. I arrived around 4:30 p.m., and they close at 5:30 p.m. There were very few people at that time, which made it a great way to enjoy the evening quietly.

The view at the top is breathtaking!! The tranquility and beauty of Mt.Fuji gave me the chills because it is purely beautiful to see and admire.
You can choose to hike up the mountain. Because we're travelling with two kids under 4yo -- we opt for the cable car. It is clean, roomy, and very well maintained. Not scary at all~
There are many facilities at the top. There are cafes, some eateries, souvenir shops, a small shrine area, kids playground, a food onsen and plenty photo spots with Mt Fuji as backdrop.
My kids went straight to the kids area first (of coz) - climbing ropes, flying foxes, slides, etc. There isn't any soft paddings on the ground.....most are dirt and rocks....so would suggest supervising the younger kids when they are playing.
Go make time and get a drink or small snack at the cafe, so that you can enjoy the seating they have near the infinity "pool". There are massive day bed sofas available outside too....which i believe you can rent hourly.
The food are delicious and reasonably priced!!
Definitely worth visiting when in the area :D
Visited back in Oct 2022.

well landscaped and up lifting refurbishing of a viewing park
souvenirs were really expensive
we enjoyed the foot bath a lot

Great experience. We went around 3pm and it wasn't crowded at all. We had the cable car to ourselves and get to enjoy the amazing view. The view of Mt Fuji at the top was amazing. There's few restaurants at the top which you can sit and enjoy the view. Comes with a small garden for you to walk along and a free foot spa with an amazing view! Parking was free. The shop sells a lot of cute souvenirs and Japan snacks!
address: Japan, „Äí410-2211 Shizuoka, Izunokuni, Nagaoka, ÔºíÔºñÔºê‚àíÔºë Â±±È∫ìÈßÖ 1F

name: Dogashima Park
reviews: A truly beautiful and well-organized place for a family trip. The availability of halal food and a dedicated prayer area for Muslims ü§≤ exceeded all expectations ‚Äî it was beyond imagination.

One of the best and most underrated place of Japan.Full of natural beauty and beautiful oceanic view.
There is natural mountain rock whose shape is just like Elephant and tortoise.
The parking is huge and free of cost.
However its far from main town area like Shizuoka.
Access is very inconvenient coz only few local buses runs there.
You have to pay a transportation charges in two stops so make sure to bring a changes when you go there.
We didn't knew about that but some how we able to manage to pay the road tax.
You can also observe the canyons via ships.
You have to pay some amount of yen and then you can see the rocks,oceans via ship.
The ship takes about 20-30min to complete its trip and worth to its price as well.
Really a beautiful place to visit.
Highly recommended.
This is a great park with bathrooms and easy walking paths. The overlooks are amazing and the stairs aren't too bad. The views are great though.
This place is cool but at night it‚Äôs amazing and beautiful! It‚Äôs full of lights and for some reason, no people. It was just me there last night and I was in love with the beauty

This place is accessible by bus from Izukyu Shimoda station. Bus is on limited time only. Better to get bus pass from Shimoda station itself. You can go by your own vehicle also. Boat ride was closed when we wet there. Its just a small park around sea shore. You can get food here. Parking is available. Convenience store also available. Place needs maximum 1 hour to see all places.
address: Nishina, Nishiizu, Kamo District, Shizuoka 410-3514, Japan

name: Hagachizaki Monkey Bay
reviews: This was a nice little spot to see the monkeys run around freely. After you turn off the main road and drive down the road to get down to this spot it is a little sketchy. Very narrow and tree limbs and big rocks in the road. However, I am still glad we made the trip here. I wouldn‚Äôt go out of your way to come but if you are nearby it is entertaining to check out. 1200¬• per adult to pay and walk down to the monkeys. There were several people who did not want to pay so they just stood in the parking lot and watched from above. You can pay ¬•1000 for a bucket of food and feed the monkeys or ¬•300 for a cup. There were a lot of babies this visit.

A picturesque bay with a stunning beach where monkeys roam freely, adding to the unique charm of the spot. You can buy food to feed them and capture some great photos. Be sure to bring some small change if you plan to purchase monkey food. A fun visit if you love monkeys!

We arrived late but I feel like it was worth the trek.  As many mentioned the drive is a little difficult, so just be cautious.  I like that the humans are in the cage when feeding.  The staff was very kind and I feel like they took care of the place.  I know some complain of the fee but it takes money to keep a place like this clean and operating, so keep that in mind.  Very cute monkeys.

This is a great place if you like monkeys and want to see them outside of a zoo. They are not captive here and roam freely. I would guess they choose to hang around here because they are fed here.

They are still wild though so follow the rules.

It is located in a beautiful bay between 2 tall cliffs. You can see the monkeys climbing the cliffs, especially after they are fed and bored after eating.

There is only one type of monkey here as it is the native species to Japan, the Japanese macaque, also known as the Japanese snow monkey as many famous pictures of them are in the snow sitting in hot springs.

There is a building you can go inside and purchase food to feed the monkeys through bars. You are the captive here and the monkeys reach through the bars to get the food from you. They will fight over it so don‚Äôt be alarmed.

There were dozens of monkeys out when we came. They will walk close to you and are not afraid of people, but they are wild. Again, follow the rules. We had no problems with them.

I would come here everyday if I lived nearby.

The drive is long and difficult to get here but worth it for me.
Expensive but worth it. Could be better maintained for the price. The road to the bay is hazardous. I saw someone driving a BMW with a flat tire but we made it just fine. The monkeys were cute!
address: 2622-1 Ihama, Minamiizu, Kamo District, Shizuoka 415-0531, Japan

name: Mt. Nesugata Summit Observation Deck
reviews:
I was tossing up whether the 1500¬• on the cable car was worth the trip. It was. If you have good weather and visibility I highly recommend this whole complex. The history, gardens, shrine and lookouts are all excellent. There is even a restaurant at the top, though I did not go there.
Highly recommend!

Great spot to experience a piece of Japanese history: commodore Perry landing site. Found this place by accident too

Short cable car ride to a beautiful park with outstanding views on a hilltop. Recommend as picnic spot

Mt. Nesugata Summit Observation Deck (ÂØùÂßøÂ±ïÊúõÂè∞) offers breathtaking panoramic views of Shimoda Bay, steeped in history and natural beauty. Highlights include an old cannon, historic info boards, and a peaceful walking area. (4/5)

Full Review
Mt. Nesugata Summit Observation Deck ‚Äì A View with Substance and Style
Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ (4/5)

The summit of Mount Nesugata (ÂØùÂßøÂ±±) is more than just another scenic overlook‚Äîit‚Äôs a blend of natural splendor, subtle historical reverence, and understated refinement, all perched above the charming port town of Shimoda.

After taking the Shimoda Ropeway, which itself is a smooth and scenic ride if timed right, you arrive at the summit and are immediately rewarded with stunning panoramic views of Shimoda Bay. The real centerpiece is the harbor vista, which unfolds beneath you like a living painting‚Äîone that, during my visit, was graced by a ship that looked plucked from a different era, sailing among modern vessels. It‚Äôs this juxtaposition‚Äîpast and present sharing the same waters‚Äîthat quietly underscores the site‚Äôs historical weight.

Wander a little and you‚Äôll encounter a cannon and its miniature replica, next to an informative plaque recounting an 1849 encounter between an English survey ship and the Tokugawa shogunate‚Äôs reconnaissance efforts. It‚Äôs not a full-on museum, but the touches of history are thoughtfully placed and help contextualize the location beyond its visual appeal. A few whimsical touches‚Äîlike a large anchor, a photo pod capsule that hints at future upgrades, and some 100-yen binoculars‚Äîadd layers of interactivity to the site. Nature-wise, although the flowers had passed their prime when I visited, buzzing bees and coastal breezes still made for an atmospheric stroll.

While it‚Äôs true that many of the summit‚Äôs photo spots offer variations of the same vantage point, they‚Äôre so arrestingly beautiful that you really won‚Äôt mind. The entire experience is well-paced, scenic, and respectful of both history and hospitality.

In sum: Mt. Nesugata‚Äôs summit is worth more than just a few photos‚Äîit‚Äôs a place to slow down, learn a little, breathe deeply, and perhaps most pleasantly, eat very well while doing so (at The Royal House restaurant). A recommended stop for those exploring Shimoda and seeking something both scenic and soulful.

Gives a beautiful view of Izu peninsula.
You need to hike up to see more beautiful views
Beautiful volcano top with a good view of the Shimoda bay. Nice garden too. Worth spending an hour here.

name: Izu Shaboten Zoo
reviews: If you like capybara‚Äòs, this is the place to go. I‚Äôve been to a capybara Caf√© before but this zoo cannot compare. You get to feed the capybara. You get to touch them. There‚Äôs like 40 of them if not more and even the other animals in the other part of the zoo is worth the visit. It is super unique and really really cool experience. You have a lot of rabbits and other animals that you‚Äôre also get to pet and feed. You can also go up Mount Otoru nearby and walk around there. This area is really lovely and it is worth a visit.

I‚Äôve been to this zoo before, and one of the highlights was getting to see the capybaras taking a bath. We also had the chance to feed them, which was a fun and memorable experience. The zoo is a bit out of the way, but you can buy food there and feed many of the animals, making the trip well worth it.

I came back to experience it again, but I wouldn‚Äôt recommend visiting during the summer. The heat makes the animal smells much stronger, which can be quite unpleasant. Visiting during a cooler season would make the experience far more enjoyable.

If you‚Äôve just ridden the Mt. Omuro cable car (the tram that takes you to the top of the grassy volcano), turn around and walk literally across the road ‚Äî that‚Äôs where you‚Äôll find Izu Shaboten Zoo. It‚Äôs the perfect laid-back half-day activity after the view from the summit.

This isn‚Äôt one of those massive, exhausting zoos. It‚Äôs compact, shady, and genuinely cozy. On the weekday I visited, it felt almost private ‚Äî hardly any crowds, just the sound of gravel underfoot and the occasional peacock screech.

Of course, the undisputed stars are the capybaras. They have a huge outdoor area with a hot-spring bath (yes, the capybaras actually soak in an onsen in winter ‚Äî adorable doesn‚Äôt even begin to cover it). Even in summer they‚Äôre ridiculously chill, lounging in the water or munching grass while visitors watch in quiet awe.

Other highlights:
‚Ä¢  Free-roaming peacocks that follow you around like they own the place (one decided to walk with me for a solid ten minutes ‚Äî best escort ever).
‚Ä¢  A fantastic walk-through bird zone where flamingos, sacred ibis, ducks, geese, and spoonbills wander right past your feet. No cages, just a big netted area ‚Äî you really feel like you‚Äôve stepped into their world.
‚Ä¢  Classic zoo lineup done well: cheeky otters, wallabies, antelopes, donkeys, turkeys, parrots, even a few lazy sloths hanging in the greenhouse section.

My only tiny disappointment was that the shoebill wasn‚Äôt on display the day I went (apparently he sometimes takes ‚Äúdays off‚Äù inside). Next time!

Everything feels lovingly maintained, the paths are easy, there are plenty of benches in the shade, and the whole vibe is relaxed and happy. Combine it with the cable car and the cactus greenhouse (the ‚Äúshaboten‚Äù part of the name) next door, and you‚Äôve got yourself a perfect easygoing afternoon on the Izu Plateau.

Zoos in Japan can apparently be notoriously bad in terms on animal welfare standards. This one was good in some ways/parts, bad in others. It is quite a large zoo, with many different areas, and glasshouses for lots of different plants. It seems that thought and care has gone into making some of the outdoor enclosures feel natural and enriching for the animals. Places like the walkthrough enclosures and free roaming animals (the bird paradise, the wallabies, farm animals, around the lake, the peacocks) were mostly good as it was the people that were kept to a small portion, not the animals, who had sufficient space to do their own thing. Although the kangaroos seemed perhaps drugged (eyes closed) to make them docile around humans which isn't good if so. The capybara onsen was great, and it was nice to feed the capybara in other parts of the park, although the keepers were prodding them around unnecessarily. But this zoo just had too many animals to house and care for them all sufficiently. The largest animals (giraffes, tapirs?) didnt really have enough space. In particular the animals kept in small indoor tanks/enclosures seemed stressed and unhappy. I'm not sure if they were indoors just for the winter cold weather (some of the outdoor animals seemed a bit chilly) or at all times of year. The fact that visitors can feed them seems with some animals be a bad idea because the animals with not much else to do then end up unnaturally begging for food from all visitors, and its quite sad (binturong, cloud rats). In particular the indoor-only primates seemed unhappy (marmosets, lemurs in cage). I'm not sure if perhaps they were being kept indoors because they were ill and needed monitoring or if this was where they spent all their time. The zoo should reduce the number of animals, rehoming some of those who don't have enough space or things to do (particularly the mammals- monkeys, kangaroos, large animals like giraffes and tapirs), giving more space to others and focus on the ones that are more suited to the areas and to being in a captivity (amphibians, reptiles, birds, farm animals, very chill animals like capybara ).

If you love capybaras, Izu Shaboten Zoo is the place to go. Seeing the capybaras in winter, quietly soaking in their yuzu baths, was such a simple joy.

The zoo has a very laid back, open feel, making it easy to wander around and enjoy the animals at your own pace. On top of that, there was a fantastic view of Mount Fuji from the zoo, which made the whole experience feel even more special.

name: Atami Sun Beach
reviews: We visited Sun Beach in August 2025. Although the posted swimming hours are 9:00-16:00, in reality most continue to swim after that, just without lifeguards. The sand is soft and the water is fairly shallow and calm. It is very nice to come at night for the illuminations. There were also many families doing fireworks in the sand. There are coin lockers, toilets, showers and footwashes (free), and dumpsters on the beach for trash.

Worth to go to watch the firework show. Perfect view on the beach. It‚Äôs an unforgettable experience for my kids. We went on a public holiday but not crowded at all. Probably it‚Äôs the last day of the holiday, local people need to go work the next day. We went there in late November, a bit chilling at night so better dress warm for the weather

A beach popular with locals as well as tourists to Atami. There is a breakwater promenade on the south side if the beach, hosting a pier for recreational boats, and is a nice place to sit and relax in the evenings. The sun is strongest here in the mornings, given that it faces east.
Awesome beach with lots of bars along the coast. Has a great view of Mt Fuji in the distance.
An amazing beach. You can play different activities here. It's perfect to have a bottle of cold beer walking on the beach in hot summer.

name: Atami Ginza Shopping Street
reviews: Old, and quiet, but I rather liked the selection of shops! We had a great time picking up little goodies along the way, and also found a retro kissaten (BONNET) along one of the side alleys.
Lovely spot, so many food options bars and the best coffee in Atami.

I don't know about this place but i like the owner response to other comment that they will make atami ginza better. That attitude is very good. I respect that.
I will visit in 7 December to watch the firework also.
There are not many shops at this ‚Äúshopping district‚Äù.  Most of the businesses are restaurants and ice cream shops.  Not worth the visit if you only spend a little time in this city.
It is crowded, but fun to see many stores.

name: Atami Castle
reviews: Atami Castle is located on a higher ground at Atami, relatively small compared to other castles such as Nagoya Castle, Matsumoto Castle, etc. It is not really for its architecture, but for its ocean view, castle museum exhibiting most (if not all) castles in Japan, exhibitions, which are pretty interesting too. We spent almost 1.5 hours (slow pace) at the castle. The entrance fee is 1200 yen per person. We took the ropeway (cable car) up to the castle.

Jan 18, 2026
Passed by on the way to Hihokan but didn‚Äôt enter. Didn‚Äôt look too bad but I can see how it can stand pale compared to other historically rich castles. The trick art museum aspect didn‚Äôt draw me in either. ¬•1,200 for a ticket to either the castle or the trick art museum or ¬•2,000 for a combo ticket.
We really enjoyed all of the model's and history of japanese castles. The views are stunning.   Taking the rope way up is very unique. Skip the 3rd floor folks...If there's a trap... it's this one

The view from this tourist castle is nice.  And the samurai museum is cool. But remember this was created I the 1950's to attract tourists so it's not a real castle.
There's plenty of parking if you drive right up to the castle.

Even though it's an old Japanese-style castle, I wondered why the inside wasn't cramped, and it seems to be because the building was constructed in 1958. Floors 1 to 5 are museums, and the 6th floor is an observation deck. The first basement floor had a free arcade, which I really liked because unlike the arcades outside where you have to insert a coin every time you die in a game, here you could play the arcade machines for free without limit.

name: Katsuoji
reviews:
The Vibrant Charm of Katsuo-ji
‚ÄãThe temple grounds are a breathtaking blend of spiritual tradition and natural splendor. Everywhere you turn, thousands of bright crimson Daruma dolls peek out from stone walls, bridge railings, and wooden shelves, their wide-eyed expressions creating a playful yet powerful atmosphere of perseverance.
‚ÄãThe contrast between the bold red lacquer of the dolls and the muted, earthy tones of the surrounding forest is particularly striking. In the winter, as seen in your photos, a light dusting of snow adds a quiet, magical layer to the landscape, making the "Winner's Luck" charms stand out even more vividly against the misty mountains.
‚ÄãThe centerpiece of the temple is its expansive koi pond, where the mist often rolls over the water, reflecting the elegant bridges and the distant pagoda. It is a place where every corner feels like a carefully composed painting‚Äîa perfect harmony of man-made devotion and the wild beauty of the Osaka hills.
‚ÄãKey Highlights from your photos:
‚ÄãThe Daruma Shelves: A mountain of luck, showing the sheer scale of the prayers left behind by visitors.
‚ÄãThe Lakeside View: The tiny Daruma "omikuji" (fortune) dolls perched on rocks by the water create a whimsical, miniature world.
‚ÄãThe Atmosphere: The snowy, overcast sky provides a soft, atmospheric light that enhances the spiritual and tranquil mood of the temple.

We pulled up to Katsuoji Temple kinda late in the day and low key thought we‚Äôd already missed peak autumn season.but NOPE. This place came through with the brightest, most gorgeous fall colors we saw our whole trip. Absolute slay üçÅüî•

From the station you‚Äôll need to hop on a bus to reach the temple. We went on a weekday and it was still crowded everyone  was taking pictures. But we still managed to get our shots, so don‚Äôt stress. Worth it.

The entrance ticket includes a postcard you stamp along the way, and once you‚Äôre done you end up with a super cute completed one. Loved that little experience. There are also souvenirs (the daruma dolls are a whole vibe), and the day we went there was even a stall selling castella cake. Say less.

Overall? Peaceful, stunning, and totally unforgettable. If you‚Äôre chasing autumn leaves in Japan this is THE spot. Highly recommended üôå‚ú®

One of the most beautiful and authentic temples for me. The walk is easy, the gardens beautiful, the lake calm and overall the whole experience is very inspiring for the soul. I especially liked what daruma dolls represent. Recommend going in the mornings and buy ticket online in advance in order to skip the lines and not wait for too long. The mountains are beautiful so if you have a day- make sure to include a nice nature walk

I thought getting here would be difficult, but it‚Äôs actually very easy. The bus stop is right near the train station, and buses run often.

Tip: Make sure your IC card has enough balance for a round trip (about 1,600 yen). There is no place to top up at the temple.

Inside the temple, there‚Äôs a lot of walking, but every corner is beautiful. You can easily take over 300 photos. Besides the fun of collecting stamps (you have to walk around the temple to complete them), it‚Äôs also entertaining to observe how people place Daruma dolls everywhere‚Äîsome spots are honestly quite funny.

I recommend spending 2‚Äì3 hours here. I liked this temple more than Kiyomizu-dera because it‚Äôs less crowded and more peaceful.

A truly peaceful and unforgettable place.

Katsuoji is absolutely beautiful, and visiting while snow falls makes the experience even more special. The temple grounds feel calm and reflective, with the quiet snowfall adding a sense of serenity and stillness throughout the area.

The contrast between the vibrant temple buildings and the snow is stunning, and walking through the grounds encourages a slower, more mindful pace. The atmosphere feels both grounding and inspiring, making it easy to appreciate the surroundings and the moment.

For anyone seeking a peaceful, scenic, and atmospheric destination, Katsuoji is well worth a visit. Seeing it covered in snow creates a magical experience that leaves a lasting impression.

name: Kurashiki Bikan Historical Quarter
reviews: At first it seems a little theme park like but it is actually quite charming. Lots of small streets with various shops. Some with tacky souvenirs others with nice things. Lots of upcycled denim goods. After dark when the shops are closed it is nice to stroll along the canal. We didn't stay long enough to venture out of the historical district but I suspect that Kurashiki has more to offer than this nice little spot.

Once a political and commercial centre of Kurashiki, Bikan Quarter is now preserved as a historical district attracting visitors from all over the world. Accessible directly from Osaka but I chose to stay a night in Kurashiki to enjoy the area.

The canal is beautiful with historical buildings alongside it, you‚Äôd spot swans swimming there as well. It was not crowded when I visited so I got to take a lot of nice photos. Look for hidden gems in cage, denim store and even brewery in this area.

I bet that this place is even charming during Sakura seasons.

Really serene and eerily beautiful at night when the shops close and tourists are gone.

Was great just to wander around a d soak up the atmosphere.

Not a lot of parking so I would suggest walking.

Delightful quaint historical center full of unique shops & cafes. It‚Äôs a place where beautiful Japanese wooden architecture meets European touch. One can explore a breathtaking vista through walking in its tranquil landscape.

Recommendations: set aside enough time to visit here.
Boat ride: until 15:00
Parking: plenty of paid parking available yet hardly can found.

In front of KURASHIKI CITY ART MUSEUM parking offers Budget parking.

üåü "A charming blend of history, culture, and canals ‚Äî Bikan Historical Quarter"
Bikan Historical Quarter in Kurashiki is a true step back in time, where beautiful Japanese wooden buildings meet elegant touches of European architecture. Strolling along the scenic canal, with its willow trees and peaceful atmosphere, feels like walking through a living postcard.

The streets are lined with unique souvenir shops, perfect for finding special gifts, as well as cozy caf√©s and restaurants to relax and enjoy a coffee or a meal. The area is also impressively wheelchair-friendly, making it easy for everyone to explore at their own pace.

Tip: Take your time here ‚Äî the magic is in the slow walk, soaking in the details, and letting the blend of history and nature work its charm. A must-visit when you visit Japan!

name: S≈çunzan Station
reviews:
S≈çunzan Station is a calm and efficient transition point between the Hakone Tozan Cable Car and the Ropeway, and it feels like a natural pause before the scenery becomes more dramatic. The station is clean, compact, and easy to navigate, with staff guiding visitors smoothly between platforms. Even during steady foot traffic, the atmosphere stays relaxed, and the surrounding mountain air gives the place a refreshing feel.

While it‚Äôs not a major attraction on its own, S≈çunzan Station works well as a starting or ending point for exploring the higher elevations of Hakone. The views from the outdoor areas are surprisingly nice, especially on clear days, and the layout makes transfers quick. It earns a 4 out of 5 for convenience, cleanliness, and the gentle mountain ambiance.

We were at this station after taking the funicular train from Gora Station. We got on board the cable car which goes up to the Hakone area. The view is scenic and we could see the volcano with sulphur mines from the cable car.
Nice station and the end of the ropeway. You can have free foot-bath in hot water here. The view is beautiful. Can take the cable car down to Gora station.

Better station to start off with with free parking. Limited parking so come early or later. If u go to Kuwadani station, there will be jam going to carpark as it‚Äôs the main geothermal attraction and u will be stuck if u didn‚Äôt check google maps
Awesome cable car that gets you from one side of the mountain to the other. Beautiful views all around, definitely recommend it if you're in town.
address: Gora, Hakone, Ashigarashimo District, Kanagawa 250-0408, Japan

name: Enoura Observatory
reviews: Great views and location. Very peaceful experience, and somewhat spiritual. Would love to meet whoever created the space. Lots of walking, but good exercise. Would be nice if they don‚Äôt use sugar for their drinks, but apart from that, their Mikan Juice is fire. üî•

A true gem. Worth a visit to get away from the routine Japan overload. But go only if you trip is long enough to have covered other major attractions as this takes away half of your day. It's more a peaceful orange orchard located in an amazing location. Wish there was some good to enjoy while taking it all in. They do have lemonade kind of drinks, coffee and tea and honey made granola.

I called the morning of to ask if they have walk-in tickets and they said yes, they also put my name down for the shuttle from Nebukawa station
Beautiful architecture, very quiet/not busy in December. Definitely stop by if you‚Äôre heading to Hakone for a night

This place is tucked away in the countryside about 1.5hrs drive from Tokyo. It's best to book in advance for admission and free shuttle bus or parking permit, 3300 yen each person. It's closed at 4:30pm and the access to the bamboo forest is closed at 4pm. Some very exquisite architecture details, as well as spaces (Mies and Philip Johnson glass house vibe), displaying works by the designer/photographer himself. It's quite a little gem esp. if you can manage to visit during a cooler day.

It is difficult to categorize this facility with anything. The facility itself is art, the location is art, the ancient Japanese artifacts are art, and the fusion of these elements makes for a special experience. The cherry blossoms and rape blossoms were in full bloom, creating an Amazing landscape. The three hours are in the morning and afternoon, but the three hours go by quickly. Reservations are required through the website.

name: Hakone Venetian Glass Museum (Glass Forest)
reviews: Beautiful museum! Lovely installations in the outdoors that play with the natural sunlight, and plenty of beautiful art pieces on display indoors. I went in December so there was a big winter tree that started to shine beautifully with the natural sunlight as the sun started to set. There is a good Italian cafe, too, and at that time there was live music performance by musicians from Italy. Worth a visit for anyone into Italian art, as the whole place felt like a slice of Italy in the woods of Japan with an astonishing view of mountains and hot springs. That said, I think it's best to visit during spring or autumn time instead of December as the lack of natural flowers and greenery was apparent in some exhibition areas.

üìç Hakone Venetian Glass Museum (Glass Forest)
ÁÆ±Ê†π„Ç¨„É©„Çπ„ÅÆÊ£ÆÁæéË°ìÈ§® @ Hakone, Japan üáØüáµ

Visited on 20 November 2025 at 4pm.
The Hakone Venetian Glass Museum features beautiful Venetian glass set among a charming garden. The outdoor Glass Forest ‚ú® sparkled in the soft evening light, and the glowing glass Christmas tree üéÑ added a magical festive touch. The surrounding autumn leaves üçÅ created a stunning contrast with the shimmering glass, making the garden feel warm, colorful, and enchanting.

Inside, the museum displays delicate Venetian glass pieces and elegant artworks inspired by classic Italian craftsmanship. The crystal arches and pathways offer peaceful, fairy-tale scenery perfect for photos.

A sparkling and romantic Hakone spot ‚Äî Venetian glass, autumn leaves, and a glowing Christmas tree. ‚ú®üçÅüéÑüèõÔ∏è

An adventurous bus ride from Hakone into the hills. The entry fee is 1800 yen. Some amazing pieces in the collection. Many nice images to take on a sunny day. The shop there is large and a cool Eki stamp as you enter. Well worth the journey.

This is definitely worth a stop.  I was lucky to be there in November when the holiday lights were up.  The whole place was glowing and sparkling.  The gift shop is very large, and feels like an extension of the museum.
A must see if you love art nouveau and Lalique. A fine collection in Japan adding some culture sightseeing. Beautiful garden and cafe as well as a unique one of a kind gift shop.
address: 940-48 Sengokuhara, Hakone, Ashigarashimo District, Kanagawa 250-0631, Japan

name: Hakone Shrine
reviews:
Visiting Hakone Shrine on a weekday made the entire experience feel calm and unhurried. There was no wait to enter, and the walk through the tall cedar trees immediately set a peaceful tone. The path leading up to the shrine is beautifully maintained, and the atmosphere feels respectful without being overly crowded or commercial. Even with a few visitors around, there was plenty of space to pause, take in the surroundings, and appreciate the history of the site. The shrine buildings themselves are elegant and understated, blending naturally into the forest setting. I didn‚Äôt need to buy tickets in advance, and everything felt straightforward and accessible.

What stood out most was how grounding the entire visit felt. The combination of nature, tradition, and quiet moments made it easy to slow down and reflect. It‚Äôs a great stop for anyone wanting to experience the spiritual side of Hakone without feeling rushed or overwhelmed. The area around the shrine is also easy to explore, with clear paths and scenic viewpoints that add to the experience. Whether you‚Äôre traveling solo or with others, it‚Äôs a place that invites you to take your time and enjoy the stillness.

üìç Hakone Shrine ÁÆ±Ê†πÁ•ûÁ§æ
@ Hakone, Japan üáØüáµ

Visited on 20 November 2025.
Hakone Shrine is a peaceful, spiritual place surrounded by tall cedar trees and a refreshing forest atmosphere. The bright red shrine buildings and stone steps create a sacred, beautiful setting. It‚Äôs also known as a popular power spot, where many visitors come to pray for good fortune and blessings.

The walk through the quiet forest felt calming, and the shrine was well-maintained and welcoming. Together with the nearby Heiwa-no-Torii, it‚Äôs one of Hakone‚Äôs must-visit spots.

A serene and meaningful shrine ‚Äî beautiful forest path, sacred atmosphere, and a famous power spot in Hakone. ‚õ©Ô∏èüåø‚ú®

Little bit of a climb up the steps, but we'll worth it.  There are a few shrines throughout the area, but this is the largest of the bunch.  You can go up and make your offerings.  Set in the forest, very beautiful.  The cedar trees are humongous, just amazing.  The parking lot is not that far away.  There is also a small path you can follow instead of the steps.  It's just so peaceful and scenic, a must stop.

2nd shrine to visit in Japan and was not expecting to be as large as it was. Took car ride all the way from Tokyo and you could see a huge lake before climing to the top of the shrine. They also have a Soba shop in the parking area so was able to enjoy a nice hot meal before leaving

Hakone Shrine is a magical and atmospheric place.
Hidden among tall cedar trees and surrounded by nature, the shrine feels mysterious and deeply spiritual. The walk to the temple is already part of the experience.
Truly one of the most evocative spots in Hakone.
address: 80-1 Motohakone, Hakone, Ashigarashimo District, Kanagawa 250-0522, Japan

name: Tamadare Shrine
reviews:
This little shrine is a must visit. It is situated behind the carpark/building.
There are two waterfalls between the 150 stairs leading up to the small shrine. Check the map because there is a little hidden trail of stairs that takes you to a mini bamboo forest.

Visited this shrine with a waterfall on New Years Day and unfortunately it was closed due to Covid. Goshuin stamp was being dispensed from a vending type machine and no Ema‚Äôs were available. We couldn‚Äôt even purchase a omamori. You were able to walk around to see the two waterfalls on site and walk up to the shrine itself. Parking is available but in a lot and it cost ¬•500.

A small shinto shrine which requires a short hike up some flights of stairs. Worth a visit!

Visited in November 2024.
Free entry. Beautiful surroundings. Free to use foot onsen.
Well worth a visit
address: Yumoto, Hakone, Ashigarashimo District, Kanagawa 250-0311, Japan

name: K≈çdaiji Temple
reviews:
K≈çdai‚Äëji Temple in Kyoto offers one of the most refined blends of history, artistry, and atmosphere among the city‚Äôs many heritage sites. Founded in 1606 by Nene in memory of her husband, Toyotomi Hideyoshi, the temple carries a quiet emotional weight that becomes apparent as you move through its grounds. The craftsmanship is exceptional, delicate screens, and carefully preserved structures reflect the aesthetic sensibilities of the Momoyama period without feeling overly staged.

The strolling garden is the highlight. Designed by the legendary Kobori Ensh≈´, it unfolds in a series of elegant scenes: reflective ponds, stone arrangements, and pathways that guide you through shifting perspectives. Even with other visitors around, the garden maintains a sense of calm that encourages you to slow down and absorb the details. In autumn, the illuminated night displays transform the space into something almost ethereal, with maple leaves glowing against the water.

The bamboo grove, though smaller than Arashiyama‚Äôs, is more intimate and far less chaotic. It feels curated for contemplation rather than photography, which adds to the temple‚Äôs overall sense of balance and restraint.

One of my favorite temple visit in Kyoto. Yes very touristy, but I don't mind. I bought the temple entrance ticket bundle with Entokuin ticket and museum ticket. I visited during momiji season so the scenery and view is very beautiful. There was a small pond and the visiting route were clearly marked for guidance to the tourist. The temple ground is quite big there are some hilly area, slopes and stairs, so just be aware if you have weak knees.  You can just also relax and walk around the flat area. This temple also has a section with bamboo forest if you want to avoid crowd in Arashiyama. I visited late noon so there's quite a lot of people there waiting for the night illumination as well.

Kodaiji Temple Night Illumination Review

Kodaiji Temple‚Äôs nighttime illumination was one of the most breathtaking experiences of our Kyoto trip. The entire garden comes alive after dark ‚Äî fall trees glowing with soft spotlights, colors looking even richer and brighter, and a gentle light show projected near the temple that adds to the atmosphere without feeling overwhelming.

The walk through the grounds felt serene and almost magical. There‚Äôs a small bamboo forest here, and with the lights shining upward, the bamboo looked like it was glowing from within. Every corner felt peaceful, quiet, and beautifully designed to highlight the natural surroundings.

If you‚Äôre in Kyoto during the illumination season, this is an absolute must-see. It turns an already beautiful temple into a completely unforgettable evening experience.

We went to visit the temple in the afternoon (at around 6pm) and we loved that there were not too many people. The place (and the park) is really nice. It was especially nice with all the autumn colors and lightning that makes the colors even more beautiful.

We also saw one of the lightning shows that the Kyoto city prepares at different temples. It was okay but it was nothing to special. But the place itself is really nice.

A lovely temple with several buildings over a spacious garden. It‚Äôs very popular with many tourists: I saw three buses in the parking lot, but it‚Äôs spacious enough that it didn‚Äôt feel crowded. It‚Äôs on a slight hill so you can go up stairs and paths up into slight wooded areas. There is a small bamboo thicket that you can pass through to get the feeling of a bamboo forest. One of the buildings requires removing your shoes to explore. There is another building where you can sit & take some tea for an extra fee. I explored this place alone, and enjoyed it a lot. It was verdant and the air was refreshing. This is one of those destinations where people take photos in their rented kimono outfits, which seemed odd to me. As a western female redhead it would never occur to me to do that but there were lots who did. There are several rental shops nearby. I took a city bus to get to the temple which was easy and inexpensive.

name: Yakiniku Koko Kara
reviews: Came here late at night around 10PM for some Japanese BBQ! Staff were super nice and welcoming and even handed us an English menu since our Japanese was very minimal. Food was fantastic usually we‚Äôre used to cooking the meat ourselves but the staff ended up cooking and cutting for us(we think cause we ordered a thick cut of meat). Prices was great for the atmosphere. Lots of local and we can tell the place was authentic. Would recommend reserving first! Great restaurant, great staff!

Came here at late 7pm but was told to return at 8.45pm for a table. Hung out nearby for a drink before returning.
It is a cosy space and certainly has its own vibes.

Ordered the 5 kinds wagyu assortment, tongue cuts platter and a cold noodle (akin to a Korean naengmyeon).
Meat was great, fresh and tender. Noodle was fine (came for the meat not noodle).

No complaints about service, but just sharing some points:
Didn‚Äôt realise they had an English menu until after we ordered - managed to cope with ordering but obviously challenged by language. You will also have to cook the meat yourself.

Vibes was great, obviously catering to the after work crowd from offices nearby.

Would come back again for the meat and drinks.

My party of 4 was looking for somewhere to eat after a long day. We were able to make reservations here and were quickly escorted to our table. The staff, especially Thet, did a great job of giving us advice on what to order and providing recommendations! We especially loved the skirt steak and the beef short ribs! The side dishes were delicious also - we got the bean sprout salad and assorted kimchi. They helped us cook the meats so they were perfect and cleaned the grill regularly. The staff was so nice and the vibes were great! Price was very reasonable for the great quality of meat - will definitely be back the next time I‚Äôm in Tokyo!
Went for dinner, had a little trouble find it this gem, Was offered an english menu upon arrival, service was awesome, food was amazing! Will be back! Thank you for the kind service!

The meat here just tastes so good. We got mainly from the set with a few a la carte. The set price itself is quite affordable and the portions are okay. There is a variety of meat offered.

There‚Äôs an English menu, just have to ask for it, and the staff are quite proficient in English too. Also super helpful in guiding you on whether you over-ordered or if you‚Äôd be good to get more.
address: Japan, „Äí103-0028 Tokyo, Chuo City, Yaesu, 1-ch≈çme‚àí4‚àíÔºï Ê¢ÖÊæ§„Éì„É´ 1ÔΩû3F

name: Yakiniku MARUTOMI
reviews: We are a couple and had lunch there. A vegetarian dish that included self-preparation of fresh yuba by heating soy milk. And another meat dish that was made on the stove with a heating candle. Both dishes came with a selection of dishes and small side dishes. It was an excellent meal in a pleasant atmosphere

A wonderful restaurant , they have plans ( menus ) you can chose from. The meat was very very good quality , great customer service. We‚Äôll be back for sure.
Great vine and beers and reasonable prices.

Best dinner in Kyoto
We ate the freshest and best meat, the price was reasonable and fair, we will come back for sure! The stuff is very nice and they spake perfectly English. We also ordered good wine from Georgia and we highly recommend.

This restaurant is located on the 8th Floor of the Kyoto Kawaramachi Garden. Directly next to the elevator.

The food was very good. The service was fast and friendly. The interior is good-looking and clean. There was nice jazz music playing.

The prices are very fair. We took the lunch menu A, which is very well worth what you get for it.

I can very much recommend this place!

Food was fantastic! My husband ate some delicious wagyu steaks, we had rice and as a vegetarian option for me also delicious grilled vegetables with spicy sauces and salad. The staff were very friendly and helpful. ‚ù§Ô∏èü§ó Thank you very much for the experience!

Edit: I forgot to make photos. Unfortunately, I just have these low quality screenshots from a video that we can't post here.
address: Japan, „Äí600-8001 Kyoto, Shimogyo Ward, Shinch≈ç, ÔºñÔºò ‰∫¨ÈÉΩÊ≤≥ÂéüÁî∫„Ç¨„Éº„Éá„É≥ 8F

name: Futo Coast
reviews: Great rocky beach with swimming, snorkelling, scuba, fishing, SUP. Plenty of parking. Nice cafe. Quite busy in summer even though the access appears deserted. It's not privatized like some beaches around Izu. There's south and west facing areas for more options when the wind is up. My wife loved the snorkelling and saw lots of fish.

Beautiful area
Beach is rough.
Need to have water shoes
Bring snorkeling gear
There is a scenic trail 1.5km that goes from Futo to Tago
2 stone beaches are connected and the water is astonishingly clear & blue. Waves make a calming sound.
just beautiful ...but weather is too hot for us to scroll around, else it will be just fantastic.

This place was excellent for a roadside stop. There was free parking before 10:00. I found that the southern portion was less occupied and a lot of fun to snorkel. There are lots of caves to explore. Lots of tropical fish that can be seen by snorkelers or divers. There is fresh water to wash your body and equipment off before leaving.
address: Futo Coast, 2217 Nishina, Nishiizu, Kamo District, Shizuoka 410-3514, Japan

name: Tagosehama Beach
reviews:
Beautiful beach with a clear water and a lot of colorful fish
Great for snorkeling and diving
Or just swimming
Family friendly
In offseason is a lot of free parking lots just near the beach
Quite place with beautiful nature
Super nice little hidden beach. We came late september mid-week, it was empty and perfect weather
Nice hidden beach. Can enjoy snorkling and kayaking. Need car to reach here. Shower and rental shop available. We enjoyed the place.
Need ticket to enter. Small rock beach. Crowded. Shower available. Perfect water for diving and rich fish variety
Love this place!
address: Tago, Nishiizu, Kamo District, Shizuoka 410-3515, Japan

name: Kujuppama Beach
reviews: This place was by far the most beautiful in the area. I should choose this beach to visit in the first place cause it has a such nice ocean view. It also has structure for long stay, like shower and toilets. I highly recommend it!
Beautiful beach, easy to access from the near parking area (just a little bit step coming back). It was beautiful to stay here also if it was a windy chill day.

Worth a visit if you are in Shimoda. Was here end of September during the week, took a small rental E-Bike at the shop across the main station and rode all the way here. On the right side it's nice for snorkeling near the rocks. Small waves, good for children. Bring drinks and snacks.

Nice small beach! If you go early will be almost empty.
The sand in the back is a bit ugly.
Walk from the parking is about 8min, there is like 2 ways, get the one close to the parking so you can have some shadow on the way.
Also good for snorkeling, we saw a few fish.

Great for snorkelling. Some of the coolest fish we've seen on the north end of the beach. Quite dense. It's a quiet Sandy beach as well. The showers in the car park are all out of order and the toilets are a bit manky, so getting changed was a problem. Also it's a steep 200m walk/stairs from the car park to the beach.
address: Kujuppama Beach, Suzaki, Shimoda, Shizuoka 415-0014, Japan

name: Hirizo Beach
reviews:
Probably the best spot for snorkeling around Kanto area. However, you need to get to the port really early like 5am to get a parking lot and put your stuff to secure your spot in a line for a boat.
Also, there will be so many people in a small area. A sand area is very limited. Other space is stones and rocks. You must take your chairs and/or air mat.
Japanese people like to stay in tents so they‚Äôll block your view.

Superb...
Excellent snorkling site outside Okinawa.
During peak season this tiny beach will be horrible crowded but at the end of season (September) this tiny beach almost like private beach.
Rocky beach has Crystal visibility, plenty various of coral fishes.
Marine boot is mandatory, except rock and other sharp objects the beach also has many poisonous Stone fish.
Absolutely recommend

The snorkeling area is nice as it's an enclosed area surrounded mostly by rocks. You need to get quite a bit out to be deep enough to swim. You will definitely need some shoes for the water as there's sea urchins and sharp rocks that I would not suggest walking barefoot on. Once you're further out though, the water and marine life is really nice.

Biggest negative is how crowded it is and having to arrive super early in the morning for parking. Most cars started waiting as early as 3am to get a parking spot. Then there's a lot of waiting until the boats start running at 8am with a huge queue of people waiting to board it. After arriving at the beach, everyone sets up their massive tents so it's a bit of a pain to walk and get around the rocks.

Hirizo beach is a very nice ‚Äúbeach‚Äù, just made out of only rocks everywhere, very small and so easily crowded. The view is very nice and snorkeling activity is ok, but too many staffs yelling at you not to swim here or there . Include also 2000¬• boat trip for one person and 2 min transportation to the beach.

That's incredible that you can find such a tropical place so relatively close to Tokyo. Arrived at Nakagi Port you can purchase for 1500 yen (as of 2018) a return transfer ticket, and boats are linking the bay every 5 minutes. However, beware the crowd of midsummer weekends. If possible go a little off season (like in mid September) and on a weekday.
address: Hirizo Beach, Nakagi, Âçó‰ºäË±ÜÁî∫ Minamiizu, Kamo District, Shizuoka 415-0311, Japan

name: Lovers' Point
reviews: Absolutely phenomenal view of mount fuji via the sea, and views of the coast all around you. However, check the weather as its not a good idea to come when its cloudy or rainy due to limited visibility. Be prepared to walk 10 minutes on quite steep concrete. Nice walk however.
Great views of the bay and Mount Fuji. We walked from Yagisawa - well worth the hike. We also stopped in the cafe for ice creams.

It was the perfect destination to take a couple. Although the place is called ‚ÄúLover‚Äôs Cape,‚Äù it‚Äôs a wonderful spot for anyone to enjoy. A short 10-minute walk through lush greenery from the parking area leads to a high vantage point overlooking the sea. The area is rich in nature, with the constant song of bush warblers, and the ocean was beautiful.
Beautiful view, and when lucky you can even see Fuji San. Difficult to manage the steps for older or handicapped people

Views at the tip of the cape are extremely beautiful but be prepared to walk up and down slopes and climb stairs to the observation deck. Overall perfect place to soak into the seaside view! Unfortunately, I was not able to see a clear of mt Fuji again.

name: Shuzenji Temple
reviews: Nice little town. Lots of parking. Public foot bath was enjoyable. Good picture opportunity towards sunset.
Nice little old temple, decorated with red maple trees were pretty picturesque!

Very nice temple in a cute little town. You can spend a few hours here (temple and streets around it). There's a small museum in the temple that cost 300 yen to enter. It had some nice old masks so I think it was worth it.
This temple and whole town around it is really adorable. We tried some wasabi ice cream, and the hop&cold spring
Quiet and beautiful temple, good to walk around the street, riverside and the bamboo forest path.

name: Kawazu Seven Waterfalls
reviews:
Visiting Kawazu Nanadaru (Kawazu Seven Waterfalls) was honestly one of the most refreshing experiences I‚Äôve had in Japan. The moment I entered the trail, I felt surrounded by pure nature ‚Äî the sound of water, the smell of the forest, and the cool air instantly relaxed me.

The walking path is beautiful and easy to follow. Each waterfall has its own charm, so every few minutes you get a new surprise. Some of them are small and cute, and others are powerful with water crashing down into a clear blue pool. I loved how peaceful the whole area felt ‚Äî not too crowded, just the sound of nature.

My favorite part was how the trail becomes more and more scenic as you go deeper. The bridges, the stone steps, and the greenery everywhere make the walk feel almost like a little adventure. I stopped many times just to take photos because the waterfalls look different from each angle.

The air around the falls is so clean and cool, especially near the bigger waterfall where you can feel the mist on your face. It made me feel awake and refreshed. It‚Äôs also a great place if you want to take your time, walk slowly, and enjoy nature without rushing.

There are small caf√©s and shops near the starting point, and the atmosphere feels local and warm. The whole area has this calm countryside vibe that makes you want to stay longer.

Overall, Kawazu Seven Waterfalls is a perfect choice if you want a peaceful and beautiful nature escape. The trails, the scenery, and the waterfalls all come together to create a really memorable experience. I would definitely visit again, maybe in another season, because I‚Äôm sure it looks different and beautiful every time.

Kawazu Seven Waterfalls is for those who are nature lovers.  It‚Äôs quiet and serene.  We went early morning during the week and the forest was ours.  Take your time and enjoy the solitude.
Mostly paved paths with handrails and proper signage around, lots of photo ops, bathrooms and a stamps station along the walking trail near each waterfalls and even a spot for an honour system plants for sale. The wish-making rock toss into a basket was challenging and fun‚Ä¶I missed but still got my wish as I was already in Japan.
Wear proper clothing and shoes with good soles as some areas can be slippery.  You need at least a couple of hours to do the full hike.

Beautiful area perfect for families. The path is paved and easily walkable. The path does have steps that go down to each waterfall so not suitable for strollers but having baby in carrier is great.

Staying at the Nanadaru Onsen Hotel also gives you access to the cave Onsen near the main waterfall.

The air is fresh, walkway is clean, and waterfalls are beautiful. Definitely worth a visit if you‚Äôre nearby.

Its very beautiful and serene but its quite a treck.

Lovely views overall and quite a nice shift from the busy citylife.

The village where the waterfalls are is also quite cozy with a very friendly shop and an amazing udon/soba restaurant serving cheap and amazingly delicious food.

If you have physical limitations or similar it could be dificult to treck through but its very beautiful for those who apreciate nature.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è
Absolutely breathtaking!
Kawazu Seven Waterfalls is one of the most beautiful and peaceful spots in Izu. The trail is easy to walk and perfectly maintained, winding through lush forest and crystal-clear streams. Each of the seven waterfalls has its own charm ‚Äî from small cascades hidden among mossy rocks to the majestic final fall that feels straight out of a movie.

The sound of rushing water, birds singing, and the fresh mountain air make it such a relaxing experience. Along the way, there are lovely caf√©s and small onsen inns where you can stop and enjoy a break with coffee or soft-serve ice cream.

It‚Äôs also a great place to visit year-round ‚Äî vibrant green in summer, fiery red leaves in autumn, and tranquil beauty in winter. If you‚Äôre in Izu, this is a must-see destination. Highly recommended for nature lovers, photographers, and anyone looking to unwind in Japan‚Äôs natural beauty. üåøüíß
address: Nashimoto, Kawazu, Kamo District, Shizuoka 413-0501, Japan

name: Shirahama Shrine
reviews: Beautiful, mesmerizing Shinto shrine. Tori gates. Peaceful place. Many people were there for new year blessings.

Neat shrine with a seaside Torii gate and a shrine a short climb up some steps to a bluff. You can pray and collect a pre-prepared Goshuin. Parking next door is expensive but you can sneak into the local combini car park for free.
The weather wasn‚Äôt great, it was a rainy day, but I visited the oldest shrine in Izu. It was very quiet and peaceful.

I went during the weekday so not much people were there. (And during the hot days lol)
So we got some amazing pictures and were able to take our time to check out the shrine (make sure to visit the seaside torii towards the beach)
To get to the torii there‚Äôs a path on the right as you‚Äôre heading towards the main shrine. (Hopefully that makes sense)

Beautiful to see but somehow underwhelming! It seems smaller in person ü•≤ It was still gorgeous and worth seeing. The weather was kind of bad so maybe it would have been more impressive with the sun shining down.

name: Shirahama beach
reviews: Very beautiful white sand beach that was not crowded. You can rent sunbeds and a parasol for the day for a reasonable price. Beach security and a few locals ladies were going around keeping the beach clean. There is a 7/11 just across the street, offering ice cold drinks, snacks and beach necessities. All in all a very relaxing experience.

AWESOME beach. Be careful with the sun though, it‚Äôs easy to get completely fried here with no shade. Plan your trip accordingly as there is limited bus runs throughout the day. If you need drinks or anything else, there is a 7/11 right across from the bus stop.

Beautiful beach. I guess I like it because I will never ever set my foot there in season! Love walking along the shore in October - November when sand barriers has been set up. Parking is a bit of a drag though.

Shirahama Beach ‚Äî just wow!
White soft sand, crystal clear turquoise water and gorgeous views. The beach is well maintained, has everything you need. The atmosphere is calm, especially in the morning. A bit crowded in season, but still one of the best places to relax by the sea in Japan. Highly recommended! üåä‚òÄÔ∏è

Tattoo Friendly!  We saw so many people with them and no one minds.

Its an amazing beach! Great quality sand and parking is on the beach.
A side note about parking, they close the lots at 1600. We tried to find 24hr parking but had no luck. So try searching before you arrive!
address: Shirahama beach, Shirahama, Shimoda, Shizuoka 415-0012, Japan

name: Mt. Omuro
reviews:
I came at 11 a.m. on August 15, 2025. I had to wait in line for about 1.5 hours for the chairlift, and it was incredibly hot with strong sun. Be sure to prepare for the long wait by bringing a hat, water, and a UV protection umbrella.

Once you're up there, the weather is clear, and the mountain is beautiful. The walk around the mountains takes about 20 to 30 minutes

enjoyable hike around crater rim of dead volcano
with good view of mountain Fuji
Archery at the base of the crater was funny
Nice tourist spot, a fun little chair lift and , you can see the mt. fuji and the lovely ocean on a good day. Restaurant there are also lovely and delicious.
You can see a crater that inspired a famous scene in Your Name. On clear days, Mt Fuji is viewable.

It was beautiful even though we visited at the beginning of summer on a windy day. The chair lift costs 1,000 yen round trip, be sure to check the official website beforehand in case it‚Äôs not operating due to wind or other conditions. If you‚Äôre taking the bus, keep in mind that the last one doesn‚Äôt run late, so plan accordingly.
address: Mt. Omuro, Ike, It≈ç, Shizuoka 413-0234, Japan

name: Kadowaki Suspension Bridge
reviews: Let me start by discussing the parking lot. If you are there for a quick stop of less than five minutes, it‚Äôs free. However, over 5 minutes it costs 500 yen and that‚Äôs the max cost for the entire day. There are other spots nearby besides the bridge and lighthouse. As for the lighthouse and local souvenir shop, it closes at 04:30 pm. The bridge itself boasts some of the best views of peninsula. Absolutely stunning! Found and spoke to a couple of local fishermen who go here everyday. Some areas require a little more athleticism to climb, but the man trails are easy.

Safe and easy to get to. Better to enjoy the coastal walk rather than driving straight there, if you have time. This is a popular attraction so you may need to wait at times as people take photos. The water here is very clear.
It's a cool bridge but the great thing about it is that it's in such a  beautiful spot.  The views along the coast are awesome.  And the hike to it is not difficult and only took about 20 minutes.
A must come by if you love nature, it is relaxing and amazing to see the rock formations here. Free admission and only pay for car park.

10 minute walk from ito station, the bridge held a fun river race. Family oriented activity with refreshing water dips once the boat flipped over. Ito is calm and clean. The orange beach was refreshing too.

name: Jogasaki Coast
reviews: If you‚Äôre in a rental car and not familiar with Japanese driving, you want to be careful because getting to the New York map Museum and Garden or JogaSaki Coast can be tricky. The roads of residential sections are hard to follow on Google maps and the roads are narrow. So check the map and use the biggest roads. Walking between the New York that museum and the lighthouse is very beautiful. I would say in July in August it‚Äôs going to be very hot so you should have water to drink and go early or later when it‚Äôs a little bit cooler. If you are not used to actual hiking, you should choose wisely. There are two parallel trails for most of the hike. The trail closer to the coast/water is up and down, steep, with step lots of steps and more rocks. The shorter, easier trail is fairly level with only a few places that are rocky or muddy. You have to watch your footing you should have shoes made for walking or hiking and if you‚Äôre elderly and have knee problems, hip problems, balance problems you might not want to risk either trail. The easier trail further from the water is only about 1 km or 6/10 of a mile so if you‚Äôre in recently good shape, you can consider taking it. You can drive from one spot to the other and just pay for parking.  The New York lamp museum area has ice cream and other treats and some light food and good bathrooms and a cafe. Both the lamps and the flowers are well worth the price of admission. On weekends and holidays and most of the summer, Both areas are quite crowded. Well worth a visit though. If you walk from the station, especially in warmer weather, you should get something to drink to hydrate along the way.

Fabulous scenery and a wonderful place to spend an hour or three. Parking is fixed at 500 yen and goes to preserve the site. Be careful around the rocks, at the lighthouse there are unprotected areas, keep an eye on your kids. Well worth the visit! Winds here can be brutal...

This place was gorgeous.
From the train station it was about 30-35 minute walk to the start point of the hike. The hike wasn‚Äôt too bad, it was short and easy. Probably like 20-25 minutes to the bridge. Depending on how fast you walk. But overall it was beautiful and would definitely go back.

We couldn‚Äôt go up Mount Omuro due to strong winds so it was great that we could view it from afar from the lighthouse. Lovely coastal views with no crowd. Do stop by when in the area especially if driving.

Absolutely beautiful views! The drive up wasn‚Äôt bad at all‚Äîthough it did get a little crowded in some areas. That said, there are plenty of spots where you can venture off and enjoy the scenery without so many people around.

name: S≈çunzan Station
reviews:
S≈çunzan Station is a calm and efficient transition point between the Hakone Tozan Cable Car and the Ropeway, and it feels like a natural pause before the scenery becomes more dramatic. The station is clean, compact, and easy to navigate, with staff guiding visitors smoothly between platforms. Even during steady foot traffic, the atmosphere stays relaxed, and the surrounding mountain air gives the place a refreshing feel.

While it‚Äôs not a major attraction on its own, S≈çunzan Station works well as a starting or ending point for exploring the higher elevations of Hakone. The views from the outdoor areas are surprisingly nice, especially on clear days, and the layout makes transfers quick. It earns a 4 out of 5 for convenience, cleanliness, and the gentle mountain ambiance.

We were at this station after taking the funicular train from Gora Station. We got on board the cable car which goes up to the Hakone area. The view is scenic and we could see the volcano with sulphur mines from the cable car.
Nice station and the end of the ropeway. You can have free foot-bath in hot water here. The view is beautiful. Can take the cable car down to Gora station.

Better station to start off with with free parking. Limited parking so come early or later. If u go to Kuwadani station, there will be jam going to carpark as it‚Äôs the main geothermal attraction and u will be stuck if u didn‚Äôt check google maps
Awesome cable car that gets you from one side of the mountain to the other. Beautiful views all around, definitely recommend it if you're in town.
address: Gora, Hakone, Ashigarashimo District, Kanagawa 250-0408, Japan

name: Owakudani Information Center
reviews:
The ≈åwakudani Information Center is a compact but helpful stop for anyone wanting context behind the volcanic activity. It offers simple displays explaining the geology, the history of eruptions, and why the valley produces its famous black eggs. The space is easy to walk through, and there‚Äôs no pressure to spend long ‚Äî it‚Äôs more of a quick educational boost than a full museum. On a weekday, there was no wait at all, making it an effortless addition to the visit.

What stands out is how the center adds meaning to what you see outside. After reading the explanations, the steam vents and sulfur clouds feel less like scenery and more like a living geological process. It‚Äôs not flashy, but it‚Äôs informative and grounding. For travelers who appreciate understanding the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind a place, it‚Äôs a worthwhile stop. I‚Äôd rate it 4 out of 5 for clarity, accessibility, and enhancing the overall experience.

We reached Owakudani from Hakone-Yumoto Station using a combination of train, cable car, and ropeway. The ropeway was especially exciting for me, as we could see Mt. Fuji partially covered by clouds but still visible. From Owakudani Station, the main volcanic area is about a 10-minute walk. One of the highlights was trying the famous black eggs, which are hard-boiled in the volcanically heated waters. Their shells turn black due to a chemical reaction with the hot spring minerals, and legend says eating one adds seven years to your life. Although the shells look unusual, the inside is just a normal boiled egg. We didn‚Äôt see them being cooked, but they‚Äôre sold ready-made nearby. As expected, they tasted just like regular eggs‚Äîonly with a much more memorable appearance.
Owakudani was formed by a volcanic eruption over 3,000 years ago, and it‚Äôs basically a dramatic valley full of steam vents and hot springs. It‚Äôs one of the most popular spots in Hakone because of its unique, almost otherworldly scenery‚Äîand if the weather‚Äôs good, you can even see Mt. Fuji peeking through. Just a heads-up: sometimes the area closes because of volcanic gases, so it‚Äôs worth checking before you go.

The site is huge, and the view is stunning!
There‚Äôs also a really cheap museum you can visit for 100 yen.
The ropeway is a bit expensive, and the wait can be long depending on the time of day‚Äîbe prepared to wait.
Beware of traffic jams on the way up the mountain!

We had an excellent experience at Owakudani. The landscape is incredible‚Äîsulfur vents steaming all around, the smell of the volcano in the air, and if you‚Äôre lucky with clear weather, amazing Mt. Fuji views. The highlight was trying the famous black eggs‚Äîwarm, tasty, and fun to share (plus the local legend of adding seven years to your life makes it even better). Shops and facilities were clean, staff were kind, and everything felt organized. Truly a unique stop in Hakone.

Pro tips:
‚Ä¢	Weekdays are calmer ‚Üí much less crowded and easier to enjoy the views.
‚Ä¢	Check the weather ‚Üí Mt. Fuji is visible only on clear days; worth planning around.
‚Ä¢	Black eggs ‚Üí sold in 5-packs, perfect for sharing with family/friends.
‚Ä¢	Bring a jacket ‚Üí it‚Äôs cooler and windy up here compared to Hakone town.
‚Ä¢	Ropeway check ‚Üí sometimes it closes due to volcanic gases or strong winds, so confirm before heading up.

Top views here! We headed straight to look at the sulphur fields and had stunning views over the whole area. Then down to the parking lot, where you get the best and unobstructed views from Mt. Fuji if the weather is your friend. A nice gimmick are the black eggs cooked in the sulphur springs, which are said to prolong your life.
address: 1251 Sengokuhara, Hakone, Ashigarashimo District, Kanagawa 250-0631, Japan

name: Hakone Checkpoint
reviews:
The Hakone Checkpoint (ÁÆ±Ê†πÈñ¢ÊâÄ, Hakone Sekisho) is a historic site located in Hakone, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. It was once an important checkpoint during the Edo period (1603‚Äì1868) and was part of the Tokugawa shogunate‚Äôs system of control to monitor and regulate travelers, particularly to prevent the movement of women from the shogun‚Äôs family and samurai. Here‚Äôs a review of the site:

Overview and Historical Significance
‚Ä¢	The Hakone Checkpoint was established in 1619 on the T≈çkaid≈ç, the most important route connecting Edo (modern-day Tokyo) with Kyoto, the capital at the time. It was a key part of the Shogun‚Äôs network of checkpoints designed to maintain control over the samurai class and prevent rebellion. The checkpoint specifically controlled the passage of people, goods, and information across the mountain pass.
‚Ä¢	The site features a replica of the original checkpoint station, and visitors can learn about the role it played in the Edo period‚Äôs transportation and governance. The original building was destroyed over time, but a reconstruction offers an immersive experience of what it would have looked like.

Visitor Experience
1.	Historical Exhibits: The site includes informative displays about life at the checkpoint, the role of guards, and the travel restrictions enforced during the Edo period. There are also costumes available for visitors to try on, which can make for a fun and interactive experience.
2.	Reconstructed Checkpoint Building: The main attraction is the reconstructed checkpoint building, which looks quite authentic and offers a glimpse into the past. The building itself is not just a structure but a historical interpretation, so visitors can feel the weight of its historical importance.
3.	Scenic Location: Situated in the beautiful Hakone area, the checkpoint is surrounded by lush greenery and is just a short distance from other notable attractions like the Hakone Shrine and the Hakone Open-Air Museum. The natural beauty of the area adds to the overall experience, especially if you‚Äôre visiting on a sunny day.
4.	Access to Local History: The museum within the checkpoint also highlights various aspects of life during the Edo period, including tools, weapons, and documents related to the functioning of the checkpoint. This is especially valuable for history enthusiasts who want to understand how the Tokugawa shogunate governed its territories.

Pros:
‚Ä¢	Educational: The site provides valuable insight into the Edo period and the strategic importance of transportation and communication during that time.
‚Ä¢	Interactive: The option to dress in period clothing and see the original and replica items up close makes it a very engaging experience for those interested in history.
‚Ä¢	Scenic: The beautiful location in Hakone provides a peaceful, historic atmosphere with stunning views of the surrounding nature.

Cons:
‚Ä¢	Small Site: While the checkpoint is historically significant, the actual site is relatively small, so it may not take up too much time if you‚Äôre looking for a longer visit.
‚Ä¢	Limited in Scope: It‚Äôs focused mainly on the checkpoint‚Äôs role, which might not be enough for those looking for a broader view of Japan‚Äôs history or a deeper exploration of Hakone itself.

Best Time to Visit
‚Ä¢	Autumn: The fall colors around Hakone are stunning, and the natural scenery around the checkpoint is even more impressive.
