‚Ä¢	Spring: Cherry blossoms in the area are also breathtaking, and Hakone is less crowded compared to other spots during the peak tourist season.

Overall Impression

The Hakone Checkpoint is a fascinating and well-maintained historical site. It offers a great opportunity to dive into a crucial piece of Japan‚Äôs Edo period history while enjoying the beauty of Hakone‚Äôs nature. If you‚Äôre a history buff or just someone who appreciates the traditional aspects of Japanese culture, it‚Äôs definitely worth a stop. However, if you‚Äôre short on time or not as interested in historical checkpoints, it might be worth combining the visit with nearby attractions to make the most of your time in Hakone.

A fascinating glimpse into Japan‚Äôs history!
Hakone Checkpoint is a well-preserved historical site that gives you insight into the Edo period‚Äôs travel and security system. The museum and reconstructed buildings are informative and engaging, with displays that bring history to life. The location by Lake Ashi offers beautiful views, making it both educational and scenic. Perfect for history enthusiasts, families, or anyone exploring Hakone‚Äôs cultural attractions!

A well organized historical fortress to secure this district. You can see lots of heritage stuffs and designated layout and artwork here. Good to take a look at this place after having the pirate boat cruising. Enjoy.

Visited Hakone Checkpoint and really enjoyed stepping back in time! The reconstructed gates and guardhouses are super well done, and the small museum has lots of interesting historical details. The lookout point offers amazing views of Lake Ashi and the surrounding mountains. Easy to walk around and the staff are friendly. A great stop if you‚Äôre exploring Hakone‚Äîhistory buffs and casual visitors alike will enjoy it!

Its important as tourist area before and still famous among locals and foreign tourist till now. Good place for photos, having meals, and shop some local souvenirs. Suitable for any group size or FIT since its open area for everyone to come and enjoy.  Promised amazing panoramic view ...Worth visit

name: BOX BURGER ÁÆ±Ê†πÊπØÊú¨Â∫ó‚Ä¶
reviews:
The restaurant is located in a quiet corner of a residential area. You can literally smell the burgers as you approach the restaurant.
Service was impeccable even though they were busy and almost full when we arrived. They were cheerful and attended to our requests promptly.
We sat in a tatami room where there were 3 tables. The 2 other groups ahead of us were waiting for their food.
We had a Box Burger each, plus fries (separate order), and beef tendon stew which was a special of the day.
Let me start off with the beef tendon stew - it was simply delicious with a well balanced taste; like a comfort food. One of the best beef tendon stews we have eaten anywhere.
Now for the burger - we would have liked it more if it was a little less salty and also if there were less lettuce in it. I do like vegetables, but found the large amount of lettuce and salt masked the taste and flavour of the wagyu beef patty. The fries were good.
Overall a pretty good and filling meal.
We noticed that almost all the customers were foreigners. Unlike some Japanese restaurants which accepts cash only,  Box Burger does not accept cash....and indication that they cater mainly to foreigners.

5 Word Review: DONT KEEP SEARCHING JUST GO

You ever lose a pick for a restaurant only so the other person could pick the one thing you really did not want to eat? That was me but boy was I glad I lost that pick! I walked to Box burger having ZERO desire to eat a burger and by the time I walked in I couldn't wait to sink my teeth into one!

Box burger is a quaint but very beautiful restaurant that offers both traditional tatami seating as well as table and chairs (we opted for the former). Like almost every restaurant we went to the service was excellent, the restaurant was immaculate and the food was fresh and delicious.

We had the bacon and egg burger and the box burger along with an order of fries and onion rings. I also had the housemade lemon squash (soda). The fries and onion rings were some of the best I have had. Incredibly tasty and clearly made in house. The burgers were juicy and flavorful with just the right toppings and sauces. Overall this was one of the best burgers I have had anywhere.... made with local beef that supposedly has been raised drinking Onsen water.

The only tragedy is we didn't go twice before departing for the states.

Overall I highly recommend this burger spot and if I ever go back to Hakone will be going back myself!

Box Burger is a gorgeous and tiny burger joint in a traditional Japanese setting. There are two small dining rooms - one with about six chairs at bench tables and one tatami style room that seats about ten people on the floor. The burgers are high quality as are the fries, shakes and extras. The staff are fun and friendly. This is a burger experience worth having!

Super friendly owner who can speak English. Onions rings were apparently the best my husband has ever eaten (I don‚Äôt eat them myself, but noted everyone else ordered & devoured them!). Great selection of burgers with local produce and beers from surrounding area. Highly recommend. Also cater to both vegetarian and vegans, which isn‚Äôt terribly common in Japan.

What a lovely place! This was one of the best burgers I've had in my life (and definitely the best gluten-free one). The rice bun was quite soft and the burger extremely juicy. The staff is very sweet and you get to eat in a Japanese style room. Such a great experience!
address: 474-37 Yumoto, Hakone, Ashigarashimo District, Kanagawa 250-0311, Japan

name: Ginza Hachigou
reviews:
I was the first alone in line when I came around 8am. A couple came around 8:40am‚Ä¶by around 9am a few more people came. By 9:30am, you are risking not getting a chance of getting in. You can also try to rsvp online but that‚Äôs only open on Saturday at 9am for the following week.
The patron came out around 9:45am to ask us to order and pay, then go back waiting in line until actual opening time. It‚Äôs suppose to open at 11am but they let us in around 10:20am‚Ä¶
Highly recommend you to have all your parties in line bcus if not, you will be asked to go in the back of line when the order/payment is done before restaurant opens.
Yes the wait was brutal, but the food really made up for it. Honestly one of the best ramen I ever had. The highlight was definitely the foie gras dumpling.

I‚Äôm so happy we were able to get a reservation at Ginza Hachigou during our time in Tokyo. I had tried before we departed for our trip and the website crashed but was lucky enough to sneak us in for the second week we were there. Be prepared to move fast when you‚Äôre booking, it is seriously in high demand!

We got the last spot at 3:30 on a Friday, unfortunately they were out of the famous ravioli but it honestly didn‚Äôt matter. Hands down the best ramen I will ever have in my life. It‚Äôs such an enjoyable experience watching the chefs prepare it fresh right in front of you. It‚Äôs an intimate 6 person seating, so you can really just sit back and enjoy a master at work in a peaceful setting.

As I said the ramen itself is incredible, flavorful broth, delicious pork, and perfectly cooked noodles. I would eat 2 bowls if I had the option. We also got a side of their pork rice with horseradish and onion, and it was fantastic. Cannot recommend this place enough as a stop during your time in Tokyo, this was a highlight of our trip and I‚Äôm so glad we finished here on a high note.

After trying for three years, I finally managed to secure a reservation at Ginza Hachigou, and it was well worth the wait.

The restaurant offers an intimate dining experience with only six seats, where the chefs prepare and cook directly in front of you. This creates a warm and engaging atmosphere that perfectly complements the attention to detail in every aspect of the meal.

The ramen broth was exceptional, rich, balanced, and deeply flavoursome, offering warmth and comfort with every bite. The use of a ravioli within the dish was truly unique and added a refined depth that elevated the overall experience.

I would highly recommend.

Honestly the most incredible ramen experience in all of Japan!

If you only have one bowl of ramen in Japan, have this ramen.

I ate over 30 bowls of ramen in my 9 week trip to Japan and this simply triumphs them all - it really is the best.

I visited twice!

Let‚Äôs start with the broth - French technique clear duck consum√©, light dashi/kombu with a depth of relentless umami. Light, powerful and perfectly balanced. What would you expect from a place that previously held a Michelin Star?

Broth is not too oily, but has just the right amount of fat, presumably chicken fat, that it coats your mouth in the best warming and inviting way possible.

The noodles are cooked to absolute perfection - literally perfection to the very last second!

Straight thin noodles complement the broth well, and it surprised me as I have visited Asahikawa on this trip and thought that shoyu ramen should be paired with curly fat noodles, how wrong I was.

You see.. the broth is neither shoyu nor shio, but simply a heavenly creation from the master. It‚Äôs modern, innovative and ultra refined.

Now onto the toppings. The char siu is simply the best I‚Äôve ever had! Super thick cut at almost 1cm thick, you almost struggle to hold it in the chopsticks, easily the best I had in Japan. You can see in my photos the perfect ratio of fat to meat.

The menma (bamboo shoots) are approx. 1cm x 1cm and have the perfect crunch. Never experience such good menma in my life.

The negi (green onions) are mild but somehow perfume the bowl with such beauty. I‚Äôm sure the owner sources the negi from Kyoto or somewhere of incredibly high standards.

The egg is simply perfect, soft and gooey on the inside it is simply cooked to perfection.

The foie gras and truffle ravioli is‚Ä¶ how do I say this politely?‚Ä¶ simply orgasmic. Did someone say tumescent? Subtle yet powerful, like a true love scene.

The last second crack of black pepper over the char siu complements the well-known ‚Äúsalt and pepper‚Äù taste so well, and is so aromatic that it‚Äôs almost the first aroma that hits you when the bowl is presented in front of you.

The service is impeccable! I dined here twice during my two weeks in Tokyo and both times I could not fault a single thing. On the second time I even asked to swap seats with the guest next to me so I could have the same seat again, that threw the cooking a seating arrangement out, but all staff did not make a fuss and completely accompanied me - THANK YOU üôè

For the rice with char siu, negi (white part), horseradish and freshly cracked black pepper. My god was this good! The owner kindly advises to add some of the ramen broth at the end to create a wet rice bowl. My recommendation, be sure to order this too if you‚Äôre feeling hungry as it‚Äôs only an additional ¬•500.

Now that you have read all the way to here!

How to secure a seat?

Well.. bookings online only open at 9am on Saturday, Tokyo time. Understandably the website crashes and the bookings are filled within a couple of minutes.

There is walk-in seating between 11am - 12pm for each day they are open. My suggestion, get there before 9am to avoid disappointment. If there are more than 18 people in line, you will most likely be turned away.

The restaurant seats 6. My understanding is that sometimes they open around 10:40am which gives customers approximately 20-30 minutes of seating time. After 12pm it is reserved for online reservations only.

I hope this review assists you on your journey to the best bowl of ramen in Japan üòä

Ginza Hachigou, THANK YOU üôè

Ginza Hachigou is all about perfect harmony in a bowl. Every element blends together beautifully, creating balance without trying to be flashy. I really respect how the chef personally prepares everything with such care and precision. It‚Äôs not about showing off. It‚Äôs about consistency and mastery. When a place can maintain this level of quality every time, that‚Äôs true perfection.
address: Japan, „Äí104-0061 Tokyo, Chuo City, Ginza, 3-ch≈çme‚àí14‚àíÔºí Á¨¨‰∏Ä„ÅØ„Å™„Å∂„Åï„Éì„É´ 1Èöé

name: Jindaiji Temple
reviews:
We visited Jindaiji Temple for Hatsumode on a weekday, and were pleasantly surprised by how calm and uncrowded it felt. While many shrines and temples in Tokyo become overwhelmingly busy during the New Year period, Jindaiji offered a much more relaxed and local atmosphere.

The temple grounds are decently sized and easy to explore, surrounded by greenery that makes it feel far removed from the city despite being in Tokyo. There‚Äôs a strong neighborhood vibe here, with visitors strolling at an unhurried pace and families quietly paying their respects.

One of Jindaiji‚Äôs highlights is the area around the temple, which is famous for its soba shops. Many long-established restaurants serve handmade soba, making it a great place to enjoy a warm meal after your visit.

If you‚Äôre looking for a peaceful Hatsumode experience without the crowds, Jindaiji Temple is a wonderful choice. It combines tradition, food, and a welcoming local feel‚Äîperfect for starting the year on a calm and reflective note.

Lovely temple located in a quiet neighbourhood. There's a path you can walk which brings you to the Botanic Garden. The temple is not that big but there are many points of interests to check out, look at the map.

Don't miss out on the dango and soba (their specialty which you don't wanna miss).
One of my fave places in Japan. Second time here. The soba is seriously good and everyone is so nice. Tons of keepsakes and the vibe is just so peaceful. Spread my ashes here when am gone
Wonderful temple. It shows the old traditional side of Japan. It‚Äôs a hidden gem ! There are also good udon restaurants around the temple, but they close pretty early.

Such a beautiful and historically significant Temple. The grounds are so beautiful with the botanical garden being adjacent. There's also good food that is both delicious and affordable out around the area. There are free maps with historical information for those who are interested.

name: Ky≈çto Orgel-D≈ç Saga
reviews:
Accidentally went to this place instead of the other location I had booked in Arashiyama and it was a blessing in disguise!

Had a lovely time building my music box with my partner. You pick what you want and pay for it before you start making the box. They provide the instructions and resin glue. Enjoyed the no time limit or reservations needed and overall amazing experience!

Made in Japan music boxes.  We came across this place after touring the Kimono Forest.  The staff was very friendly. I purchased several music ornaments and boxes. Prices range from $18-$4500+ USD.  Isles are very narrow so be careful if you have a back pack on.  I will definitely come here again. They even had a section where you could personally decorate a music ornament with the supplies they had on hand.  If you like my review, please give it a thumbs up.
Beautiful shop, it's amazing even just to see. The carillons are all really pretty. It's almost like entering a fairy tail
Very nice store. Lots of made in Japan products. There is glass ware and a few accessories. Love the music boxes. Very relaxing.
Visited this music box shop when strolling around kimono forest in arashiyama. Handful collections of music box with unique design.
address: 30-35 Sagatenry≈´ji Tsukurimichich≈ç, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto, 616-8384, Japan

name: Edo Kiriko Asakusa Ojima
reviews: We have just spent a very interesting and fun morning learning about Edo Kiriko glass engraving with our excellent teacher Taichi (apologies if I have spelled the name incorrectly). After the overview of the history and techniques we designed our first piece. Best to keep it simple and base the design around circles to start but it‚Äôs up to you. At the end we were kindly given a  piece made by the professional - Recommended if you are near Asakusa. Short walk from Senso-Ji.
Someting new and interesting to do very fun and unique  !! Loved the experience
Beautiful and fun experience with my wife and two daughters . 8 and 11 year old very safe and fun experience
A chance the feel of being a glazier artist
They had many exquisite glasses, but not the thin-walled one I wanted. However, the owner was still very friendly and explained things to me in English. ü•∫

name: Yoroniku Ebisu
reviews:
Honestly, this was one of the best and most delicious dining experiences of my life.
The quality of the beef was exceptional ‚Äî incredibly tender, juicy, and full of flavor. It truly melted in my mouth, and every single bite was amazing.

The staff were also wonderful ‚Äî very attentive and provided excellent service throughout the entire meal.

I‚Äôm so happy and truly grateful to have had the chance to dine here. If you love great food and high-quality beef, this is a place you must visit at least once when you‚Äôre in Tokyo. I highly recommend making a reservation in advance.

I will definitely come back again when I have the chance.

This will probably be one of your pricier meals but there aren't many better ways to enjoy yakiniku than this place. We each ordered the same set meal which did include some raw beef but they did inform us ahead of time. The grilled meat is cooked by staff in front of you so you can't mess up your own dish and burn it. Each serving highlighted the differences between cuts. The flavors and textures of each item varied and the sauce perfectly augments select items. The shaved ice at the end of the night was a nice, light way of finishing the meal. Our seating time was limited to 2 hours as they have set seatings every night. Drink order is mandatory too.

Amazing wagyu experience. Every cut is served with care and grilled perfectly with staff guidance. The chateaubriand and shimofuri were unreal‚Äîmelts-in-your-mouth level. Service is warm, professional, and the pacing of the meal is excellent. Pricey, but absolutely worth it for one of the best yakiniku meals in Tokyo.

The meat quality is pretty insane. We got the truffle set and everything was good. However, the place was busy, and they tried to turn the tables quickly, so the whole experience felt a bit rushed. A reservation is definitely recommended, and you might need to make it even a month in advance. Their reservation online system opens on the first day of the previous month so you can reserve for the next month. With drinks, it was about 18000JPY per person. Overall, 8/10.

Food is alright.
Service is of average - some staff were serving two tables, while other staff were just standing there chatting with each other. Some staff looked like they didn‚Äôt even want to be there.
Restaurant is quite small in size and you can absolutely hear what people at the next table were talking about.

name: Sankeien Garden
reviews:
A Summer Escape to Sankeien Garden..
If you're looking for a peaceful break from the energy of Yokohama, you've to visit Sankeien Garden. I arrived arounf 11.30 qnd completely charmed by this place, especially in the summer (which a bit hot). It's not just a beautiful park; it's a collection of history, with a bunch of traditional buildings‚Äîold farmhouses, pagodas, even teahouses. I have walked through the paths felt like a journey back in time, with each new structure telling its own story against the backdrop of vibrant green.
The whole garden is designed so beautifully. The main pond is a big part of the experience, with the dense summer foliage creating perfect reflections on the water. I could have spent an hour just sitting there, watching the ducks and enjoying the quiet hum of cicadas. The paths wind around, leading you to hidden spots and incredible views. The lush, verdant trees create a natural shade that makes exploring even on a hot day incredibly pleasant.

A little tip: make sure you find your way up to the Choshukaku Pavilion. It‚Äôs a bit of a slope, but the view is absolutely worth it. It‚Äôs the perfect spot to sit and take a moment to soak it all in. The front staff were all so welcoming and the price is affordable üëçüèª

Beautiful garden, though one of the main houses was closed for a private event during our visit. Did quite a bit of walking within the garden but was well worth it. There‚Äôs a bus stop just outside the entrance so this made it very convenient to return to Yokohama station. Entrance fee was ¬•900 for one adult.

Sankeien (‰∏âÊ∫™Âúí, or "Three Creeks Garden") is a renowned traditional Japanese-style garden in Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa Prefecture. Spanning 175,000 square meters (about 43 acres), it's celebrated for its serene landscapes, seasonal beauty, and collection of historic buildings relocated from across the country. Designated as a National Place of Scenic Beauty, it offers a peaceful escape with ponds, streams, winding paths, and vibrant foliage changes year-round.
Agree to place to enjoy fall foliage at leisure. I suggest going to the garden in day afternoon, so that you can also enjoy the setting Sun right next to Mount Fuji in the observation Tower.

Sankeien is absolutely breathtaking ‚Äî a perfect blend of history, nature, and serenity. The garden is beautifully designed with wide ponds, winding paths, and traditional teahouses that make you feel like you‚Äôve stepped back in time. The highlight for me was the three-storied pagoda perched on the hill, a stunning backdrop especially during cherry blossom and autumn seasons.
Entrance is 900 for adults‚Ä¶
address: 58-1 Honmokusannotani, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0824, Japan

name: Sakuragicho
address: Sakuragicho, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0062, Japan

name: Akarenga Park
reviews: Nice park with plenty of things to see. Flowers, places to eat, photo friendly areas and overall feel-good place.

Beautifull place to be.
Whether to jog, or to gather your thought.
Good to socialize, or to be alone.
Here is 'something for everyone.

Next to the Red Brick Warehouse, it is the open area for sit, walk and enjoy any weather. Good for having a break, sit and talk, or eat. There are green grass patches and benches to sit. A couple of cruise options to Yokohama Station are also available from this waterfront. Also a good place to enjoy and participate in the events happening in the premises.

Akarenga Park in Yokohama is a delightful urban oasis that seamlessly blends historical charm with modern leisure. As a visitor with an affinity for both culture and relaxation, I found this park to be a true gem in the heart of the city.

The park's centerpiece is the iconic Red Brick Warehouse, a remnant of Yokohama's rich maritime history. The historic architecture, coupled with the serene waterfront setting, creates a captivating ambiance that transports visitors back in time. The warehouse has been repurposed into a vibrant shopping and dining complex, adding a contemporary touch to the historical site.

Strolling along the park's promenade, I was treated to stunning views of Yokohama Bay and the Yokohama Landmark Tower, adding to the picturesque allure of the location.

Akarenga Park is a popular gathering spot for locals and tourists alike, offering a wide array of events and seasonal festivals throughout the year. The lively atmosphere, coupled with the lush greenery, provides a perfect setting for picnics and social gatherings.

As a culture enthusiast, I appreciated the occasional art exhibitions and performances that added an artistic flair to the park's offerings.

In conclusion, Akarenga Park in Yokohama is a must-visit destination for anyone seeking a blend of history, leisure, and natural beauty. The harmonious integration of the Red Brick Warehouse's historical significance with the modern amenities and scenic waterfront creates an enchanting and dynamic experience. Whether you're exploring Yokohama or simply seeking a serene escape, Akarenga Park promises an unforgettable journey through the city's cultural and natural splendor.

Fantastic park during the Pikachu Outbreak.  The light and water show was great especially when they utilized the drones.  The show lasted nearly ten minutes.  A lot of refreshments are available between the two red brick warehouses.
address: 1 Chome-1 Shinko, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0001, Japan

name: Yamashita Park
reviews:
I came here on my last day of my trip to Japan. Glad I did! Wonderful quiet place and with such an amazing weather, it was an enjoyable walk. Not far from central Tokyo if you take the train and it‚Äôs so soothing.
Lovely!
Nice little park! Wish I could be here at night to see how this place lights up! They had a "Moveum" exhibit by Toyota, but I was a little intimidated to go in. Very beautiful park by the ocean!
It's a beautiful place. Lots of flowers, and it has an incredible view of the sea. The air is fresh, and if you are lucky, you can see so many different birds and insects. Totally worth it.

A Great open space in front of a vast body of water. If you want to have some quiet time out, alone or with company, this could be the place. A little crowded on the weekends but people are generally not boisterous in Japan..

On Sept 23, 2025, my wife and I came to this waterfront park. Judging from the number of visitors and activities here, the Park was a popular one. We didn‚Äôt walk much but took a tour bus from a nearby station - we bought a one-day bus/train ticket for Yen700.
address: 279 Yamashitach≈ç, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0023, Japan

name: Yokohama Motomachi Shopping Street
reviews: It‚Äôs a long walking distance from the World Porters but just beside the Chinatown to go here but the vibe here is different than other shopping street. I can feel the calmness of this shopping street compared to others that is famous among tourists. It‚Äôs good if you just want to stroll around it but there is not many things.

The Motomachi Shopping Street in Yokohama is a good place to visit if you have time after visiting Yokohama Chinatown. The Motomachi Shopping Street is only a few minutes' walk across the bridge. Most of the stores and restaurants are much different than those in Chinatown. I found many shops, bakeries, and restaurants that interest me.
Nice shopping street next to chinatown. Was here during winter and there was some nice illuminations around too. The street has lots of local and international brands.

There is a great shop for Japanese Woodblock prints (M. Iishii and Sons) along with a large selection of traditional Japanese ceramics and wooden kitchen items. The shop  owners are welcoming and very knowledgeable about the process of woodblock printing. Iishii-San had a small book that he shared to teach us about the traditional process of woodblock printing. Beautiful selection of woodblock prints and having one as a memory of Japan is a treasure.  Check it out.

Yokohama Motomachi Shopping Street
Review on 15/4/2025

It was a cool, crisp evening ‚Äî about half past six ‚Äî with the sun sinking into the horizon and the temperature gently dropping. Leaving the comfort of our hotel, we embarked on a nostalgic journey toward Motomachi Shopping Streets, a place steeped in cherished memories for one of our traveling companions.

The city felt serene, almost ethereal, as we walked along the sparsely trafficked main road. Fairy lights twinkled softly on the shrubs, illuminating sections of the pavement and casting a magical glow. We passed the dark, mysterious street that led to Yokohama Chinatown, a tantalising glimpse into another world waiting to be explored.

After about 25 minutes of walking, we arrived at our destination ‚Äî the enchanting Motomachi Shopping Streets. Greeting us was a striking metal arch crowned with a phoenix-shaped sculpture, its gleaming figure symbolising renewal and prosperity. It stood as a beacon of promise, inviting us into a realm of discovery and elegance.

The streets themselves were like stepping into a storybook ‚Äî no enclosed mall here, but open-air cobblestone pavements lined with charming boutique shops, cozy caf√©s, and tempting restaurants. The decorative streetlights cast warm halos over the pavement, blending Western sophistication with Japanese artistry to create a cosmopolitan haven.

The sky had turned into a blanket of midnight blue, and most of the shops had already closed for the day. Still, the architecture lining the streets captivated us ‚Äî majestic buildings with distinctive non-Japanese styles, each telling a tale of Yokohama‚Äôs vibrant history.

Our true quest came to light as we learned our companion‚Äôs purpose: to track down the elusive musical clock she had encountered 38 years ago. It was a bittersweet hunt, weaving past storefronts until we found ourselves at a corner 3-storey building specialising in jewelry, watches, and clocks. This store displayed a modest clock design with dotted lights on its external wall ‚Äî simple yet striking, though far from the grandeur she remembered.

Then came the moment we had anticipated ‚Äî the clock began its performance. Its melody broke through the hushed streets, enchanting the air and transforming the ambiance into something magical. It was a long-awaited delight, an echo of the past that seemed to bridge decades in a fleeting instant.

With hearts full and spirits lifted by the melodic chimes, we turned toward the street leading to Yokohama Chinatown, ready to indulge in a dinner that would cap off an unforgettable evening. The journey was more than a stroll; it was a tapestry of memory, discovery, and quiet beauty.
address: 1-ch≈çme-8 Motomachi, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0861, Japan

name: Yokohama Chinatown
reviews: I had a great time at Yokohama Chinatown where the food was delicious and the overall street design was truly impressive. I particularly loved the giant chicken which was only 500 yen and the ice cream for 400 yen was also a highlight. It was a pretty great experience and a wonderful place for a walk to enjoy all the different sights and flavors.

Loved it. Go at night for the lovely lights and atmosphere. Felt very welcome. Lots and lots of food, sweets, and gift options. Easy to get to from Tokyo. It is very crowded but if you move off the main drag it gets a bit better. If/when I come back to Japan, I would really think about staying in this area.

Very lively and colourful neighbourhood. Yet, not jam packed with tourists as in central Tokyo for example. You can actually walk and admire things here!
Many restaurants and interesting shops and there‚Äôs a train station very nearby if you‚Äôre coming from central Tokyo.

We looveee Yokohama.

First of, like most if the tourists, we only planned to visit Chinatown. But once we arrived, we kinda got confused bc every shops sell food and souvenirs only. And the price is not cheap either. But worth trying.

After decided to just try one of the restaurant, we headed to the brick building and want to see the ferries wheel. Instead of taking train or bus, we just walked. And that is the best way after all.

We found the city is so calm (prob bc it's sunday, so no workers or traffic). We like the buildings, the air, the harbour, and we bumped into an event, which we believed it for dogs. Bc everyone was bringing their dogs in costumes.

We didn't go to cup noodle museum or other attractions. Just enough for more than half day trip. Hope can be back someday bc we were in hurry to leave.

Yokohama Chinatown is a vibrant and lively place that feels completely different from other parts of the city. The moment I entered, I was surrounded by colorful gates, bright signs, and the smell of delicious food coming from every direction.
There are countless Chinese restaurants, street food stalls, and small shops selling sweets and souvenirs. I tried steamed buns and dumplings, and everything tasted rich and authentic. Walking through the streets was exciting, with people chatting, taking photos, and enjoying the atmosphere.
Even though it can get crowded, the energy of the area makes it enjoyable. It‚Äôs a great place to explore, eat, and experience a unique blend of Chinese and Japanese culture. I would definitely recommend visiting Yokohama Chinatown if you‚Äôre in the area.
address: Yamashitacho, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0023, Japan

name: Shinjuku Golden-Gai
reviews:
I finally made it to Golden-Gai and I‚Äôm honestly obsessed. This was my first time visiting and even though I‚Äôm usually not a fan of crowded, loud party spaces, there is something so different about this place.

The vibe is just amazing. It‚Äôs a maze of tiny alleys and every single shop looks so cool and unique. It feels like stepping into a different era of Tokyo. I loved that there are so many different types of bars to choose from so you can really find a spot that fits your mood. I ended up trying an oden bar which was super cozy and then found this other bar that literally looked like a library.

The only real downside is that a lot of the bars have a cover charge or an additional seating fee, so just keep that in mind before you head in. But honestly, for the experience and the atmosphere, it‚Äôs totally worth it. Such a unique spot!

THE MAZE WHERE EVERY DOOR IS A DIFFERENT UNIVERSE

¬∑

VIBE CHECK
this is not a street, it's a living diorama of post-war tokyo. golden gai is a legendary network of six narrow alleys packed with over two hundred micro-bars, each with its own wild theme and personality. the vibe is historic, intimate, and incredibly cool.

THE BAR SCENE
this is where you find many cool small bars, some seating only a handful of people. it's about connection and curiosity. bar-hopping here feels like flipping through channels on the world's most interesting tv.

FINAL VERDICT
come with an open mind and respectful curiosity. it's a unique, immersive dive into tokyo's soul. find a spot that calls to you, order a highball, and soak in the magic. an absolute must for an unforgettable night.

¬∑

peep the images for your ref; they‚Äôre worth a thou.

make sure to ‚ù§Ô∏è!

Golden Gai or Golden Town, in Shinjuku, is a small alley area, composed of 6 small lanes, where there are many small pubs, bars and small diners which often sell simple BBQ food, soup noodle, etc., in addition to liquor and wine.  In addition to eating and drinking, the area is also one of Japanese folk-art and other performing arts' birthplaces and later becomes a living center for many young performers and artists to manage their pub business and, at the same time, waiting for the acting, performing art opportunities.

Many small pubs do have their own unique decorations inside and outside the stores, including posters, and it is worthy for tourists to take a walk of the area. If tourists want to take photos, then, day-time walk is recommended because not many customers in the area, and photo taking may be easier.

Many bars or pubs in Golden Kai section have history of 40 years or longer, and a few of them do not accept foreign customers or tourists as their customers; generally, these bars or pubs prefer their frequent customers.

But a few pubs do open for all customers, including foreign tourists, such as Kenzo‚Äôs Bar [Bar owner is a playwriter and an actor, and he is very friendly and bar plays 1980s music], Bar Darling [perhaps because it is owned by a female actress, staffs are all female; the bar welcomes female customers, even single female], Ace‚Äôs [it does not impose cover charge and staffs can communicate English and welcome foreign tourists, and these bars do have reasonable pricing for drink and food.

Most of the bars in Golden Kai do impose entrance fee, seating fee or cover charge per person, which is in the range of 500 Yen to $1,000 Yen per person, although there are few bars which do not have entrance fee pr cover charge.  Most of the bars open from later afternoon or early night, such as 08PM, although a few of the bars do open 24/7 daily.

Although there are many bars in Golden Kai, the area does not allow public drinking or smoking in public section, and it is strictly enforced for the no smoking or drinking in public street rules.  However, most of the bars do allow smoking inside their bars.

1st time foreign visitors or tourists, can take Tokyo Metro Marunouchi Line [M Line] and get off at M-09 Shinjuku Sanchome Station and then walk to Exit 2, and the Golden Gai is in very short walking distance.

Great Spot to go out for drinks in Shinjuku. It‚Äôs like a labyrinth of tiny cozy bars with a very local vibe. Most of them are foreigners-friendly. Either with friends or solo, you‚Äôll always find some fun interesting people you can chat and share a drink with. Some bars have a small cover charge, others don‚Äôt but the drinks may be slightly more expensive. Most of them open around 5pm and can stay open till 5am, convenient for a barathon üòÇ and to taste a different local drink in each bar. One of the few bars I‚Äôd avoid though is ‚ÄúAdieu l‚Äôami‚Äù, they won‚Äôt tell you there‚Äôs a cover charge until the end (they had taken down the sign with the cover charge price the day I went) and the drinks are too expensive for what they are, I felt scammed.

Really cool looking alleys with bars in them. For some reason it didnt feel like the friendliest place though, which felt unusual for my experience of Japan so far. Still some great photo opportunities at night time. Didn't go into a bar because im an introvert and it felt like I would have to speak to strangers as they so small. Would recommend a walk around here though. Was better than Omoide Yokocho.

name: Yasukuni-jinja Shrine
reviews: A beautiful and vast shrine with a presence. The large tori gate greeting you as you enter the shrine makes this temple unique among the temple in Tokyo. When you enter the temple, you are greeted with a large public area with many sections to explore. Going near the end of the day is unique as you get to see the sun setting over the tori gate and the temple.

It's beautiful. The shrine is dedicated to the respect of all those who died fighting for Japan from the Meiji Era onward. There is the shrine proper, the Yushukan a museum to preserve the memory of the kami, an archive, a beautiful garden and several monuments.
The shrine is very important and there is a lot of people there during the day. The best time to be there is very early in the morning.

Very beautiful and peaceful place. They were doing construction before an event so there was scaffolding, but even that was pretty. Inside the museum is a nice gift shop and a pretty public toilet. Quick note, if you want to take a photo of the shrine, take it from the side near the gravel (or the guard will politely remind you).

Very big temple with - parking, vending machines, museum, food stalls and largely many festivals and ceremonies held very frequently. One of the best places to visit and experience the difference - pleasant and lively location with lot of Ginko trees and tree shades to beat the heat while in summer, beat the cold with fantastic views in winter, thrilling views during autumn with the color changes ‚Ä¶ a place one should never miss.

Founded by Emperor Meiji in June 1869 to commemorate those who died in service for Japan.
The shrine contains names of almost 2,5 million men including one thousand war criminals there of whom 12 were charged with class A crimes.
Because of this controversy the last two emperors never visited the shrine.
There's also a military museum adjacent to the shrine.

name: Chidorigafuchi Park
reviews:
Chidorigafuchi is hands down our ultimate favorite sakura spot! üå∏üíñ Nowhere else in Tokyo is more beautiful than Chidorigafuchi!

Another lucky coincidence that we came here on the last day of the sakura festival, as there weren't that many people. We planned to come here a week before, but it was raining for days. Good thing we waited for that beautiful, sunny day.

Definitely coming back here in the future.

Tips:
- The best route is from the exit of Kudanshita Station.
- There are approximately 1,000 sakura trees. According to their billboard, you can donate to the park if you want to help protect these poor trees from the effects of climate change.
- According to the signs, you can't use tripod.
- The line for the boat is already long when we passed by at 8am. They start operations at 9am.
- Night lights turn on from sunset to 10pm.

Although the park is located a bit far from the city center, the distance is well worth it. One of the things I appreciated most was that it wasn‚Äôt overly crowded, which made the whole experience feel more peaceful and enjoyable. Out of all the parks I visited in Tokyo, this one easily had the most stunning scenery‚Äîlush greenery, serene water views, and beautifully maintained landscapes that felt almost like stepping into a painting. The air was noticeably fresh and clean, adding to the overall sense of calm. I highly recommend trying the boating experience here‚Äîit was both relaxing and fun, offering a unique way to take in the natural beauty of the park. It‚Äôs definitely a hidden gem and a great escape from the hustle and bustle of the city.

We visited during cherry blossom season, and it was absolutely beautiful. I‚Äôm not sure what it‚Äôs like the rest of the year, but our experience at that time was amazing. You can‚Äôt reserve boat tickets in advance (at least not that I saw), so it‚Äôs first come, first served. We waited in line to get a scheduled time and were lucky to get a slot just 45 minutes out‚Äîwhich was great! We had expected to wait much longer, possibly even needing to return in the evening.

My tip: arrive early and have a few other things planned nearby so you can adjust based on what time slot you get. Even if you don‚Äôt end up boating, the area itself is gorgeous and definitely worth a visit.

Sakura Walkway by the Riverüå∏üõ∂ü¶Ü

‚Ä¢ A peaceful spot for a seasonal walk during cherry blossom time!

‚Ä¢ Be sure to check the weather‚Äîsunny days enhance the atmosphere significantly.

‚Ä¢ While the overall view is pleasant, there are only a few standout spots for photos. Most sections of the path look quite similar, so don‚Äôt expect a wide variety of scenic points. Still worth a visit if you‚Äôre nearby and enjoy sakura strolls.

This one is another beautiful park to visit in Tokyo to view Cherry blossom.  Visited it on 7th April afternoon. The view of Cherry blossom along the Hanzo moat was simply magical. From the park, the path leading to the Imperial Palace east garden is a nice walk and in the evenings the cherry blossom glowing in the light is another unforgettable experience. Even without cherry blossom the walk along the moat in the evening is quite nice.

name: Imperial Palace East National Gardens
reviews: Beautiful and peaceful, wide open spaces with lots of greenery that will make you double-think if you're really still in Tokyo. The weather was great (late Oct) and although the autumn leaves weren't out yet, the trees and grass are lush and full of life. The huge koi fish swimming in the pond are also wonderful to look at. There is a bag check at the entrance.

Loved visiting the Imperial Palace East Garden. It‚Äôs a vast and peaceful place, perfect for a relaxing walk. Lots of different trees, nice gardens, koi ponds, and interesting old palace structures like guard houses, cellars, watch-towers, tea house. In case u want to take a break, there are rest areas equipped with vending machines too. The entry to the garden is free! Totally worth visiting... üçÉ

Absolutely gorgeous garden! A lot of work has gone into preserving its historical significance and beauty, including preserving original guard barracks and the orchard. Now, the garden serves as a celebration of Japan. They‚Äôve added various sections such as the bamboo garden with different bamboos found across the country and a tree garden with one tree from every province. The landscaping is impressive‚Äîthey‚Äôve maintained the original walls and moats‚Äîand they‚Äôve done their best to make the gardens accessible to all ages.

No fee or ticket needed for entry, just a bag check at the entrances. Reading other reviews, it‚Äôs worth noting there is no palace here anymore, nor is the palace really visible. This is just the East Garden adjacent the current Imperial Palace.

The Imperial Palace East Gardens are beautiful, even on cloudy days. I enjoyed seeing seasonal fruit trees like persimmons and citrus. The gardens are modern but designed based on the Edo-period layout on the former castle site. The guided Imperial Palace tour pairs well with a visit.

Beautiful grounds - a lovely, green sanctuary within the busyness of the city. It seems very well maintained. I appreciated the informative signs, and labels for the trees. A really nice way to spend a sunny afternoon!

name: Tsuzumi-mon Gate
reviews:
We visited Kanazawa Station‚Äôs Tsuzumi-mon Gate just before 5pm, right as the sun was setting, and it was absolutely breathtaking. The warm evening lights illuminated the massive wooden archway, creating a dramatic contrast against the cool blue sky. In person, the scale and craftsmanship are even more impressive than any photo can capture.

The gate is shaped like traditional Japanese tsuzumi hand drums, and standing beneath it feels both grand and inviting. The beautifully lit structure draws you in, leading naturally toward the modern glass Motenashi Dome behind it. The combination of traditional design with modern architecture is truly iconic ‚Äî a perfect reflection of Kanazawa‚Äôs blend of culture, history, and innovation.

The entire area is spacious, clean, and beautifully designed. We loved walking around the plaza, taking photos from different angles ‚Äî from directly underneath the pillars to across the street where the whole gate comes into view. The lighting at sunset was perfect and made the reddish wood glow warmly.

Whether you‚Äôre arriving, departing, or simply sightseeing, Tsuzumi-mon is a must-see landmark and one of the most memorable station entrances in Japan. A spectacular welcome to Kanazawa!

The gate view is nice but the station has nothing much to offers, it's busy, there is a shopping mall next to it where youay shop some clothing a d good food. Overall, it's just a wooden gate, with blue lights shining it...

It's big, it's impressive, it's symbolic. It lights up at night (looking better in blue than red, imho) and there's a fun little clock nearby.

Lovely little focal point that lets you know you're in Kanazawa.

Pretty impressive gate right in front of Kanazawa station
Along with a small fountain and a clock.
Impressive landmark, popular with tourists and locals alike.

name: Kanazawa Castle Park
reviews:
Kanazawa Castle has a spacious interior area, beautifully designed like a Japanese garden. The atmosphere is calm and perfect for relaxing or even going for a jog. It‚Äôs not crowded and the grounds are very clean.

A big bonus is that it‚Äôs right next to Kenroku-en Garden‚Äîyou can walk between the two easily. The castle itself has been nicely renovated and looks fresh and well-maintained. If you‚Äôre visiting Kanazawa, it‚Äôs definitely worth a stop.

Stunning castle grounds with incredibly well-preserved architecture. The contrast between the white lead-tiled roofs and the massive stone walls is beautiful.
It is much larger than it looks, and the panoramic views of the courtyard are great for photos. It's located right next to Kenrokuen Garden, so it‚Äôs easy to visit both. Highly recommend a peaceful walk through the park!

This is an interesting place to visit. Mixture of original and reconstructed buildings On a large site great to walk around and explore.

Impressive rebuild of the castle buildings. The detailed craftsmanship is amazing. Other buildings are in process of being rebuild.

A good 1-2 hours to get around the site. Not too busy either.  Nice park and gardens. Other attractions close by too

This was a very nice and and peaceful place. The crowds were not too bad but it was a week day in autumn. The castle part was undergoing reconstruction efforts so I couldn‚Äôt explore a lot however there was still parts to explore and learn.

The gardens though were immaculate, the trees were just beautiful. There‚Äôs tons of great places for cute photos here too. There‚Äôs pods and bridges just very serene and worth the time to visit on a casual stroll.

I would say if you are less interested in nature you may not enjoy this place. It‚Äôs not full of flowers or other vibrant things. Instead the architecture around the walk ways and the shape of the trees along with the ponds makes it a wonderful and relaxing place.

What a lovely park, very clean and tidy. Good to have a wander round, even if you don't want to actually enter the castle itself.
Lots of toilets, as is usual for Japan. It's absolutely lovely to see public toilets, open, clean and not vandalised. If you're in the area, have a wander through the park, it's very nice.

name: Oyama Shrine
reviews:
Oyama Shrine is a quiet and pleasant stop in Kanazawa, best known for its unique Western-style gate, which makes it stand out from other shrines in Japan.

The shrine is connected to beautiful garden areas, and if you keep walking a little further, you can easily reach Kanazawa Castle. It works very well as a scenic shortcut or a calm route when walking toward the castle, instead of taking the main streets.

The grounds are peaceful and easy to walk through, making it a nice place to slow down for a moment while exploring the city. A great stop if you‚Äôre visiting Kenrokuen, Oyama Shrine, and Kanazawa Castle on the same route.
This is an understated shrine and its compound is beautifully landscaped and ornamented. There are ample places for good photographs. Entry is free. Some donations would be appreciated.
A free to visit shrine that features magnificent architecture and there is not that much people on a weekday. Worth a visit but there is no need to spend a lot of time there

Decent shrine. You can walk past it to get to Osaka castle. Pretty laid back area. Not full of tourist so you can get some decent photos during the day. What I liked most is that it‚Äôs fully accessible at night as you can get some sweet photos unless you have a Nokia or are one of those cool alternative people with film. But I would still recommend it if you are one of them.

This shrine has a unique western influenced architecture which is easily seen from the outside. The inside of the shrine is spacious and there's a garden and pond behind it which has really nice scenery for photos. It was drizzling when we visited and the vibes are kinda chill and calming.

name: Nij≈ç Castle
reviews: I have mixed feelings about visiting this place. I thought the story about the nightingale floors was super interesting, and you can really hear it super well when you're walking around inside! It is lovely. But besides that, everything inside the castle really did not manage to keep my interest. Everything you see is a replica, and there are life sized dolls/mannequins all throughout the property to illustrate how people used to sit in the rooms for example. Personally i really dislike when museums use these kind of dolls, to me it's cheap and disrupts the beautiful things there are to see, but i understand why the mannequins are placed there. I understand they are there to help people visualize better. I just personally don't like it. The gardens around the castle were nice. The public restroom was dirty.

Visited Nij≈ç Castle today. It's a good culture experience to visit and look at how they constructed the building all those years ago.

It's a marvellous to see how it has held up all these years later.

It's something you need to experience when visiting Kyoto.

If you can, join a tourist guide for a little $$ extra on top of the entry fee to listen to the history, build, how each room was used, and image you being there back in the 1600.

Worth doing if you want to learn about the history or just want to kill some time.

I visited Nijo Castle on a weekdays therefore there were not that much crowd. It is such an interesting place to learn about the castle history. There are observation deck too where you can relax. On the day I visited Ni omaru castle was closed unfortunately. I love the architecture of the door/ gate so much. It's exquisite.

Nijo Castle is a good stop if you want to see an important historical site in Kyoto. The Ninomaru Palace is the main reason to visit, especially the nightingale floors, which make sounds as you walk and are quite memorable. The rooms are well maintained, but photos are not allowed inside, so just take your time looking.

I recommend buying the ticket that includes the Ninomaru Palace, the palace rooms are well preserved, but photos are not allowed inside. The garden is nice and relaxing, and it‚Äôs worth walking around slowly. There is also a former castle keep area where you can get a view of the grounds.

Nearby places: After visiting Nijo Castle, it‚Äôs easy to continue to Kyoto Imperial Palace, Nishiki Market for food, shopping, and caf√©s.

A very beautiful castle, and the castle grounds, particularly the gardens, are equally impressive. Entry fee is minimal, and the castle itself was located very near to our hotel. Be ready to take a lot of pictures and a lot of walking. If you're traveling with kids, they might not be able to appreciate the whole place, and may lose interest after the first 30 minutes or so üòâ. Nevertheless, this is a must visit attraction if you are in kyoto.

name: Kiyomizu-dera
reviews:
Visited Kiyomizu‚Äëdera in March 2025.
In the afternoon, it was somewhat crowded, but still manageable and didn‚Äôt stop me from enjoying the visit. There‚Äôs quite a bit of walking uphill to reach the temple, passing through the charming historic streets that lead toward the complex.
What really stood out to me was the iconic wooden main hall and terrace.
The massive wooden stage is one of Kiyomizu‚Äëdera‚Äôs most famous features‚Äîbuilt high above the hillside and offering sweeping views of the forest and the city below. It creates an incredible sense of openness, and stepping onto it feels like looking out over Kyoto from a natural balcony.
Beautiful  vantage point, especially with sunlight hitting the surrounding scenery.
The architecture itself is impressive. The entire temple complex blends beautifully with the mountain landscape, and the buildings reflect centuries of cultural and religious history.

Kiyomizu-dera is a must when you go to Kyoto. I went on an evening for one of their autumnal evening sessions. It was very stressful to deal with all the crowds so I suggest you come there either very early or late if you want to see it peacefully. The complex has lots of history and rituals (the fountains, the anchor, the fortune telling, etc.) to explore so I recommend you do it at your own pace to do everything.

I think the temple looks gorgeous at night with the momiji season and this place warrants both a daytime and nighttime visit (but only if you have been here before and you have plenty of time for a second visit).

Autumn at Kiyomizu-dera is absolutely stunning, and visiting during the peak maple leaf season means crowds are inevitable. Even so, the entrance ticket and the breathtaking scenery make it completely worth it.

We arrived at Kiyomizu-dera around noon on a weekday, but the number of visitors was no less than on a weekend. Sannenzaka was packed with people, so we chose a quieter side path instead. Along the way, we unexpectedly discovered a small embroidery gift shop with unique and beautifully crafted items.

As we made our way uphill, we explored several spots, drew a fortune and got daikichi (great luck), and even heard children playfully imitating crow calls, which added a lovely sense of life to the journey. The whole atmosphere felt perfect for unwinding and clearing the mind after a busy work schedule. Nice choice for annual leave.

That said, I would recommend starting earlier in the day to avoid the crowds and better enjoy the autumn leaves.

Beautiful but way too crowded. Incredibly overstimulating and chaotic. There are hundreds of people. First you have to walk through a bizarrely busy street to even get to the temple. So over all its just overwhelming. The buildings are beautiful though. In this area there are also many ladies dressed up in kimono's which is cute to see. You can also collect Goshuin here in a separate room where you have to take off your shoes.

My favourite sight in Kyoto. Super crowded during our visit around 12.30pm on a Sunday. This is such a gorgeous temple with beautiful grounds. Can imagine how much more gorgeous the place is in spring or earlier 2 weeks ago during the autumn changing color. Even now, it looks so gorgeous and serene especially around the pond area. It was quite a way to walk in but interesting to see all the shops around. Strongly recommend to try the mochi mochi shop along Matsubara-Dori Street. For someone who doesn‚Äôt like mochi, this was really good, haha love the chocolate flavor. Great treat and beautiful sights!

name: Pontocho Park
reviews: Beautiful places and I love the vibes here‚Äôs especially in the evening. You will find a street music and go to the small street to have dinner. Beautiful üòª

I recently visited Pontocho Park, and it perfectly captures the charm of Kyoto‚Äôs traditional atmosphere. Nestled beside the Kamogawa River, it‚Äôs a peaceful spot where you can enjoy both nature and the city‚Äôs vibrant culture. The narrow streets nearby are filled with old-style restaurants and lanterns that glow beautifully at night, giving the whole area a timeless feeling. It‚Äôs a wonderful place to take a quiet walk, watch the river flow, and feel the unique rhythm of Kyoto life. Truly an underrated gem worth visiting!
Lovely place to chill and watch the river. Also every evening from 4 to 9 there are local musicians playing Shamisen and other instruments. Had a great time. Will come again. And you should too. üòÜ

Cool place to hang out. Seems very lively at all hours. Lots of shops, restaurants and bars. Lots of people walking about purposefully. Nice place to people watch and grab a meal or just stroll by the river.
It‚Äôs a bit touristy but very nice still. Lots of stores and little food stands.
address: ÂÖàÊñóÁî∫ÈÄö, ÔºëÔºîÔºï, Umenokich≈ç, Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto, 604-8012, Japan

name: Eikand≈ç
reviews:
Our guide told us this is one of the best places to see Autumn üçÅ colours. The temple is unique for Amida Buddha statue looking back over its shoulder , unlike any other Budda statue in Japan.
We took off our shoes in placed them in a bag and walked around the temple to learn more about it, photography inside isn't allowed.
The outside garden is beautiful and filled with red and orange üçÅ leaves.
The highlight is a pond with the reflection of the autumn leaves and a bright red Koi fish in it.
Loved the temple complex.

Visiting Eikan-d≈ç Ê∞∏Ë¶≥Â†Ç in Kyoto was a truly memorable experience. The temple grounds are spacious and beautifully arranged, and every step feels like walking into a quiet painting. The pathways, trees, moss, ponds, and traditional buildings all blend so well together that you naturally slow down and enjoy each moment.

The scenery changes beautifully with the seasons, but Eikan-d≈ç is especially famous for its autumn colors. When the leaves turn deep red and golden orange, the entire temple looks almost unreal‚Äîlike a landscape painting brought to life. Even in other seasons, the subtle greens and soft natural light give the gardens a peaceful charm.

One of the most enjoyable moments was simply standing still and looking at the reflections in the pond; the scene looks perfectly composed, as if nature and architecture were designed together from the beginning. There are many viewpoints where you feel like the scenery in front of you could be framed as art.

Walking around Eikan-d≈ç gives a calm feeling and allows you to appreciate not only the beauty of the temple itself but also the atmosphere of traditional Kyoto. It‚Äôs a place where nature, culture, and quietness all come together in a very harmonious way. I felt like I was looking at paintings everywhere I turned, and the experience stays beautifully in your memory even after leaving. üåø‚ú®

They say this where to see the beautiful autumn foliage in Kyoto aside from Kiyomizu-dera üôÇ some other maple trees are in full bloom others are all withered. They have a special event for autumn. It‚Äôs really best to visit the temple a few hours before closing as there were fewer crowds and I‚Äôve witnessed a monk ringing some ceremonial bells for a few minutes.
I got to climb the pagoda too and see the beautiful golden sky of Kyoto city. I really enjoyed my stay here as I‚Äôm flying back to my country the next morning. I would love to visit again! üå∏

One of my favorites temple visit because of the momiji illumination night view. I walked from Nanzenji temple for around 5 minutes or so before reavhing to Eikando temple. However had to wait for half an hour because the night illumination is only open from 5.30pm onwards, the queue was quite long since it is a famous night illumination spot. Needless to say, the view is really enchanting at night, despite being at night you can still see the vibrant colors of the leaves. Do brace the cold if you go in Dcember though. I had a great experience here and would recommend everyone to pay a visit during peak momiji season.

Visiting Eikando for the night maple illumination was a unique and memorable experience. The lighting beautifully highlights the vibrant autumn leaves, giving the whole temple garden a magical atmosphere. It feels completely different from daytime viewing‚Äîwarmer, deeper, and full of charm.

That said, be prepared for very heavy crowds. The paths move slowly, and it can take quite a while to get through the grounds. Still, the scenery is stunning enough to make the slow pace worth it.
A wonderful spot for night-time autumn foliage.

name: Nanzen-ji
reviews: One of my favorite Kyoto temples that I visited. A bit far from the city center but can be reached by taking the City Bus. It's on a hilly area so do expect stairs and slopes and uphill terrain. One of the most beautiful temple I went to since it is during momiji season therefore the tree leaves are colorful. One of its famous attractions and popular photo spots is the old aqueduct. If you go further up the hill you'll find a shrine at the top. I love how this temple is at the hill, therefore it's literally in the woods. It's like you're going through a wood with a temple in it.

Nanzenji Temple is one of Kyoto‚Äôs most important Zen Buddhist temples, known for its peaceful atmosphere and rich historical charm. Located at the base of the Higashiyama mountains, the temple grounds are spacious and surrounded by nature, making it a perfect place to slow down and reflect. The massive Sanmon gate stands as a powerful symbol of Zen philosophy and offers a beautiful view of Kyoto from the top. One of Nanzenji‚Äôs most unique features is the brick aqueduct from the Meiji era, where traditional temple scenery blends naturally with modern history. In autumn, the temple becomes especially popular as maple leaves turn the area into shades of red and gold, while spring brings fresh greenery and quiet beauty. Walking through Nanzenji feels calm and grounding, as the sound of water, rustling leaves, and temple bells creates a timeless and soothing experience for visitors.

The autumn colors at Nanzen-ji are some of the most beautiful I‚Äôve ever seen‚Äîvivid maples everywhere, yet the atmosphere remains calm and deeply serene. The temple grounds have a quiet, timeless charm that makes you slow down without even realizing it.

One of my favorite moments was sitting along the engawa overlooking the garden as the sun set. The warm light on the trees, the soft breeze, and the peaceful silence felt incredibly relaxing and healing.

If you‚Äôre visiting Kyoto in autumn, Nanzen-ji is an absolute must. A perfect blend of nature, beauty, and Zen tranquility.

A must see Kyoto attraction as a tourist. A bit far from the station, which was great for a more quiet, relaxing visiting.

There's both paid and free areas, both are beautiful. Definitely worth a visit.

Also one of the few temples where there's opportunities for tourists to take their shoes off and walk freely inside. Please be considerate of staff instructions and posted signage.

Serene and peaceful, that‚Äôs why there are many visitors to this temple. It‚Äôs set right behind a mountain with gorgeous forrest. This is a must visit place when you are in Kyoto if you are looking for where locals visit. My family absolutely love the environment.
address: 86 Nanzenji Fukuchich≈ç, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto, 606-8435, Japan

name: Daihikaku Senk≈ç-ji Temple
reviews: I skipped the arashiyama monkey park as there is already plenty monkeys where I came from (Malaysia, humans included) and I walked down the path leading all the way to this temple. Along the way you will find multiple signs which promises you a temple with great view. While the path towards the temple was pretty long, I would say it's worth it simply for how beautiful it is, I would even say the walk itself is my favourite amongst everything I have done in Arashiyama. There is also a bell where you can ring before heading up towards the temple. Once you arrived, you are required a 400 yen entrance fee. The temple itself is not grand by any means, but you do get the promised view which was quite fulfilling. Also there's was an ongoing meditation (?) class in the room so that's pretty cool.
Yes it‚Äôs worth taking the path with less ppl. Worth taking that 200 steps hike up to this temple to soak in the view. Simply beautiful to soak all the nature w/o the crowds.

Amazing temple away from the busy crowds üòç you get to see beautiful river on the way to the temple too, they take cash only 400yen /person. I was there and it wasn‚Äôt that bad of a hike. Absolutely calm and peaceful üòå
Lovely walk along the river,  you live all the hustle and business behind. A climb up via steps appro 1.6 k from the centre

One of the most incredible adventures of my life. The walk to the climb is alongside the river. Incredible views everywhere. Decent effort required to climb but anyone can do it and should. The staff are so kind and welcoming. Ring the bell at the top and visit with the monk. The view over the top is a memory you will love forever.
address: 62 Arashiyama Nakaoshitach≈ç, Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto, 616-0004, Japan

name: Rankyo Gorge
reviews:
Had lunch here on a hot day, which was both a great idea and a questionable life choice. The scenery is outstanding: emerald-green water, forested hills that look Photoshopped, and boats drifting by like Kyoto‚Äôs idea of ambient screensavers.

The downside? Shade is optional. Very optional. The sun shows up fully leveraged, no mercy, no clouds, just vibes and UV. Bring water. Bring a hat. Bring the humility to admit you are not tougher than July in Kyoto.

That said, this is an excellent place to slow down, eat something simple, and pretend you‚Äôre in a travel documentary instead of quietly sweating through your shirt. The path along the river is easy, scenic, and well maintained, and even when it‚Äôs busy, it feels calm...like everyone collectively agreed not to rush.

This isn‚Äôt a place for comfort. It‚Äôs a place for perspective. And maybe heat stroke-adjacent reflection.

YOU ALL HAVE TO VISIT THIS SIDE OF THE KATSURA RIVER, A HIDDEN GEM OF ARASHIYAMA!
No words can describe the beauty of this place in autumn. Crystal clear water, colourful foliage, moutain, boats, rocks, everything creates an epic natural picture. Cross the bridge, walk along the river bank and enjoy the quite side of Arashiyama.

I've had a wonderful experience there. It's a nice trail from the Arashiyama Bamboo Forest. Just follow the signs and you will get there. You can then sit around and relax!

There is a view point of this river before arriving here in case you missed. I believe it's more beautiful in Autumn.
Excellent place. You can enjoy a beautiful and peaceful natural landscape if you come early enough, i.e. before the crowds arrive. We visited in the early morning on 23 November 2025.

Nice if you can manage to find the trails and go deeper into the park. Very close to The Bamboo forests but close to the Arashiyama shopping areas and tourist hot spots. Row boats are available to rent to go up and down river. Very beautiful scenery and worth a visit. No cost to walk around the park areas and nice for a quiet getaway day hike.

name: Arashiyama Park viewpoint
reviews: The journey to this place was worth every step up. Recommended to come on the 1st  train. The view in the morning before the crowd come is absolutely gorgeous. You'll need to walk through arashimaya bamboo trail then up a steep trail in the hills before you see 3 view points. Come wearing comfortable shoes to walk a trail.

One of the most scenic places I have ever been in all of japan

Its quite a hike to the observation deck but the views are absolutely worth the effort

There are shops and cafes. Near the river

I got there from the Arashyma bamboo groove by walking through the Kameyama-Koen area of Arashiyama Park. The deck is located on a hill overlooking the Hozu River and is easily accessible from the northern end of the bamboo grove.

22nd November 2025
Part 5 of my Arashiyama trip review.

It took some climbing but nothing crazy. I had some trouble as I was still recovering from a jog last night.
Once I've reached this place.
A great view, but I would be lying if I wasn't disappointed (only a little though). Unfortunately, I was wrong to hope that the whole (or at least 50%) of the mountains are in lush red, orange or green.
Mainly, the colours are dispersed quite sparsely. But hey! Don't let me take away from your experience!
Still definitely worth the visit !
Stunning panorama and breathtaking views of mountain and valley, blanketed in the foliage of autumn. Just takes few minutes walking from arashiyama bamboo forest.

A really beautiful part of the world. The short trek to the viewpoint past the bamboo forest is breathtaking (and free!). When you hit the T-junction in the bamboo forest, go left and then head uphill to the observation point. Next view point about 50m to the right is also nice. Then take the long walk along the river back to the town area. The view of the river and gorge alone is well worth the visit.

name: Tenryu-ji
reviews: Tenryu-ji Temple in Arashiyama felt like stepping into a perfectly painted landscape. The whole place is incredibly calm, with a beautiful pond right at the center that reflects the trees and mountains like a mirror. The garden is stunning and so well maintained that every corner looks deliberate, almost like it was arranged for visitors to slow down and breathe for a moment. It is peaceful, scenic, and genuinely one of those temples where you can just sit for a while and feel your mind settle.

I visited Tenryuji temple while visiting Arashiyama. It is famous for its garden. During momiji peak season the garden is very beautiful with tress with different colored leaves, sadly I went when the peak season is ending therefore a lot of leaves already fallen. If you buy ticket for temple entrance and garden together you can get a cheaper price. The trail was easy there was no steep slopes or many stairs so very friendly towards people with knees issue. From the garden also you can get a glimpse of the famous Arashiyama bamboo forest.

Very nice and grand temple for sure.  It has many from small, medium, and large individual sections of house that next to each other.  And at the middle, there is a garden (which you have to purchase tix to entrance). Each house has it own garden and the design and the decor are different from one to another.  Very intriguing and inspiring, you can cell the calmest one you enter the temple.   Very unique and one of a kind for sure.  The garden is big and pretty and very picturesque.

Visiting Tenryu-ji Â§©ÈæçÂØ∫ in Kyoto was a truly enjoyable experience. The temple grounds feel peaceful from the moment you enter, and the beautiful garden surrounding the main hall is one of the highlights. The combination of traditional architecture, quiet pathways, and carefully arranged nature creates a relaxing atmosphere that invites you to slow down and appreciate the view.

The famous garden is especially impressive with its large pond, elegant rocks, and the beautiful arrangement of trees. No matter which season you visit‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs fresh greenery, colorful autumn leaves, or gentle winter scenery‚Äîthe landscape has its own charm. The way the garden blends naturally with the mountains behind it makes the view look almost like a living painting.

Walking through Tenryu-ji gives a calm feeling and offers a wonderful way to enjoy both nature and traditional temple culture in Kyoto. It‚Äôs a lovely place to take photos, enjoy the scenery, and spend a quiet moment away from the busy city. I found the experience very memorable and would definitely recommend it. üåø‚ú®

Tenryu-ji (Arashiyama): Arashiyama‚Äôs Zen garden gem‚Äîits pond uses ‚Äúborrowed scenery‚Äù to frame Arashiyama‚Äôs mountains (pure landscape magic).

‚Ä¢ Seasonal highlights: Fall = maple hues + mountain reflections; Spring = cherry blossoms dusting the garden.

Pro Tips:

‚Ä¢ Walk 5 mins to Arashiyama Bamboo Grove (perfect combo route).

‚Ä¢ Arrive

name: Arashiyama Park Kameyama Area
reviews: Enjoyed this more than the bamboo forest as the crowds were more spread out. Beautiful to visit in fall. Could have spent more time exploring the different paths, but had to leave to catch a boat ride. Toilets were also clean

22nd November 2025
Part 3 of my Arashiyama Trip review.
Across the bridge, I arrived at the ABSOLUTELY STUNNING VIEW of Kameyama Park.
The colours....the Red, Orange, Yellow, each with different hues, along with thr ever-present lush greens. These combo, complemented with the vast infinite blue sky, was jaw-dropping.
As you can see from my photos, it still does not do justice to the real life scenery.
My eyes are forever spoiled by this trip. It will never see colour again and I am ever more grateful to be blessed with sight

Beautiful scenery. Arashiyama park is a great place to take photos. The restaurants and stores near make this park even better if you want to spend the day near it too. The best part is that all of this is free!

Summary üìù:
- beautiful scenery üèûÔ∏è
- near restaurants and stores üõçÔ∏è
- despite being near a river, there are very
little bugs üêú

I'm not a good photographer, so you could probably get much better photos than the ones below!

Right next to the bamboo forest and it‚Äôs far less crowded. There are beautiful riverside views, and even more beautiful views of the gorge from the top of the hill. Well worth the climb, even though it‚Äôs not the most fun in the middle of summer.

Kyoto's Park Kameyama Area is a lovely spot for a relaxed break from the city's crowds. Tucked away within the Arashiyama Bamboo Grove, it's easy to miss, but worth seeking out. The park is a peaceful, hilly area with a few scenic viewpoints that offer great photo opportunities of the river and the surrounding mountains. It's a nice place to sit on a bench, enjoy the quiet, and watch the small boats drift by. While it doesn't have the grand, iconic feel of some of Kyoto's more famous sites, its charm lies in its simplicity and tranquility. It's the perfect place to catch your breath and enjoy a moment of nature before heading back into the bustling streets.

name: Arashiyama Nakaoshitacho
address: Arashiyama Nakaoshitacho, Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto, 616-0004, Japan

name: Nishiki Market
reviews:
Nishiki Market is a lively, sensory-rich place that captures the everyday food culture of Kyoto in a very direct way. Walking through the long, narrow arcade, you‚Äôre surrounded by stalls selling everything from fresh seafood and pickles to sweets, skewers, and traditional snacks. The atmosphere feels busy but engaging, with many vendors preparing food right in front of you, which makes browsing as enjoyable as eating. It‚Äôs an easy place to sample a wide variety of local flavors in a short amount of time.

That said, the market can feel crowded, especially during peak hours, and it‚Äôs more suited to slow wandering than quick shopping. Prices at some stalls may seem higher than outside markets, but the convenience and variety partly explain that. Overall, Nishiki Market offers a vivid snapshot of Kyoto‚Äôs culinary traditions and is well worth a visit for anyone interested in Japanese food and street-level local culture.

A total tourist trap but one you have to experience at least once. The street is narrow, the crowds are relentless, and the atmosphere is loud. Come for the chaos. Stay for the spectacle: a maze of tightly packed vendors offering everything from fresh seafood and skewered mystery snacks to delicate sweets, fragrant teas, and unique souvenirs.

The energy here is infectious, the grazing is fun, and pushing through the crowds feels like stepping straight into Kyoto‚Äôs food culture. The food varies widely in quality. There are some truly delicious finds, but many offerings are just okay and often come with a hefty price tag. Still, that‚Äôs part of the charm, sampling unfamiliar treats, watching skilled vendors at work, and soaking up the vibrant chaos.

Take your time wandering, try a few intriguing snacks, and enjoy the spectacle. If you want a more substantial or reliably high-quality meal, though, you‚Äôll be better off heading to one of the nearby restaurants just outside the market.

Wonderful 1st day in Japan & Kyoto to explore all the delish foods available.  The place is about half a mile long or abit more and every inches of the place filled with different type of foods which make it harder to figure out which one to try 1st.  We ended up tasting 30% of everything that offered.  Glad that we ate and walked and ate and walked some more.  Definitely a great place to check out for sure.  All stalls and restaurants are great with customer service, and it makes it harder to leave.  Love it and will come back for more next time.

This is the spiritual home of Kyoto snacking: five blocks of culinary temptation wrapped in a roof that looks like a technicolor spreadsheet. If you come here hungry, congratulations: you‚Äôre the target demographic. If you come here not hungry, don‚Äôt worry...give it ten minutes and the smell of grilled seafood, sesame, and pickled‚Ä¶ everything‚Ä¶ will break you down like a private-equity acquisition.

Yes, there‚Äôs genuinely great food here. Fresh seafood, sesame-crusted everything, teas, sweets, things on sticks you couldn‚Äôt identify under oath...it‚Äôs all part of the charm. The vibe is electric, chaotic, and very much a people-watching goldmine.

But let‚Äôs not kid ourselves: this place is also touristy as hell. For every stall selling authentic Kyoto flavors, there‚Äôs another quietly upselling you into a ¬•700 ‚Äúlocal experience‚Äù that may or may not be microwaved. It‚Äôs the classic trap...you know it, they know it, and we all just smile and play our part.
