Still, the energy is great, the snacks are fun, and weaving through the crowd feels like stepping into Kyoto‚Äôs bloodstream. Come for the food, stay for the vibe, accept that you‚Äôll overpay for at least one thing and pretend it was worth it for the cultural enrichment.

Four stars. A must-visit...just keep one hand on your wallet and the other on the nearest skewer.

This was fun! It wasn‚Äôt very crowded around 10:30am on a Tuesday and all of the shops were open. We were able to stop for food at different stalls and walk the entire market in about an hour and a half and as we were leaving around noon it was getting very crowded so definitely come early

name: ringram Osakaumedaten
reviews: I had a wonderful experience at Ringram! The staff were incredibly kind, patient, and professional. The craftsmanship of the rings is truly impressive ‚Äî elegant, unique, and made with great attention to detail. The whole process felt personal and special, and I left with a ring that I absolutely love. Highly recommended for anyone looking for quality and exceptional service! üíç

I had a wonderful experience making my own ring for the first time. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è The one who assisted me was very patient and accommodating. She tried her best to help me translate the phrase that I want for the ring engraving. All the staff are friendly as well.

It was such a fun experience! Took less than an hour. We made the appointment a month in advanced. We chose the option to select your style once you got there. They allow you to try on samples and pick what size, design, and finish (matte vs shiny). They also offered the simple engraving for free! We don‚Äôt speak any Japanese and were able to communicate well. Highly recommend for the memories.
This shop is a great place to come with your partner or friends to make each other a ring. The shop has a great atmosphere and the staff are friendly. Highly recommended!
Very nice workshop. Staff is very friendly and teach us how to do the tasks. Rings are so lovely üòç
address: Japan, „Äí530-0013 Osaka, Kita Ward, Chayamachi, 8-3 „É≠„ÉÉ„ÇØ‚àí8 Ëå∂Â±ãÁî∫„Éì„É´

name: Nintendo Museum
reviews: This is a must‚Äëvisit spot in the Kansai area. We‚Äôd been meaning to visit the museum for over a year, and we were lucky to get tickets. The museum was fairly busy, so expect some waits for the popular games. The Hanafuda workshop was a fantastic family experience‚Äîour kids learned a lot about Hanafuda history and the seasons, and it made a great keepsake to display after the trip. Don‚Äôt forget to look for all the Pikmin. The staff are very helpful, and the entire venue is incredibly detailed.

We managed to get a 2-2:30pm entrance slot on a Thursday! Entrance was easy. They have storage lockers where you deposit a ¬•100 coin to get a key and then you scan your QR code for entrance. There are some spots for photos and there are staff at each spot to take your picture for you.

The shop had everything we wanted in stock other than one shirt in XL. Some items are limited to 2 per customer, like the blind box keychains of the console sounds and the mini consoles.

The exhibit on the second floor was extensive and we loved seeing the history of Nintendo and all of the games from our childhood. There was a really cool display on the wall that showed the evolution of some of the games from console to console. Pictures were not allowed on the 2nd floor.

The first floor interactive exhibit was really cool. Each activity you pick will take pictures and automatically upload them to your ticket page. The lines seemed long but moved quickly because each activity was pretty short.

We would definitely want to come again and spend more time exploring the exhibit!

A must visit place for Nintendo fans and gamer in general.  The exhibition floor itself is enough to pay a visit, experience the 40 years of nintendo history, a chance of glancing through game design and development, our beloved character iteration by iteration before the final version that we knew of.  Comsoles of good old days.  What a feeling.  The day we went was quite crowded, 3pm entry, so we do not have enough time to play all the games on the 1st floor, but that's totally ok.  Morning entry is way better with crowd.  Merch is all great for fans.  Highly recommended.

You know when you signed up for when you come to this place. If childhood and nostalgia is a place, it's this museum. This place is separated into 2 levels. The first level displays all the consoles Nintendo ever created, as well as the game. It is displayed in a circle which makes it very nice to walk and enjoy your favourite console's history and games. The bottom floor is more interactive and has N74. super Nintendo which you can play using the card you're given. There are also other games where you use giant controller or your body to play. Those have a longer queue then the normal console games.
I think the only downside is the booking of tickets. It is a pain to book and sells out fast, so do try your luck before your trip as I managed to get tickets just 1 week before my trip.
Oh and photography is not allowed at the top floor where the displays are.

‚ÄãAs a lifelong Nintendo fan, visiting the Nintendo Museum was nothing short of a dream come true‚Äîit‚Äôs a true pilgrimage site.
‚ÄãEntry & Booking:
The process is a bit of a challenge as you need to enter a lottery on their official website months in advance to secure tickets. It‚Äôs a bit troublesome, but let me tell you, it is absolutely worth the effort!
‚ÄãMuseum Layout:
The facility is well-organized and divided into three main areas: the Outdoor Photo Spots, the Restaurant, and the Main Building. Inside the Main Building, you‚Äôll find the 2nd-floor Exhibition Hall, the 1st-floor Interactive Play Area, the Shop, and the Workshop.
‚ÄãThe Experience:
‚ÄãExhibition Hall (2F): This was the highlight for me. It‚Äôs organized by different consoles and timelines, showcasing an incredible volume of rare collectibles and historical items. Even as a long-time fan, I was completely blown away by the depth of the collection. Seeing the evolution of my favorite series was a truly emotional experience; it brought back so many precious memories of playing these games over the years.
‚ÄãInteractive Area (1F): The interactive exhibits are incredibly creative, blending classic Nintendo charm with modern technology. I highly recommend visiting with friends, as many of the games are designed for two players and are a blast to play together.
‚ÄãService:
The staff members are exceptionally helpful. Their English is more than sufficient for basic communication, so international visitors don't need to worry at all.
‚ÄãTime Spent:
If you‚Äôre a true fan, you could easily spend an entire day here. I entered in the afternoon and stayed until they closed, and I still felt like I could have stayed longer!
‚ÄãFinal Verdict: Don't hesitate‚Äîif you get the chance to win the ticket lottery, just go. It's a beautiful tribute to the history of gaming.

name: Chureito Pagoda
reviews:
üìç Chureito Pagoda Êñ∞ÂÄâÂ±±ÊµÖÈñìÂÖ¨Âúí Âø†ÈúäÂ°î
@ Fujiyoshida, Yamanashi üáØüáµ

We visited Chureito Pagoda on 18 November 2025, one of the most iconic Fuji-view spots in Japan. Located within Arakurayama Sengen Park, the pagoda is part of the Chureito Memorial Tower (Âø†ÈúäÂ°î) built to honor the war victims of Fujiyoshida City.

The climb up the long staircase takes some effort, but the reward at the top is incredible. The viewing platform offers the classic postcard scene ‚Äî the red five-storied pagoda‚õ©Ô∏è, the city below, and Mount Fuji üóª standing beautifully in the background. During our visit, the area was decorated with red maple trees üçÅ, adding even more colour and depth to the scenery.

The park is well maintained with clean paths, and the fresh mountain air makes the walk enjoyable. The autumn colours around the pagoda created a warm and vibrant atmosphere, making this viewpoint even more memorable.

A must-visit landmark with stunning Fuji views, vibrant red maple trees, and the classic pagoda silhouette ‚Äî absolutely worth the climb. üóª‚õ©Ô∏èüçÅ‚ú®

We began our journey by taking the train from Kawaguchiko Station and alighted at Gekkouji Station. From there, it was about a 15 to 20-minute walk to the base of the hill leading up to the pagoda.

As we approached, we began our climb up the staircases. Along the way, we paused to admire and photograph the vibrant autumn leaves, which painted the trail in brilliant shades of red and gold.

Eventually, we reached the Chureito Pagoda. Although it was a cloudy day and Mount Fuji remained hidden, the experience was still breathtaking and serene.

I hate being around other tourists, but this was very much worth the hype. Soak in the whole experience, not just the basic photo op at the top. The crowds were slightly bothersome but manageable in the fall. Lots of stairs so prepare to be winded. So worth it though. You actually start seeing crazy views of Fuji on the stairs if you pause and turn around on your way up. The fall colors were absolutely stunning. Highly recommend watching sunset here. We stayed much longer than we initially allotted because we just couldn't stop looking at Fuji's majestic form. It got pretty cold once the sun set which was to be expected. The pagoda is beautiful but the massive uninterrupted scale of Fuji taking up the whole horizon was really the best part. There are staggered steps in front of the pagoda to mitigate the crowds but there are other winding paths on the sides that were totally empty. When we arrived at first it looked like there was a line (?) but only for the area right in front of the pagoda. It kinda dispersed 30 minutes before sunset.

In my opinion, this is the best viewpoint we went to. If you don't have much time in Fuji, skip the cable car and just do this.

After dark, the stairs are not lit at all so be careful of that. With nightfall the crowds dropped significantly and yet there were some small groups starting their ascent as we were leaving.

Photos from late November.

I had a good time regardless if I didn't get to see mt. fuji because of one cloud that didn't want to leave. Yes you should plan ahead and look at the weather for the day but we just went out on a limb and decided to go for it. Again overall we still had fun. We took a bus all the way there and a bus back. We didn't book any tour group. You can also take the train there but being able to book a bus and get assigned seats was better. Didn't have to worry about getting a seat. Be prepared to walk or climb a bunch of steps. Definitely got a leg workout that day. There are to paths, stairs and a slow gradual incline road to get up to the Pagoda. The stairs are more direct but more exhausting. Was still a beautiful sight to see.

We visited this place during the second week of October 2025. We had booked a Mount Fuji tour on Klook, the guide took us to Oshino Hakkai, Lawson station, Lake Kawaguchigo and this pagoda was our last stop near this area. Our guide said that it would take just 30 minutes to go upstairs for a healthy person. I managed to climb the first 50 steps but my leg started giving up. I even felt nauseous and sat in between for a while. Then I had a sudden rush of adrenaline and started analysing why am I here at Japan if I can‚Äôt even climb 500 stairs to goto a viewpoint. Then I slowly started again and took break between every 15/20 steps. My husband whom I had asked to go earlier had already reached the top and made a new friend from Mexico and was talking to him. He was delighted to see that I made it, I was over the moon because I never gave up. The view of Mount Fuji was incredible. On our way back we shared a lot of stories with the Mexican friend. Overall a wholesome experience.

name: Hakone Jinjya Heiwa-no-Torii
reviews:
Visiting Hakone Jinjya Heiwa-no-Torii on a weekday was one of the most peaceful experiences of my trip. There was no wait to enter, and the quiet setting made it easy to take in the beauty without distraction. The iconic red torii gate rising from the lake felt timeless ‚Äî a perfect blend of nature and tradition. The surrounding trees, soft breeze, and gentle ripples on the water created a calm that stayed with me long after I left. It‚Äôs not just a photo spot; it‚Äôs a place to pause and reflect. I didn‚Äôt need to buy tickets in advance, and everything felt accessible and welcoming.

The walk to the gate was smooth, and the area was well-maintained without being overly commercial. I appreciated how the site allowed for personal space and quiet moments, even with other visitors nearby. If you‚Äôre looking for a spiritual or scenic stop in Hakone, this is one of the most grounding places to visit. It‚Äôs ideal for solo travelers, couples, or anyone wanting to slow down and connect with the landscape. I‚Äôd recommend going early in the day to catch the soft light and avoid any weekend crowds.

üìç Hakone Jinjya Heiwa-no-Torii
ÁÆ±Ê†πÁ•ûÁ§æ Âπ≥Âíå„ÅÆÈ≥•Â±Ö @ Hakone, Japan üáØüáµ

A beautiful lakeside torii and one of Hakone‚Äôs most popular power spots. The red torii standing on the water creates a peaceful, spiritual atmosphere with stunning lake views. It‚Äôs also a very popular photo spot, so expect some queueing. The forest path leading in is calm and scenic.

A serene, iconic torii with powerful energy and a must-visit view in Hakone. ‚õ©Ô∏èüåø‚ú®

The Peace Torii at Lake Yamanaka was a really special stop.
You get an amazing view of Mount Fuji framed by the red torii gate, and the place has a calm atmosphere even when a few people are around.
We went in the morning, the light was perfect for photos, and the contrast between the lake, the torii, and Fuji in the back is just beautiful.
If you're exploring the Yamanakako area, this spot is a must for photos and a quick peaceful break.

A peaceful shrine nestled in the middle of the forest. The torii by the lakeside is very pretty and picturesque, though there was a long queue to take photos up close. We didn‚Äôt join the line since we were part of a tour group and had limited time. There are plenty of other torii and smaller shrines to explore around the area. The weather was cool and pleasant in November.

Torii Peace is a Japanese-inspired restaurant that typically focuses on providing a blend of traditional and modern dishes. It often stands out for its calm, serene atmosphere, reflecting the peacefulness and aesthetic of a traditional Japanese torii gate, which symbolizes transition or a gateway to a sacred space.

Here‚Äôs a general review breakdown based on the elements people commonly look for in such a restaurant:

1. Atmosphere
‚Ä¢	Ambience: From the name ‚ÄúTorii Peace,‚Äù you can expect a minimalist, tranquil setting. Many patrons appreciate the quiet elegance, with elements like soft lighting, wooden accents, and Zen-like decor.
‚Ä¢	Service: Service tends to be attentive but not intrusive, in keeping with the peaceful theme. Waitstaff usually have a calm, respectful demeanor.

2. Food Quality
‚Ä¢	Menu Variety: The menu may range from sushi and sashimi to izakaya-style dishes, hot pots, and noodle soups. Expect a focus on fresh, high-quality ingredients, especially fish and seasonal produce. There might be a variety of vegetarian and vegan options too.
‚Ä¢	Signature Dishes: Dishes like sushi rolls, teriyaki, and perhaps specialties like miso-glazed cod or grilled eel may stand out. Some places also offer unique fusion items that combine traditional flavors with a modern twist.
‚Ä¢	Presentation: Japanese cuisine is known for its artful presentation, and many reviews highlight how the dishes are thoughtfully presented, resembling a work of art.

3. Flavor
‚Ä¢	The food usually balances delicate and bold flavors. You can expect umami-rich broths, fresh seafood, and careful seasoning with ingredients like miso, soy sauce, sesame, and pickled vegetables.

4. Drinks and Beverages
‚Ä¢	Many places like Torii Peace will offer a selection of sake, Japanese whiskey, and possibly craft cocktails inspired by traditional Japanese flavors (e.g., matcha, yuzu, or umeshu).
‚Ä¢	Tea selection: You can often find a curated selection of Japanese teas, from matcha to sencha, served with attention to detail.

5. Value
‚Ä¢	Prices can vary, but given the quality and experience, many consider it worth the price. Some might find the dining experience a bit on the pricier side, especially if you‚Äôre opting for high-end sushi or premium sake.

6. Overall Experience
‚Ä¢	Customers often describe dining at Torii Peace as a holistic experience, where the flavors, the environment, and the service work together to create a peaceful and enjoyable outing. Whether it‚Äôs a casual lunch or a special dinner, it‚Äôs the kind of place where you go to unwind and savor the moment.
address: 80-1 Motohakone, Hakone, Ashigarashimo District, Kanagawa 250-0522, Japan

name: Dekasan
reviews:
Came at 1030 during Christmas, was first in line. However, a line was forming rapidly to about 5-6 party by the time it was time to open. There's two line, one to dine in and one to takeout, the friendly staff ushered and reordered the queue that I had formed previously 15 mins before 11. Restaurant seats 10, about 3 party per wave. Food came around 1115, and we were the first to be served.

While the restaurant is renowned for its beef sandwich, I personally preferred the Egg sandwich. It was outrageously oversized, creamy, fluffy, the bread toasted with butter, it also contained flavourful egg white (sunny side up style) to break the monotony, good job! The beef sandwich comes in 200/400g, and it's always comes in 2 separate sandwiches regardless of the meat portion size. The beef slices were aromatic, seasoned very well with pepper, my eyes were opened. However the beef was chewy, hence I preferred the Egg mayo. I also tried the chicken nanban sandwich and enjoyed the tomato, mayo, and lettuce.

When we left around 1140, there's about 4 other party waiting outside. I'll come back to takeout the egg sandwich :-)

Absolutely incredible. Best sandwich I‚Äôve ever had! I got there early so there wasn‚Äôt much of a wait. The place does takeaway as well as dine in. I‚Äôm 100% certain that any sandwich you choose is going to taste amazing. They are known for their egg sandoichi which was obviously oishii and I also had the steak. But my favourite was the ham and cheese! I don‚Äôt think you will find any better. Meccha Oishii!!

Shop opens at 11 but we already lined up (dine-in line) at around 10:30 to be the 3rd customers to get in. Staff were very friendly and accommodating. The place is very small (I think they can only have ~10 people dining in inside) that the take-out line was also a good option for some who didn't mind eating elsewhere.

To be honest, I think people come here for the steak sandwich but the highlight for us was the tamago sandwich!! The bread was very soft and tasty that I kept talking about it after. The steak was a bit chewy and the but was still tasty nonetheless. The chicken with egg was also good but I'd really keep going back for the tamago sandwich :)

Didn't know about the instagram fame of this place just saw the line up and decided to check it out the next day. Came early to try and beat the line but still had to wait over an hour. Especially for dine in, there is limited space inside so be prepared for hour long wait, much quicker to do take away.

Had the egg salad, steak and potato sandwiches.

Egg salad was okay, they had a large piece of cooked egg white meringue around the outside to keep the egg salad from spilling out which was salty. From the color of the egg salad I was expecting something more but the bright orange color is them spreading egg yolk on the cut. The egg salad on the inside is nice and creamy but no different from any conbini eggsalad.

Steak sandwich was really strangely sweet and was the only sandwich we didn't finish. The meat was certainly rare in parts and well cooked in others but all of the pieces were extremely chewy. It's a very chewy almost dessert like sandwich.

Potato salad was nice, creamy, good mayo but that's all it is. They also sprinkled the top with black pepper which I like in my potato salad but having it as a topping just made me sneeze and lead to bites with too much pepper.

All of this pales in comparison to the state of their kitchen, it looks like they never clean the kitchen area, pans looked crusty and the walls near the stove was covered in old burnt grease and they were storing the fried sandwich fillings like the chicken right next to it. I have been nothing but surprised at how clean all the restaurants and shops have been in japan and this was a disgusting slap in the face.

The one thing this shop excels at is clearly marketing but has no substance to back it up. I hope tourists see this review and decide to spend their money at many of the other shops around that serve quality food for cheaper and from cleaner kitchens.

I was very disappointed by all the hype and the TikTok and Instagram posts. We ordered the egg sandwich, the small steak sandwich, and the Namba chicken sando. The only one that was okay was the egg sando. The Namba chicken sando was cold and just average. The steak sando was the worst‚Äîthe beef didn‚Äôt taste like beef at all and was extremely chewy. It also had an unpleasant seasoned flavor that ruined it.

I really don‚Äôt understand the hype. In my opinion, it wasn‚Äôt good at all.

Thank goodness we didn‚Äôt have to wait long since we went early. By the time we left, there was a long line, and I honestly felt bad for those people.

name: Cois Espresso Club Shinjuku Gyoemmae
reviews:
Their Basque Br√ªl√©e Cheesecake is to die for!! Super soft & smooth texture on the inner portion of the cake, and more dense towards the edges, beautiful gastronomical experience lol! With that richness, I had to get an americano. Even their coffee tasted interesting! Bitter with a little bit of acidity.

The space is intimate & they have outdoor seating. They play jazz music inside, free WiFi, toilet, and quick service! No card & cash only. Would come back to try their other coffees & espressos!

We had a late dessert here as we wanted to try the brulee cheesecake. We just shared one and my friend ordered an americano.

They said to order one drink per person but I already said my friend ordered one and I'm ordering a cheesecake slice.

The place is cozy but quite cramped. It has a very chill vibe and has outdoor seating too.

The brulee cheesecake was creamy and not too sweet. It's best partnered with black coffee or plain tea, not the sweet coffee drinks.

Cois Espresso Club Shinjuku Gyoemmae has moved from its original location, which is a bit of a shame because I actually preferred the old spot. It was smaller but had that cozy, slightly crowded charm that made it special. The new place still has a nice vibe though. The cheesecake is delicious, and when it comes to coffee, I think the fancy or signature drinks stand out more than the basic ones. Overall, still a lovely caf√© worth visiting if you are in the area.
The best expresso experience we‚Äôve had in Tokyo thus far. The cr√®me br√ªl√©e cheesecake was phenomenal. Worth the wait. The ladies inside were very polite and helped with seating.

Wow! That was such an amazing coffee experience
I‚Äôm always looking for fusion in restaurants, something new and exciting, and I finally found it here
Each coffee flavor is extraordinary, I took the other day the tiramisu espresso which was FANTASTIC and the br√ªl√©e espress and cheesecake where sooo good
Today I took the Rocher, the chocolate berry and the cheese and each one was outstanding!
The service was amazing and they even got us the br√ªl√©e cheesecake on the house!
We will take something to go and definitely come back tomorrow
address: Ê∞∏‰∫ï„Éì„É´ 1Èöé, 1-ch≈çme-6-11 Shinjuku, Shinjuku City, Tokyo 160-0022, Japan

name: Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden
reviews:
The gardens were beautiful the time we went in November. All the autumn colours were just so vibrant it felt kind of like a little movie üé•

There's so much diversity in everything that's on offer the gardens from simple plans and trees to water fixtures and architecture. It's a very warm and welcoming place very cheap to get into to as welll.

I proposed to my partner now at this garden and I couldn't think of a better spot within Tokyo üóº

Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is a stunning and serene oasis in the heart of Tokyo. The beautifully landscaped gardens combine traditional Japanese, English, and French styles, offering a peaceful escape from the city‚Äôs hustle and bustle. Walking through the winding paths, I was captivated by the perfectly maintained lawns, seasonal flowers, and tranquil ponds. The cherry blossoms were particularly breathtaking, creating a magical atmosphere that made my visit truly unforgettable. It‚Äôs an ideal place to relax, take photos, and enjoy nature, all while feeling completely immersed in a calm and refreshing environment.

I visited late July 2025. Even though it was one of the pricier parks I visited in Japan at 500 yen, I went to Shinjuku Gyoen twice and absolutely loved it. The park is very large, so you can easily spend a long time walking around and exploring the many ponds. You can also go inside the Taiwan Pavilion and learn about its history. I really loved the nature and the beautifully designed landscape, with scenic paths and bridges crossing the ponds. Along the way, you can see turtles, birds, and fish. There is also an area with many rosebushes. The park has toilet facilities and caf√©s, which makes it comfortable to spend several hours there.

This place is absolutely stunning in autumn. initially set aside 1 hour to visit the garden but ended up spending close to 3 hours here. Park opens at 9am (in Nov) so don‚Äôt go too early. also recommend to watch the historical video on how the garden started to appreciate it better - 10/10 would recommend to take a breather from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. come early as it tends to get crowded around noon.

A beautiful and peaceful escape in the middle of Tokyo. Shinjuku Gyoen is incredibly clean, spacious, and well-maintained. The park has lovely Japanese gardens, open lawns, and a stunning greenhouse. Perfect for relaxing walks, picnics, and photography.
I went during ___ (spring/autumn/etc.), and the scenery was breathtaking ‚Äî especially the cherry blossoms!
Very easy to access from Shinjuku-Gyoenmae Station. Highly recommended if you want to enjoy nature in the city.

name: Lake Kawaguchi
reviews: Absolutely the most scenic bike ride I have ever done. Even though it‚Äôs not the cherry blossom or snow-capped season, the view of Fuji mountain is quite spectacular from every angle along this lake.

One of the most serene lakes i have ever seen in my life. I visited in autumn and the weather was slightly cold but very lovely.

It is about an hour and 30 minutes drive from tokyo

On a clear day you can get scenic shots of mount Fuji

The lake is next to oishi park which I also recommend visiting, there you will find souvenir shops and cafes

The best place! We got engaged here! It‚Äôs very walkable and bikeable, with lots of spots to take pictures of Mt. Fuji. Very nature vibes and super clean. They have boats you can ride on the lake on warmer days.

Lake Kawaguchiko is a truly peaceful and breathtaking destination, offering one of the most beautiful views of Mount Fuji. The scenery feels calm and refreshing, with the lake, mountains, and changing seasons creating a perfect natural balance.

Walking along the lakeside is relaxing, and every angle feels like a postcard ‚Äî especially on clear days when Mount Fuji reflects on the water. The area is quiet yet charming, with cozy caf√©s, small shops, and scenic spots that invite you to slow down and enjoy the moment.

Lake Kawaguchiko is more than just a sightseeing spot; it‚Äôs a place to unwind, reconnect with nature, and appreciate the simple beauty of Japan. A truly memorable destination that leaves you feeling peaceful and inspired. üå∏üóª

Lake Kawaguchi is a stunning, natural lake surrounded by mountains and hills. The water was very pristine. There is a track and road around the entire lake which you can use for walking. It is also popular for people to hire bicycles to ride around. I found the area to be calming. Mt Fuji can also be viewed from here if weather conditions are good.
address: Lake Kawaguchi, Fujikawaguchiko, Minamitsuru District, Yamanashi, Japan

name: Masahiko Ozumi Paris Êú¨Â∫ó
reviews:
We bought 2 little cakes (rose and mont blanc) and 1 pumpkin tarte. They were delicious! I would have liked more of a rose flavor but it was good. It's also an awesome crochet design and the texture is fun. I would recommend going out of the way to try these.

I only speak English but I do know please and thank you in Japanese and that was enough to get by and I was treated normally.  They asked how long our travel was to get to where we can eat them and based on that they will put ice pack(s) in the packaging. As long as you are prepared to take them to go and eat somewhere else it is great. It was a 20-25 min commute back to our hotel and it worked out great.

This desserts are amazing. They are perfect, not too sweet and all the ingredients mix perfectly without covering the other flavours. I‚Äôm not a big fun of super sugary food, so this was really good. We will definitely come back to try more üòç
This place is so cute!  The pumpkin pillow was tasty and everyone enjoyed a treat. Downside is no seating but this place is elegant and feels fancy.

We came because the cakes looked adorable and perfect for photos. We were not expecting them to taste as delicious as they did. Both cakes we got were the right amount of sweet, with complex flavors, and the perfect size for one person. They were so flavorful and I can‚Äôt wait to go back and try other flavors!

It's a take away place in a quiet neighborhood of Osaka. Cakes and the ambience is quite aesthetic. The staff is polite and helpful. We were here to try their Instagram famous crochet cake. They change the flavours ever so often so we ended up picking the pumpkin flavoured cake and to our surprise it tasted amazing. We went here late in the evening but we're lucky enough to get our hands on it. After speaking to the staff we realised the best time to visit is earlier in the morning as the best ones get sold out fast and there is a big rush in the later hours.
address: Japan, „Äí540-0021 Osaka, Chuo Ward, ≈åted≈çri, 2-ch≈çme‚àí4‚àíÔºò assess Â§ßÊâãÈÄö„Éì„É´1Èöé

name: Amagiso
reviews: This was a day use only. This place was so incredible, easy access by bus. Stop at odaru Iriguchi. 1000 yen to get in, the robe is 500 yen. Water was 96-107 degrees. Views were incredible. Must do for sure. Watch for the bus schedule so you come out on time. The bus runs every 55 min after 4 pm.

This was my first time experiencing a beautiful outdoor onsen with an amazing view right in front ‚Äî a large waterfall.

On the left side, there‚Äôs also a swimming pool.

The pool and onsen were both great, and there weren‚Äôt many people either. When we visited, it was just the two of us in both the onsen and the pool.

The place is really beautiful. You can check in for an overnight stay, or if you just want to access the onsen and pool, that‚Äôs also possible. The rental swimwear is already included in the fee.

The hotel is unavailable so this is only talking about the baths. There are two types of baths: the single private bath that is in the cave along the stairs down to the waterfall, and the public bathing area that is next to Oh-daru (the waterfall).

The one private bath is in a cave and you actually have to walk past the entrance to get to the service desk. There is a locked door and it must be reserved, you get the key which must be returned in 30 minutes. There is no shower or toilet in the cave. There is no locker or changing area either but that's fine since the door is locked. The cave is actually quite dark which gives it a certain atmosphere. Recommended for couples.

The public bathing area is quite large and begins at the base of the waterfall and extends along the river. There are 6-7 baths of varying size and temperature, some of them outdoors, a single shower, a swimming pool, and small sheds used for changing. Because the area is public and outdoors, swimsuits are required. There are coin lockers at the entrance.

The price is 1000 yen per adult. Towels and swimsuits are not provided but available for rent for a fee. Notably, slippers are not available at all given the size of the public bathing area. Overall the public baths are quite scenic and outdoors mixed baths are extremely rare now so it's a great opportunity if you're a family and the private bath is unique and interesting, but the facilities are old and there are almost no amenities provided! Shower beforehand and bring your own swimsuits, towels, and pool slippers.

went as day use the place is butifule, several pools with diff temperature.
pools are clean , there are chaning rooms.
in short amazing.

We went there by april 29 for there "hotspring day only" . We didnt book rooms for the hotel of amagiso. Amagiso is famous for there open air public bath.

The price is very cheap including the perfect view of the falls and the nature while bathing on their hotspring.

‚úÖYou must wear a swimsuit or diving suit.

‚úÖTattoos are allowed as long as it's not that visible. You can just cover them with your long swimsuit

‚úÖthere's a large pool but open only during summer season

‚úÖYou need to walk down maybe about 10-15mins to reach the reception center. (It's just a small house)

‚úÖdo not bring too much stuff because they don't have that enough space or room.

‚úÖThey have comfort room.

Take note :

They do not have washing area to cleanse your body after bathing. So you do not need to bring any shampoo or soap. It is just literally like dip then get out.
address: 359 Nashimoto, Kawazu, Kamo District, Shizuoka 413-0501, Japan

name: Ine Fishing Village
reviews: We came here on a day trip booked via Klook. The village itself is peaceful, with houses built along the seaside. It‚Äôs nice to walk around and very quiet. You rarely see locals ‚Äî most of the people around were tourists like us, wandering through the area. It feels like a wonderful place to live

"Ine Fishing Village is a breathtakingly beautiful and peaceful place. I had a truly relaxing time admiring the crystal-clear water and the serene blue sky‚Äîeverything felt so calm. The only lively spot is near the pier where you can take a boat tour and feed the seagulls. The seagulls are quite bold and their beaks are a bit sharp, so be careful, but it's a fun experience! The traditional wooden houses (Funaya) lining the waterfront create a unique and stunning view. This is the perfect sanctuary if you're looking for tranquility. Highly recommended!"

Ine is a charming and picturesque town that offers a refreshing contrast to the bustling energy of major cities like Osaka and Kyoto. One of the most appealing aspects of Ine is how peaceful and quiet it feels, making it an ideal destination for travellers who want to slow down and enjoy a more relaxed pace. The town has a calm, laid-back atmosphere that allows visitors to truly appreciate its natural beauty and traditional surroundings without the crowds commonly found in larger tourist hubs.

As you explore Ine, you will find a small but pleasant selection of restaurants and caf√©s scattered around the town. These spots provide comfortable places to rest, enjoy a meal, or simply sit back with a drink while taking in the scenic views. While the dining options are not extensive, they are sufficient and add to the overall charm of the town rather than overwhelming it. The focus here is clearly on quality and atmosphere rather than variety.

Beyond dining, Ine is best enjoyed as a place to wander leisurely. The town is known for its beautiful waterfront scenery, traditional boathouses, and tranquil streets, making it perfect for walking and photography. One of the highlights of a visit is taking a boat tour, which offers a unique perspective of the town from the water and allows you to fully appreciate its distinctive character. Overall, Ine is a lovely destination for a peaceful day trip, ideal for those seeking quiet beauty rather than busy attractions.

Highly recommend visiting Ine Fishing Village. This style of fishing village is unique to Japan with the houses right on the water. If arriving via vehicle. There's a parking lot across from the Ine Junior high school "Inechugakko Inenomori Parking Lot", recommended to park there. It's free and only about 50 meters down to the water's edge. There's alot of traffic and if there's no parking available at the shoreline, you'll need to follow the lines of cars to the next lot. So best to park there, and beat the traffic.

From the viewpoint at the water's edge, there's a tourist information center across the street beside the paid parking lot.

Walking around Ine Fishing Village ‰ºäÊ†π„ÅÆËàüÂ±ã and visiting the Funaya no Sato Observation ËàüÂ±ãÁæ§Â±ïÊúõÊâÄ was a very nice experience. The viewpoint gives a wonderful scene of the blue bay, and the traditional boat houses lined up along the water look very charming. It‚Äôs amazing to see how the funaya houses are built right at the edge of the sea, showing a traditional lifestyle that is unique to Ine.

The contrast of the calm blue water and the wooden houses creates a beautiful and peaceful atmosphere. From the observation deck, the view feels like a postcard, and you can really appreciate the history and quiet charm of the village.

It‚Äôs a great place to take photos, enjoy the sea breeze, and simply relax while looking at the scenery. The walk through Ine and the viewpoint together make a memorable experience and a lovely moment by the sea. üåøüåä‚ú®
address: Hirata, Ine, Yoza District, Kyoto 626-0423, Japan

name: Kegon Waterfalls
reviews:
Kegon Waterfall, located in the scenic town of Nikko in Tochigi Prefecture, is one of Japan‚Äôs most famous natural attractions and is often regarded as one of the country‚Äôs top three waterfalls. Standing at an impressive height of about 97 meters, the waterfall is created by the outflow of Lake Chuzenji, which sits high in the mountains of the Nikko National Park. The water cascades dramatically down a towering cliff face, creating a powerful mist that fills the air and adds to its majestic atmosphere.
Visitors can enjoy two main viewpoints. The free upper observation deck provides a broad, panoramic view of the waterfall surrounded by lush greenery in summer and vibrant foliage in autumn. For a closer and more immersive experience, a paid elevator takes you down to the lower viewing platform, where the thunderous roar, cool mist, and sheer scale of the falls can truly be felt.
Kegon Waterfall changes dramatically with the seasons. Autumn brings brilliant reds and golds, winter transforms the falls into frozen pillars of ice, and spring offers a refreshing, clear display. Whether you're into photography, nature, or just sightseeing, Kegon Waterfall is a must-visit destination that captures the raw beauty of Japan‚Äôs landscapes.

Kegon Falls is an incredibly calming place‚Äîits powerful waterfall is truly mesmerizing. You can enjoy the view from the top, but if you‚Äôd like to experience it from below, there‚Äôs an elevator that takes you down about 100 floors (with a small ticket fee). The view from the bottom is absolutely beautiful.

There are a few eateries around Kegon Falls where you can grab a bite. About 200 meters away is Lake Chuzenji, where you can enjoy swan boating or take a lake cruise. The scenery around the lake is stunning and definitely worth visiting.

One of the most beautiful waterfalls I‚Äôve ever visited and probably the most beautiful I‚Äôve seen in Japan. I arrived in early November, a bit too late for the fall colors but still wondrous nonetheless. It‚Äôs relatively easy to access great viewing points and worth the effort to see if you‚Äôre in the area. Definitely check it out when in Nikko!

The scenery was stunning. I visited at the end of October, traveling by rented car. The autumn leaves were changing color, which was absolutely beautiful. To view the falls, you must purchase a ticket before descending by elevator. The Kegon waterfall vista from the base is simply superb. They also have a souvenir shop there. Be aware that these falls are located in the mountains, quite a distance from the Shinky≈ç Bridge, so you should plan your time carefully to arrive before sunset. üçÅüçÇüçÉ

Enjoyed the bus ride to Kegon Waterfalls.  The falls were impressive and was worth paying the small fee to travel down the lift to get a different view of the falls.  We walked through the small town for a bite to eat, checked out the pretty lake.  Its a good half day visit or you can explore further.

name: HOSHINOYA Kyoto
reviews:
It has been eight years since my last visit, and stepping back into Hoshinoya Kyoto felt like returning to a cherished memory.
‚ÄãWhile the staff has changed over the years, the profound sense of magic and tranquility‚Äîthe Hoshinoya Kyoto experience‚Äîremains absolutely intact. This ryokan possesses an unparalleled charm that distinguishes it from any other lodging.
‚ÄãThe awe-inspiring beauty of the surroundings, the meticulous attention to detail, and the serene, timeless atmosphere along the River truly define this place.
‚ÄãIf my travels ever bring me back to Kyoto, there is no doubt that I will choose to stay here again. It is more than a hotel; it is an enduring masterpiece that continues to deliver a deeply moving and unforgettable experience.

I stayed at the Tsukihashi Maisonette at HOSHINOYA Kyoto, and everything about it was spectacular. It‚Äôs a true gateway from all the city buzz ‚Äî surrounded by a peaceful bamboo forest and overlooking the river.

What I loved:
‚Ä¢	The service was exceptional ‚Äî thoughtful, polite, and always delivered with a warm smile.
‚Ä¢	The location and setting are absolutely magical, tucked away in nature yet close to Arashiyama.
‚Ä¢	The 5-step facial skincare routine provided in the room was such a beautiful touch ‚Äî relaxing and luxurious.
‚Ä¢	The morning stretch session was refreshing and set the tone for the day perfectly.
‚Ä¢	The panoramic view from our Tsukihashi Maisonette room was breathtaking.
‚Ä¢	The room design itself was stunning ‚Äî antique Japanese style with authentic details and modern comfort, spread across two floors.

What could be improved:
‚Ä¢	The first floor includes a tatami room and bathroom. The tatami room had a very strong smell that I personally found uncomfortable, but the housekeeping staff were kind enough to spray and light incense to help.
‚Ä¢	The narrow stairs connecting the two floors can feel a bit inconvenient, especially when you need to go downstairs to use the bathroom at night. It would be great if the tatami room were replaced with an additional bedroom, as it would make the maisonette perfect for families or groups.
‚Ä¢	There‚Äôs no direct access to the rooms; guests must take the hotel‚Äôs boat each time to go in or out. While the boat ride is beautiful and unique, it can feel restrictive if you‚Äôre staying for several nights.

Overall, it‚Äôs a beautiful, serene, and luxurious escape ‚Äî perfect for one or two nights of tranquility. But for longer stays, the limited access and room layout might feel a bit less convenient. Still, an unforgettable Kyoto experience.

This is an outrageously beautiful and remote property. You take (book) a boat to get to and from the hotel, but they can pick you up in a car if it's after hours. This place leaves you feeling completely transported, and the staff are so attentive and gracious. Wonderful on site restaurant and a host of activities that you can book in advance, some free (i.e. morning stretch/riutal), others require payment (we did Matcha tea making on a boat ride that was so serene). Cannot recommend this hotel enough... it's on the pricier side, but worth it. Thank you Hoshinoya Kyoto team for such a memorable stay!

The views at HOSHINOYA Kyoto were spectacular. I stayed here for a nice relaxing end to my trip in Japan and it really delivered on that. The boat to/from the hotel was fun. However, for the cost you pay to stay there, I felt it was pretty lacking overall.

THE ROOM:
The bed was not comfortable at all. It had a super hard mattress and two terrible pillows that could combine to make a somewhat OK one. Views from the bedroom were really nice though - you could see the river and it was very peaceful.

Other than that, there wasn't a ton there. It was a pretty standard room with a nice (albeit dark) bathroom.

AMENITIES:
There wasn't a ton here. I ended up spending quite a bit of time in the lounge because there wasn't much else to do if you were at the hotel itself.

In the lounge area, they had a few seats outside that overlooked the river. It was great for bird watching. The general refreshments were OK - drinks were hot tea, cold brewed green tea, a Nespresso machine and rice crackers.

FOOD/DRINKS:
Breakfast is served in your room and is a hot pot with some side dishes. It overall tasted nice.

Dinner is served in a separate building and typically goes for 2 hours (it did really drag on at the end each night). The food was overall quite nice - there are a good variety of dishes which was fun. I have a dairy allergy, and they were great at making swaps that didn't feel like I was missing out on anything.

I give it a 3.5.

This was the hotel I was most looking forward to staying on my trip to Japan. Unfortunately it was very underwhelming and for the price, I would not stay here again. Like others have mentioned, the rooms are dark and even though they face the river, our room is obstructed by the window trimmings. I think tje interiors could definitely use a refresh. In addition, there was a mildewy smell in our hallway and room that was unpleasant. The dinner on site was not very good and I didn‚Äôt eat most of the courses. The highs were the service - everyone was very friendly and helpful - and the morning stretching class.
address: 11-2 Arashiyama Genrokuzanch≈ç, Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto, 616-0007, Japan

name: Oide Park
reviews:
Oide Park is a peaceful and picturesque park that offers one of the most beautiful views in Hakuba. With a charming bridge, flowing river, and the Japanese Alps in the background, the scenery feels timeless and postcard-perfect.

The park is quiet and relaxing, ideal for a gentle walk, photography, or simply enjoying nature. Each season brings a different kind of beauty, from fresh greenery to snowy mountain views.

Oide Park is a wonderful place to slow down and appreciate Hakuba‚Äôs natural charm. Simple, serene, and truly memorable. üåøüèîÔ∏è

Such a peaceful spot surrounded by nature ‚Äî perfect for a relaxing evening walk. The view of the mountains and river is beautiful, especially during sunset. A great place to unwind and enjoy the calm side of Hakuba.

The river along the park üåøüèûÔ∏è is absolutely breathtaking with the scenery behind! üíô
There‚Äôs also a hidden spot if you walk a bit up the hill.

The only downside ‚Äî parking‚Äôs a bit small.

Relaxing in summer!

Come early, when i arrive at 7 am, no one here! So i enjoy my calm, relax and good vibes!

Please go up! Just 2 minutes walking and you will see a good view! Mix of snow mountain, river and green tree!!

Today still have sakura but a little bit and after heavy rain them will be less more.
But if you're want to walking and relax this place is very beautiful.
address: Hokujo, Hakuba, Kitaazumi District, Nagano 399-9301, Japan

name: Koya Design
reviews:
Garden Set arrived by delivery and was installed.
An oily spot was discovered on the umbrella. Contacted Customer service.
A replacement part was arrived and installed within days.
Great response and excellent service!!

We visited three times and then as the saying goes in Hebrew: ◊§◊¢◊ù ◊©◊ú◊ô◊©◊ô◊™ ◊í◊ú◊ô◊ì◊î a model that we really liked arrived. Noam was super nice and explained about the modular sofa that we could fit as we want. Thank you and for sure we will come back. The furniture were extremely easy to put together. Not like the Swedish company do it yourself until you want to smash the furniture in pieces üòù.
Big variety of gardens tables, chairs and more. Great design and good service.
Good prices, fantastic products and welcoming staff
Finally well designed Outdoor Furniture Design  Center...

name: American Village
reviews: Such a cool step back in time! The historical reenactments and period costumes really brought everything to life. There are so many buildings to explore and well laid out schedules. My absolute favorite was the apothecary demonstration‚Äîso fascinating to see how medicine was once practiced. The grounds are gorgeous. I do wish we had gotten there earlier‚Äîwe ended up missing a few of the reenactments.

We attended the Homeschool Day and my family and I LOVED IT! We're all history nuts and we had a wonderful time! It was beautiful, historical, and everyone was friendly. We didn't get to finish all of the events due to prior engagements, but we WILL be back! And bring others with us!

My friends and I attended the first,  because of the brave  5k today. What a beautifully campus with over 20 structures a pond a bridge and so much history.  The buildings are so beautiful and the grounds are kept up to perfection. What an important part of history.
Really fun and educational place with lots of things to do. Everyone was very nice. Went for fourth of July and got to watch a reenactment.

This is a cool place. They have several buildings that are replicas of the real buildings with exhibits in some of them. They have a new exhibit which I think requires an age limit as it's had a lot of audio-visual talking aspects and children under 12 are going to get bored very easy as a lot of them did on the tour, I was part of it, and it was hard to hear the lady who was leading the tour. But I do recommend seeing the exhibit and the buildings its pretty cool. They are adding to the area Im not sure what they are adding as I didnt ask as I didnt know who to ask. There are bathrooms in several areas on the property and parking.

name: Arashiyama Park Nakanoshima Area
reviews:
Togetsukyo Bridge ‚Äì Arashiyama, Kyoto

- Location: Arashiyama district, western Kyoto, Japan.
- Name meaning: ‚ÄúTogetsukyo‚Äù translates to Moon Crossing Bridge, inspired by an emperor‚Äôs remark that the moon seemed to move across the bridge.
- History: Originally built during the Heian period (794‚Äì1185), the current structure dates back to the 1930s, blending traditional wooden design with modern reinforcement.
- Highlights:
- The bridge spans the Katsura River, offering panoramic views of the surrounding mountains.
- It is a symbol of Arashiyama, often featured in paintings, films, and postcards.
- Particularly famous during spring (cherry blossoms) and autumn (red maple leaves) when the scenery is breathtaking.
- Activities for visitors:
- Walk across the bridge to enjoy the seasonal landscapes.
- Take photos of the river, mountains, and traditional townscape.
- Combine the visit with nearby attractions such as the Arashiyama Bamboo Grove and Tenryu-ji Temple.

22nd November 2025
Part 1
Saturday, the first day of the 3-day weekend.
After weeks of waiting and checking the Kyoto Autumn calendar, I am finally here- Arashiyama!!!
After exiting the station, I was greeted by lush green and combinations of vivid red, orange and yellow which blew me away. Magnificent mountains contrasting the bright blue sky lined with white clouds.
Continue with next part ! See if you can find it !

Beautiful park with nice views on the river
You can go early if you want to beat the crowds and have a more serene experience but most shops open after 8 am

Still very nice place to just sit down and enjoy the weather and view üòç

Great area, great views. Getting there early helps beat the hundreds of people that will be visiting, however most things do not open until late morning. Great views, great weather(September), I was in Kyoto for about 2 days on a 2 week trip in Japan and wish I could have been there majority of the trip!

Park is very wide and by the river, pretty relaxing. It is near the train station so it does get crowded.

Visited on 2nd Apr, 5:30pm, and sakura was still 60% bloomed only. Do come back when it‚Äôs full bloom.

name: Takamine Onsen hot spring
reviews:
Hideo Goto, the owner of Takamine Onsen waved us off as we departed, his love for the environment, the hot spring, his drive to educate his guests and in fact his attitude to life is inspiring. After a gas fire in 1975, he gradually rebuilt the lodge without electricity, water and with the restriction of only being able to work in the summer months. He rebuilt it strong, with triple glazed windows and wood in preference to concrete. Accommodation is traditional, with futon and cushions on tatami, there are no chairs, beds or TVs in the rooms. There are many communal areas with seating though and Goto happily shares his knowledge,  delivering daily talks about the birds, the stars and the health benefits of the spring water. The highlight of course is the open air bath admist the Takamine alps. The Japanese do not hesitate to get totally naked on mountain tops in minus degree temperatures and why not, the experience is exhilarating: excruciatingly freezing, to exquisitely warm and then  breathtakingly visual. The outdoor bath is open to guests between 7am and 5pm. The correct protocol is to collect a basket in the open air bath waiting area. Red for ladies and blue for men, the baths are segregated, if there are no baskets - wait. After leaving the waiting area, there are outdoor slippers to change into. Wet your body by pouring a bucket of water, scooped from the bath before entering. At least look like you are having a quick wash before entering. The lady in the bath asked if she could talk to me. It was her third visit to the hot spring, mine too, there are a lot of repeat visitors. Takamine Onsen is one 150 hot springs that have been selected as members of the preservation of hot springs society, and there is stamp booklet to try and collect ten stamps within three years, to earn a free stay from any of the 150 hot springs, none of which will disappoint.
My previous visit to Takamine Onsen was in autumn, the highlight of that visit was joining the 4-hour guided tour to Ikenodaira Wetlands, a pond within a volcanic crater. There are many well marked trails from the lodge, gum boots and snow shoes are provided and the ski slopes are within easy reach.

Even if venturing outside is too daunting, there are four indoor baths, two each for men and women, which are brimming with magnesium, calcium and natrium/sodium.  Goto-san encourages guests to drink the spring-water which is purported to cure constipation, skin conditions and diabetes. The bird watching area is a great spot to learn the names of the Alpine birds and wildlife.

I only went to use the bath. It is small but it's one of the best ones I've been to. Perfect temperature and between baths you can rest with a cold drinks in a seating area where they have a squirrel feeder right outside the window. Or you can chill in front of the fireplace.

„ÄêÈõ≤„Å´Èö†„Çå„ÅüÁµ∂ÊôØ„ÄÅÂøÉ„Å´ÊÆã„ÇãÁÅØ„Çä„Äë

At 2000 meters above sea level, Takamine Onsen Lamp no Yado feels like a hidden retreat floating in the clouds. Even on a gray, misty weekend, the place was full‚Äîproof that it has earned its reputation.

The common spaces carry a rustic, outdoorsy charm, while the guest rooms feel fresh and well maintained, clearly renewed in recent years. The onsen was the star: silky, milky-white water with that unmistakable mineral scent, hot enough to soothe yet cool enough to linger. Although the clouds kept the mountain panorama hidden, you could sense how spectacular the view would be on a clear day.

Dinner was homely and satisfying, the highlight a pork-and-apple miso grill prepared right at the table‚Äîsweet, savory, and deeply comforting. When stargazing was rained out, the owner hosted a cozy slideshow of the surrounding seasons, a gesture that made the evening feel intimate and personal.

If there was a flaw, it was in sleep: the futons were so thin that comfort was elusive. Breakfast, too, was on the plain side. Yet with its genuine hospitality, healing baths, and the promise of unforgettable vistas, I left already wanting to return‚Äîthis time to see the stars and walk the trails.

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ (4/5)

„ÄêFeatures„Äë
‚ô®Ô∏è Onsen: Milky-white water, outdoor and indoor baths, excellent quality
üõèÔ∏è Room: Clean, well-maintained, renewed in recent years
üõå Sleep: Futons thin and less comfortable
üçΩÔ∏è Dining: Dinner highlight‚Äîpork with sliced apples in miso, cooked at the table
ü•¢ Breakfast: Simple, somewhat plain
üôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Staff: Warm, thoughtful, photo slideshow when stargazing was canceled
üåÑ View: Hidden by clouds, but stunning on a clear day
üéê Ambience: Outdoorsy common areas, cozy atmosphere
üèîÔ∏è Location: 2000 meters elevation, ideal for hiking (weather permitting)
üîô Would I visit again? üíìDefinitely

This simple mountain lodge stands on the Takamine Plateau at an altitude of 2000m. Hot spring lovers will love the open-air bath, which is synonymous with the lodge, where you can enjoy the milky white hot spring water and the dynamic mountain scenery. They also hold events where you can get in touch with nature, such as trekking for beginners and stargazing events.

The room price might seem high, but staying in this hotel is totally worth it! I enjoyed staying at the outside onsen, the inside one (there is a small and a big one inside) were also nice to relax. It was really nice to talk to everyone while having a bath. The price also included dinner and breakfast. The highlight was the view from outside onsen and the star watching after dinner! We did not have enough time to book a trekking tour or to go hiking, but I saw that you can rent a lot of equipment for free! The staff did not speak English, so communication was a little complicated, bit worked out in the end. The hotel is very close to a ski place, which is why some routes were blocked and we had troubles finding the hotel. Gladly we stopped at a different hotel, they helped to call and we were kindly picked up from the hotel bus. I highly recommend taking a room with mountain view, it was stunning to wake up here!

name: Amami ≈åshima
reviews: Pristine beaches, calm and quiet nature, friendly people, great food--it's all you can get on a holiday.

Beautiful and quiet island. Locals are very friendly
Love the place‚ù§Ô∏è
I want to go there again.

Great Place. Soo much peaceful. Amazing on Summers. Beach isnt very clean. I confirmed from locals the reason they mentioned that all this garbage is coming from Korea and China mostly. And yes you will find a lot of plastic bottles with Chinese written on it.
Public transportation isn't very common so better to rent a car. It's not very expensive. Food is amazing specially sea food.
Be careful in night there's Snakes(viper) which dangerous. We found a lot of dead snakes on beach. Read on the Wikipedia and found out that they have affection for land so they visit Japan and find a mate here on the land.
One of the best islands for a nice beach vacation. Lots of things to do and great restaurants all over.

name: Karov Theatre
reviews:
An fringe theater.
We saw the play: "Who murdered Alma?" Based on an Agatha Christie book.
The place is very intimate. The crowd was at most 50 ppl.
That gave a very nice atmosphere.

The olay was nice, but had some issues.
The level of performance was inconsistent.
The video segments were redundant, and there was a black square in the middle that obscured some of the video.
It would have been better to remove ut altogether, and focus on the actors performance.
The AC was set to high, that cause the audience to be more tired ( given how cold it was outside) and to lose focus.

The level of volume was inconsistent, and it wa sometimes too high or too low.

The play flow was not smooth enough.

Some suggestions:
1. At the beginning, the host should introduce the actors or to announce the start of the play.

2. At the end, there should be an "end play" musical note. I was confusing.

3. Eventually, the set of events that led to the death of Alma should more emphasized

4. At the end, a few words and announcement of the names of the actors would greatly improve the experience

5. Before the play started, the audience had time to stay at the reception area.
It would have been great if the organizers would have setup a spot to sell coffe, some pastries, soft drinks etc.
While it is nice that it is open to all, both the audience and the theater would benefit from a more professional solution.

Overall, a unique and recommended experience.

Intimate place.bring the theatre for all people. Good seen, at low price. Small and comfortable. The only drawback its location inside the central station, which is not so  freindly place, especially at night.
The very best theater in Tel Aviv, dealing honestly with problems of our modern life, free of ideology.  It was my second visit and I 'll be back üíõ.
nah man it don't really do it fo me dat actin shi
Not a good fun of theater but it was fun.
address: Tel Giborim St 5, Tel Aviv-Yafo, Israel

name: Shirakawa-go
reviews:
Just a stunning place we spent a wonderful day in Shirakawa-go and were lucky enough to have a warm-ish, sunny winter day, which made the experience even better. Some of us walked up to the observation area, but there‚Äôs also a shuttle you can take for just a few yen (cash only), which is a great option especially with the icy conditions.
There was quite a bit of black ice around and it was slippery in places, so sensible footwear is definitely recommended (though we did see some very brave souls in heeled boots!). The views are stunning and the houses look straight out of a fairytale absolutely beautiful and very photogenic.

We had a few travel options and chose to take the bus from Kanazawa there and back. For us, this was by far the easiest option comfortable, straightforward, and cost-effective compared to piecing together trains, buses, and walking.

The bus takes you straight into the village and back again, and at around $50‚Äì$60 return, it was well worth it in our opinion.

We found a small local spot serving udon soup, which was delicious and incredible value. We also visited the onsen, and it was completely empty either our timing was perfect or we were just very lucky, but it made for such a peaceful experience but they only take cash.

One tip: bring cash. Not all ATMs accept foreign cards, and one we tried wasn‚Äôt working, so we had to walk to the post office ATM instead. Overall, a magical place and well worth the visit.

Second tip: if travelling by bus then yes beat to book tickets (even a few days) in advance.

Rides üöåüöåüöåüöå

Just 50 mins bus from Takayama. Yes - save yourself the hassle of driving in snow. Day trip or overnight at onsen, both works. Beauty - pics speaks all. Once will do. Lovely touristy shops too for hot sake or snacks and collectibles. indeed a beau. Worth the time as 50 mins trip to spend couple of hours in such a scenic and comfortable place. Can do it

Shirakawago was truly a once-in-a-lifetime experience for our family. We were incredibly lucky to witness snowfall on December 4th, turning the entire village into a real-life winter fairy tale. The traditional gassho-zukuri houses covered in fresh snow were absolutely breathtaking.

Visiting with my wife and kids made the moment even more special. The atmosphere felt peaceful, magical, and unforgettable‚Äîespecially since this was a rare early snowfall. A perfect mix of winter charm, culture, and family memories that we will cherish forever. Highly recommended, especially if you‚Äôre lucky enough to catch it during snowfall.

This is definitely a must-visit destination in the Gifu Prefecture of Japan.

We stayed at ANA Crown Plaza, Kanazawa, which was located about 3-min walk to the bus station where we waited for a coach to send us to Shiragawa-go. Thank goodness we booked our tickets prior as the coach was already full. We wanted to go a day later but there wasn‚Äôt any seats available.

It was barely an hour coach ride, the scenic journey was easy & pleasant. There were a lot of tourists from all over the world. We were immediately reminded to stay at the same place for our pick up coach upon reaching. Not necessary to buy any more entry tickets‚Ä¶we gotten an English map & walked along the paths, just looking out for oncoming villages‚Äô cars or goods trucks.

Sorry for I have not posted my review much earlier. So these pictures were taken before the snow hit the area, we preferred the super cool season, but we wanted to still see every detail of the heritage houses & compound!

It was a beautiful, clean & well kept area. The old houses were well maintained. We loved how they were weaved & heaped together with wooded planks/straws & many other materials. Amazingly they could withstand the changing but drastic weathers. There were a few eateries, cafes, a supermarket & some souvenir shops. We bought a few boxes of chocolates & cheese cakes. Wind was pretty strong snd by the end of our walk, the drizzle was already making us feeling so cold. Heat packs were pasted all around our pockets to keep us warm. Umbrellas were needed. The drop off & pick up holding area was rather small & crowded with people waiting for coaches. As it was cold outside, many tourists rushed here to take shelter from the drizzle first. It was so so packed! Do check the weather forecasts before visiting this place.

I would highly recommend that you stroll up the little hill on the higher ground to take a bird‚Äôs eye view of the village. It was breathtakingly beautiful. There were cyclists riding uphill, what a daunting task to me. We were already panting halfway up!

It took us about 3 hours plus to complete our stroll around the entire compound. We had 50min spare time before our coach arrived. We walked to the other end where a small cafe stood quietly. The old couple were veteran owners of good coffee brewers. They served aromatic hot coffee, hot chocolate drinks & good cakes too. Again, definitely worth a visit to Shiragawa-go.

A beautiful and well kept village. Really let you have great experience how local stayed in the past. There is some snowfall a few days earlier so we still get to see some snow here and there although is melting. A beautiful and stunning location with a proper huge parking location design for tourist. In the village, it is not allow to drive unless you are folks that stayed or work there. A nice walk along the village with many small shops along the street selling souvenirs and small eats. We also climb up the slope to the mountain to have even better view of the village. Note that this is a highly touristy location and during peak time, it is really full of many buses of tourist dropped here in the morning. A day trip is sufficient imho. unless you want to experience the ryokan stay there.
address: Ogimachi, Shirakawa, Ono District, Gifu 501-5627, Japan

name: Tsubame Onsen
address: Tsubame Onsen, Sekiyama, Myoko, Niigata 949-2235, Japan

name: Shinsekai
reviews:
Shinsekai is a very lively and crowded area with a fun and energetic atmosphere. The streets are always busy, full of people, lights, signs, and shops. Walking around Shinsekai feels exciting, especially at night, because there is always something happening and many places to look at.

There are many small game shops and attractions in this area. Visitors can try different games and enjoy the playful environment. However, most of the games are shooting-style games, such as shooting guns or archery. At first, they look fun and easy, but after playing, many people feel that the games are designed to make players lose.

Some games use tricks or unfair rules, making it very hard to win prizes. Because of this, visitors often spend more money without getting good results. This can be disappointing, especially for tourists who are not familiar with these types of games.

Overall, Shinsekai is a fun and colorful place to visit and walk around. It is great for experiencing a lively local atmosphere. However, when playing games, visitors should be careful and not expect to win easily, as many games focus more on earning money than fair play.

STEP INTO A TIME MACHINE SET TO 'RETRO-FUTURISTIC OSAKA'

¬∑

VIBE CHECK
this neighborhood is a vibrant, slightly chaotic love letter to a bygone era. it feels like a carnival frozen in the best way, with colorful signage, old-school game halls, and the iconic tsutenkaku tower watching over it all. the energy is nostalgic and genuinely fun.

THE BACKSTORY
shinsekai, meaning "new world," was built in 1912 to showcase a futuristic vision. today, it stands as a wonderfully preserved old part of osaka city, a historic entertainment district that offers a raw, authentic slice of osaka's past.

FINAL VERDICT
come here to wander, eat legendary kushikatsu, and soak up a uniquely osaka atmosphere. it's less polished and more real, offering a delightful contrast to the city's modern hubs. a must-visit for culture and vibe enthusiasts.

¬∑

peep the images for your ref; they‚Äôre worth a thou.

make sure to ‚ù§Ô∏è!

Cool retro futuristic place with the iconic Tsutenkaku tower. Recommended to visit both in the day and night as the vibe of the place feels entirely different.

The area is relatively small, and filled with food and game stalls, most of them serving the local specialty- kushikatsu. Really love some of the 3D designs of the shop lots too.

Definitely a must visit here in Osaka.

Shinsekai feels like stepping into Osaka‚Äôs retro past in the coolest way. It‚Äôs colorful, slightly chaotic, and full of personality. You‚Äôll find bright neon signs, giant puffer fish lanterns, old-school arcades, and plenty of places to eat. It‚Äôs a fun area to just walk around, grab some snacks, take photos, and soak up that nostalgic ‚Äúold Osaka‚Äù vibe.

It can get touristy and crowded at times, but that lively atmosphere is part of what makes it memorable.

Absolutely loved exploring the streets around Shinkesai and Tsutenkaku Tower. This area has such a unique Osaka energy ‚Äî vibrant, a bit nostalgic, and full of charm. Wandering through the narrow streets, neon signs, old-school eateries, and quirky shops felt like stepping into a different era of the city.
The atmosphere is lively but authentic, not overly touristy, which made the experience even more special.
Definitely a must-visit when in Osaka if you want something real, fun, and full of character. I‚Äôd go back in a heartbeat!
address: 2 Chome-5 Ebisuhigashi, Naniwa Ward, Osaka, 556-0002, Japan

name: Koyasan
address: Koyasan, Koya, Ito District, Wakayama 648-0211, Japan

name: Fish Market Tsukiji Outer Market
reviews:
This place gave my family one of our best food experiences in Japan ‚Äì and at an unbelievably cheap price, if you know the trick!

We arrived around 11am and the market was already packed with people. We were told they close around 1pm, so it was getting close to the end of the day. Instead of buying straight away, we decided to walk around first to check the prices and compare the different stalls. It‚Äôs very tempting to buy from the fancy-looking shops, but I‚Äôm so glad we explored a bit more.

That‚Äôs when we found a small, simple stall run by an elderly man. No fancy sushi displays, no stylish plating ‚Äì just honest, fresh tuna belly sashimi being cut right in front of us. The portions were incredibly generous, and the price was literally half of what the more commercial stalls were charging. He didn‚Äôt even have tables; it felt like he mainly sells to locals.

Even though he couldn‚Äôt really speak English, he was very friendly and tried his best to accommodate us. We ended up standing next to his fridge eating fresh tuna sashimi until we were completely full. It was such an authentic and memorable experience.

We‚Äôve been to several markets around Japan, but this was by far our best discovery. Amazing food, great value, and a truly local vibe. If you visit, take the time to explore ‚Äì you might just find the same hidden gem we did!

Highly recommended for anyone who loves fresh sashimi and real local experiences.

Such a fun place to eat, shop, and explore! There‚Äôs an amazing variety of food, from fresh seafood like melt-in-your-mouth tuna, sushi, oysters, and grilled scallops, to sweet treats like the popular egg desserts that are totally worth the wait. The market is lively, colorful, and full of energy, making it a great spot for photos as well. While prices have gone up and some shops feel more geared toward tourists, most of the food is still delicious. Shops do close early, so it‚Äôs best to come in the morning, but even visiting in the afternoon can be rewarding with some great discounts. Overall, it‚Äôs a must-visit for anyone looking to enjoy fresh food and soak in the vibrant market atmosphere.

If you‚Äôre a food lover, this iconic Tokyo destination belongs at the top of your travel list. Tsukiji Outer Market is a vibrant, bustling food paradise that delivers an unforgettable culinary experience for everyone ‚Äî from seasoned sushi aficionados to casual explorers.  Ôøº

From the moment you step into the maze of narrow streets lined with stalls and restaurants, you‚Äôll feel the energy and colour of one of Japan‚Äôs most legendary food districts. There‚Äôs a reason people call it Japan‚Äôs Food Town ‚Äî the mix of fresh seafood, local snacks, kitchen shops, and traditional eats is nothing short of spectacular.  Ôøº

Fresh, Affordable Seafood & Sushi
The seafood here is as fresh as it gets ‚Äî most of it delivered daily from the renowned Toyosu Market ‚Äî and that freshness shines in every bite, especially the sushi and sashimi. Whether you‚Äôre grabbing a classic nigiri plate, a giant kaisendon (seafood rice bowl), or sampling oysters and grilled tuna skewers, the quality is consistently excellent and often surprisingly affordable for Tokyo standards.  Ôøº

Something for Everyone
It‚Äôs not just seafood ‚Äî while fresh fish and sushi are major highlights, you‚Äôll also find a dazzling variety of street food and snacks. From fluffy tamagoyaki (Japanese sweet omelette) and grilled seafood to hearty miso soups and sweet pastries, the market offers mouthwatering options at every turn.  Ôøº

Lively Atmosphere & Local Culture
Part of what makes Tsukiji so special is the atmosphere ‚Äî a lively blend of locals and travellers exploring, chatting with vendors, picking up kitchen tools, knives, and other unique Japanese goods, and enjoying food on the spot. Go early in the morning to experience it at its best and beat the crowds before noon.  Ôøº

Perfect for All Types of Visitors
Whether you‚Äôre a sushi purist, a curious traveller, or visiting with family, there‚Äôs something here for everyone. It‚Äôs educational, adventurous, delicious ‚Äî and one of the best ways to dive into Tokyo‚Äôs food culture.

Tsukiji Outer Market is an exciting place to explore, where simply wandering around is enjoyable and every bite is tasty and filling. It‚Äôs highly recommended to walk through the market and sample some of the local favorites, especially the fresh sushi and incredible wagyu beef. The area is full of excellent dining options, though it does get very crowded and prices can be a bit high. Keep in mind you‚Äôll need cash and there‚Äôs an ATM available inside the market. If you‚Äôre visiting Japan, this spot is definitely worth a stop for an unforgettable food experience.

A food lover‚Äôs paradise! Tsukiji Outer Market is an absolute gem and one of the highlights of any trip to Tokyo. Even though the wholesale market moved to Toyosu, the outer market is still thriving with the same energy, incredible freshness, and unbeatable seafood.

The food here is simply amazing‚Äîsome of the best I‚Äôve ever had. From silky, melt-in-your-mouth otoro sushi and perfectly creamy uni to grilled scallops dripping with butter, fresh sashimi bowls bursting with flavor, and sweet tamagoyaki egg omelets, every bite is pure perfection. Everything tastes like it was caught that morning, and the variety of street stalls and small restaurants means you can hop from one delicious spot to the next.

The atmosphere is lively, authentic, and full of friendly vendors happy to share their craft. Come hungry, wander the alleys, and treat yourself to breakfast or lunch here‚Äîyou won‚Äôt regret it. A true Tokyo must-do!

name: Higashi Chaya District
reviews:
Visited Kanazawa & stayed at ANA Crowne Plaza for 3D2N. This hotel was so near to the bus station, train station & all malls & food eateries! So travelling around Kanazawa was made easy by getting a map as well as a transport day pass per person. The tourist info centre here rendered all the assistance we needed, so try to get everything there. We followed the map & their recommendations.

We arrived by their route bus to Higashi Chaya district. No queue. No entrance fees. Not too crowded as it was a pretty, nicely spread out district. However, it would be very much nicer if you could visit it in the late afternoon to night as the lightings were more beautiful.

Pleasant slow walk, for about an hour & a half. There were tourists getting snacks & ice cream in different parts of the districts. Small cafes & eateries spread around here. We were not hungry after our heavy breakfast so we were gamed for a walk only. It was rows & rows of old houses, still liveable & well maintained. Fresh air & clean environment. Saw a wedding possession  in a Japanese shrine I would deem it special. Quite a private one & a priest was holding the ceremony for the couple.

At all the bus-stops, the directional signs were clear. Route buses always had passengers we could ask for help, but we usually looked at maps, listened to the announcements made in buses, or followed the crowds to alight. Besides, there were plenty of taxis around too. No one could get lost here.

Do visit if you have the time.

Higashi Chaya District („Å≤„Åå„ÅóËå∂Â±ãË°ó) is a beautiful and atmospheric place to visit in Kanazawa. The preserved wooden teahouses and traditional streets really make you feel like you‚Äôve stepped back into old Japan. It‚Äôs especially lovely in the morning or late afternoon when it‚Äôs less crowded and the light is perfect for photos.

There are many small cafes, souvenir shops, gold-leaf desserts, and traditional sweets to try. Even just walking around and soaking in the calm, historic vibe is worth it. It‚Äôs clean, well maintained, and very walkable.

Highly recommended if you enjoy history, culture, photography, or just a relaxing stroll in a traditional setting.

The main street is a bit touristy but the neighbourhood is quite lovely and colourful, I much preferred coming here than to Nagamachi Samurai District. You‚Äôll see many people wearing kimono (mostly for picture taking), and it‚Äôs quite fun. Many shops and caf√©s, and there‚Äôs one place that offers workshops about gold leafing but you have to book that in advance.
