This was our first experience in this beautiful part. We enjoyed the cute red trees that transformed into a red color. We liked the rides in the amusement park as well.

However, it would be nice if all the information were given a little bit more clearly.

For example, the Ferris wheel. We were in line at the Ferris wheel for about 10-15 minutes already until we saw someone cut the line. We realized that we were in the wrong line.

Moreover, the information for the one-day pass option for unlimited amusement rides should be at the entrance.

One complaint is that all the paper tickets you need are inconvenient to hold on to and use.

We held six different tickets while visiting the park.  Perhaps if they combine all the tickets into one, everyone will benefit from this in the future.

A small reminder, this place is near the ocean. That means there are strong winds so I would suggest that you bring a warm jacket with you.

Breathtaking flower paradise!
Hitachi Seaside Park is absolutely stunning ‚Äî a must-visit for nature and photography lovers. The seasonal flowers, especially the blue nemophila in spring and red kochia in autumn, create incredible views that look like a painting. The park is wide, clean, and beautifully maintained, perfect for walking, cycling, or just relaxing in nature. A peaceful and unforgettable day trip from Tokyo!

name: Shiraito Falls
reviews:
The Shirato Falls are worth a climb down and back up the stairs! They are beautiful and on a sunny day you can see multiple rainbows hovering in front of them. When travelling here by car try to avoid the men waiving you toward their car parks. Prices for parking range from ¬•150 up to ¬•500 for a normal car. But you can park for free if you go slightly further from the falls.
Also, from some points you can catch the Shiraito Falls and Mt. Fuji in one photo shot.

We drove from tokyo, north around fuji stopping at places along the way, including Shiraito Falls. There is a 500 yen charge to park your car but plenty of space. A short 1-1.5km loop with great views. Small shops and food stalls, surprisingly well priced, on the walk down. Visited in early December so many of the autumn leaves had fallen but still plenty of green. Well kept paths but be prepared for a few stairs, some being a bit steep. If you are already doing the loop around fuji, add this to the list.

We visited Shiraito Falls on a cloudy and rainy day, but despite the weather, it turned out to be such a memorable experience for all seven of us in the family. The soft drizzle actually made the surroundings feel more magical as the mist from the falls blended beautifully with the fog, giving the whole place a dreamlike atmosphere. The sound of the cascading water was so soothing, and the lush greenery around us looked even more vibrant under the rain.
What made the visit even more special was that, just for a brief moment, the clouds parted and we caught a glimpse of Mount Fuji in the distance. It felt like a small gift from nature after waiting patiently in the rain. The walking paths were easy to follow, though a little slippery, and we took our time enjoying every view along the way.
Even with wet shoes and umbrellas in hand, we couldn‚Äôt help but smile. There was something peaceful about being surrounded by nature, hearing the water roar, and feeling the cool mist on our faces. Shiraito Falls truly lived up to its name as one of Japan‚Äôs most beautiful waterfalls, rain and all.

So beautiful! This place took me totally by surprise with its beauty. Lots of tourists here but fir a good reason and if you decide the walk into the park you'll barely see any tourists there and the views are fantastic. The scenery around the waterfalls is breathtaking.

A beautiful sight which you can only dream of seeing. This lovely view, with several waterfalls. Was able to experience a rainbow at the center of all the waterfalls.

The serene walk from the street, coupled with several little shops with roasted chestnuts, and souvenirs. Leading to several stone stairs leading down to the bridge where you can view the lovely waterfalls from afar. Once coming close up to them, you a fresh mist of water and a breath of fresh air blasting your nose.

After several pictures, there is a path with stairs leading up to one of few viewing decks, where you can see through the many colorful trees, a view of Mt. Fuji-san. A view you can only see in pictures and post cards.

The cool air brought a joyous feeling to our faces, and would recommend family, friends, and couples to definitely visit.

name: TOHO Cinemas Shinjuku
reviews:
So this review is on the hotel, not cinema.  When leaving the East exit from Shinjuku station, you only have to walk straight about 500m to the hotel, super easy to find.  When you enter, the lobby is on the 8th floor and the elevators only stop one the 1st and 8th floors.  The hotel lobby is very clean with a lot of decor.  There is a sweet Godzilla display with Godzilla and three other monsters.

Checking in was very easy.  I was so lucky to be able to have Godzilla room on the 30th floor.

There is a Godzilla theme bar if that is your flavor as well in the lobby

The terrance to go out and see the Godzilla head is/was closed so to "issues".  My gut feeling is stupid people were climbing on the head to take pictures.  So right now you can not go out there.  Still really cool to see.

Unfortunately, I am not going to talk about what my room looks like.  The surprise is worth it.  I recommend not seeing too many pictures of the room so you can get the true experience.  I can say the room was very clean, and fun to be in.

Would I stay here again?  Yes, however the only downfall is the location from the airport.  If your final destination is this hotel, getting back to the airport can be a pain if your using public transportation.  If you taxi, your looking at about 11,000 yen.  Trust me that is worth it if you have a lot of luggage.

For folks that want to do the experience, so it.  If you can get any of Godzilla theme rooms, do it.  You only live once.

Had an absolute blast here! Went to see Tron: Ares cause was listed as Sub (So knew it would be in English). The concession prices were fair, and they had a little scoopable candy option! Made a fun movie candy mix! Seats were comfortable enough, and the gift shop had some awesome classic movie gifts! Plus the view from the window was quite awesome! And Godzilla was next door!

Great option to watch your favorite movie while eating the classic popcorns and your favorite drinks. (I recommend the set combo for two so that you can enjoy both caramel and salty popcorn)Clean and comfy the facilities are upstairs. Book in advance!

It's a large cinema complex with Godzilla! It offers great location and many movies in different formats. They also serve food and drinks including alcoholic drinks. You should book a seat before you go and can be very busy.

Well organized Cinema! We watched the new Demon Slayer Movie!‚öîÔ∏è HINOKAMI KAGURAüî•üî• I enjoyed the overall experience. We even got a little present from the movie!!! The seats are a bit narrow tho. If you're from a western country you'll immediately feel the difference especially if you're over 180cm. If the movie is over 2h it might get a tiny bit uncomfortable The quality of the Projectors are top notch and it's nice to see that everyone respects the rules and is quiet even tho the theater was completely filled.
address: Japan, „Äí160-0021 Tokyo, Shinjuku City, Kabukich≈ç, 1-ch≈çme‚àí19‚àíÔºë Shinjuku Toho Building, ÔºìÈöé

name: Takaragawa Onsen Osenkaku
reviews:
This Onsen was the highlight of our Japan trip. We went the first week of November at the peak of fall colors and I couldn't believe how beautiful it was. Our room was right above the river and we had such a good view. The indoor and outdoor baths were clean and lovely to enjoy. I could not give this location a higher recommendation. The service and respect from the staff was top notch and we really enjoyed staying there. Having everyone in Yukatas was an added bonus - really added to the theme.

Some notes as mentioned in other reviews:
1)They only serve breakfast and dinner so you'll want to either bring cash to buy some ramen from the gift shop or bring some food in for lunch.
2)Yes they could dust more and get of some of the cobwebs on the ceilings. I'm tall and there were many short beams and ceilings I had to duck under. Hit my head a fair amount of times and had some cobwebs in my hair lol
3)They do not have western style beds and you sleep on a few tatami mats with comforters. I don't have an issue with these sleeping arrangements, but just something to note if you are more comfortable sleeping on softer surfaces

Overall - very relaxing and enjoyable experience. I would recommend going in fall/winter to avoid bugs (Nov - Mar).

WORTH THE PRICE & JOURNEY!

The Osenkaku located in the mountains of the Gunma, is one of the best traditional Inn i stayed in. From flawless pickup and welcome to winsome food and customer service, its a place where one would definitely come back again.

Having a checkin at 4pm, the hotel provide complimentary from the nearest JR Local (Minakami) & Shinkansen (Jomokogen) stations beforehand; the gentleman bus driver found us (Grp of 5) from inside the ticketing area of the station and guided us to the bus. At the Hotel, we were welcomed by the staff where checkin was doing along with a introduction to the Onsen, its rules & other facilities. The staff promptly helped with any basic queries as it was our first time in a Japaneses Onsen; along with helping in choosing the right Yukata and coat. Later too, they will make the beddings too when the guests are having the Dinner.

The Hotel itself is quite huge and have certain area which are not disable-friendly; since its quite old but well maintained. The Onsen is connected with a bridge where there are common pools and a dedicated pool for women. Bathrobe (suited for 6ft+) for the pool is provided and there are gendered changing rooms, showers and dryers available too next to onsen pools.

The Meals are quite exquisite and extensive Japanese items. Prior arrangements is made for any allergies. All the meals are served in the Restaurant.

beautiful and amazing trip with family. we came just in time to see the beautiful autumn foliage. as its my first time being in japan in autumn, and coming to the countryside outside of major cities like tokyo, this was such a beautiful retreat from the hustle and bustle of rhe city. the onsens were wonderful and mixed gender public onsen was great for family time! while the gender separated ones were perfect for some personal time relaxing after a long day of travelling and exploring the region. Of course, in true japanese hospitality style, we enjoyed delicious meals (we stayed for 3 days) for breakfast and dinner ‚Äî everyone in our family, both young and old, enjoyed it greatly. Its definitely a trip to remember!

Social media promotes this place well. There are four outside baths, three mixed and one female only. The shower rooms aren‚Äôt near the baths. I am not certain that anyone washes up when it is freezing cold out; it just isn‚Äôt really feasible. You are required to wear bathing garments in the mixed bath. At my visit, all of the women were wearing garments in the outdoor female bath. The indoor bath was nicer for me, didn‚Äôt need to trek in the cold, and had the standard bathing facilities‚Ä¶ garments were prohibited. The scenery is wonderful in the area. The food was on par with other ryokans.

The walk to the outdoor baths is uncomfortable when it is freezing cold outside.

This is still the place to stay if you want to visit this area.

I spent one night here, 12/29/25.

You cannot beat the view and onsen. It‚Äôs stunning (just a bit colder than I wanted). This is not the ‚Äúlocal Japanese ryokan‚Äù experience I was looking for, though. It was 95% tourists/non-Japanese and catered for it. Food was good, but mild as a result and the signs everywhere bossing us around were kinda of a lot and entirely in English. The room was spacious, but just very old. Indoor bathes and outdoor changing rooms need a touch up. It‚Äôs perfect for a couple, though. I would not recommend for a family or solo traveler.
address: 1899 Fujiwara, Minakami, Tone District, Gunma 379-1721, Japan

name: teamLab Borderless: MORI Building DIGITAL ART MUSEUM
reviews:
About a 10 minute wait once you arrive.
You have to watch a quick video and how to go through the exhibits, that the rooms change and theres no path, you go at your own pace.

We enjoyed it a lot, spent about 4 hours in there and we still somehow couldn't find the Tea Room. I started to get Zenn'ed out but my partner loved it. There is a small resting area, and a water refill station by the bathrooms if you have a refillable water container.

Amazing displays. Only bothersome thing was the parents who let their kids run wild, screaming and damaging the displays. Staff would ask them nicely to not pull and bend pieces but the kids would ignore it to the point I was starting to get upset, as well as a few others trying to enjoy the displays.

Would recc as its a fun first experience and the artistic setups and displays were just amazing. My videos and pictures don't showcase it well enough.

TeamsLab Borderless was an experience that played into your sense of sight, touch, and hearing. If you want a full experience, it is encouraged to download the app, which has more information on each respective room and pieces. True to its name it‚Äôs really borderless, as you‚Äôll see the different art pieces go into different areas to create unique circumstances. Some pieces also made me feel small as there seemed no end to it!. With art pieces drifting to different areas, this means you‚Äôll experience something new as you revisit rooms.

I went with some friends around 2:30 PM on a Monday. It was pretty busy at that time. We spent about 1.5 hours here at a moderate pace of exploring and revisiting spaces. I had a great first time experience and would love to revisit in the future.

An amazing place you MUST go! You will have a totally new and unforgettable experience. There are many rooms in the place, each has its special lights and music, some are so addictive, I can stay there and watch the lights keep changing to lots of different gorgeous pictures for whole day.

Everyone is so enjoyable, no matter kids or adults. You can miss senso-ji, but you can‚Äôt miss this!

We booked same day for 330-4pm entry timeslot.  The mall in which this installation is located is large but there are clear directions everywhere to find teamLab.  We took advantage of the free lockers to store our winter coats.  We waited a short while before watching a mandatory video (rules, safety) before entering.
We enjoyed our time here although it was quite busy - Sunday afternoon is probably not ideal!  - especially if you want to take photos without some stranger appearing in the photo.
We did not experience the tea room as the online booking option was not available (sold out).we stayed between 1-1.5hours.  It‚Äôs something I can go to again easily as I didn‚Äôt see all the art work - each room will have different art at different times, so you are encouraged to return to rooms/areas you have already visited.

Absolutely breathtaking and unforgettable

teamLab Borderless at the MORI Building was truly an unreal experience. From the moment you step inside, you‚Äôre completely immersed in a world of light, color, and movement. Every room felt like a living piece of art‚Ä¶constantly changing and flowing, so no two moments felt the same.

What I loved most is how interactive and limitless it felt. There‚Äôs no set path, which makes the experience feel personal and exploratory, like you‚Äôre discovering something new at every turn. The visuals were stunning, calming.. definitely a place where you can slow down and really be present.

Pictures don‚Äôt even do it justice. This is a must see if you‚Äôre visiting Tokyo and enjoy art, technology, or unique experiences that stay with you long after you leave. I would 100% go again.
address: Japan, „Äí106-0041 Tokyo, Minato City, Toranomon, 5-ch≈çme‚àí9‚àíÔºô Azabudai Hills Garden Plaza B, B1

name: Arashiyama
reviews:
Arashiyama was absolutely beautiful during our visit in late November, right in the peak of momiji season. The combination of colorful autumn leaves, the calm river, and the iconic scenery around Togetsukyo Bridge created a very peaceful and scenic atmosphere.

Walking through Arashiyama with my wife and kids felt relaxed and enjoyable. The area is spacious, stroller-friendly, and offers plenty of spots to slow down, take photos, and enjoy nature together. From the bamboo grove to the riverside views, everything felt timeless and memorable‚Äîone of the highlights of our family trip to Japan.

Maaf kalau a

Arashiyama is a beautiful escape from the busier parts of Kyoto‚Äîpeaceful, scenic, and full of nature and culture. While most people rush straight to the Bamboo Forest, I personally felt it was skippable, especially if you‚Äôre visiting during peak hours. The bamboo path is iconic in photos, but in reality it can get crowded quickly, and the experience feels a little rushed.

What truly makes Arashiyama special, in my opinion, are its temples and surrounding nature. Places like Tenry≈´-ji, J≈çjakk≈ç-ji, and Nison-in offer a far more tranquil and meaningful experience. The temple grounds are beautifully maintained, rich in history, and surrounded by stunning seasonal scenery. Walking through these places gave me a sense of calm that the bamboo grove didn‚Äôt quite deliver.

The Katsura River area is another highlight. The gentle flow of the water against the backdrop of mountains makes for an incredibly relaxing stroll, perfect for photos, snacks, or just soaking in the atmosphere.

Arashiyama is full of charming streets, traditional sweets, and little shops worth exploring. But the real gems are the quieter corners- temple gardens, forested pathways, and scenic viewpoints that let you enjoy Kyoto‚Äôs beauty at your own pace.

Overall, Arashiyama is definitely worth visiting, but I‚Äôd recommend skipping the Bamboo Forest crowds and spending more time at the temples instead. You‚Äôll get a more peaceful, authentic, and memorable experience. üçÅüåø‚ú®

Very nice and relaxing bamboo forest place.  This little cute and chill town has this bamboo forest that is well known worldwide, it is such greenery and make you completely relax walking through it walk pathways - it‚Äôs not long, I would say about 30mins and you could covered all of it pathways.  There is alway a pathways just for jinrikisha (traditional Japanese carriage) quite nice and romantic too.  There is a burial site and I guess a temple within it.  Also there is a railroad and once in awhile you can see a rain speeding by. It‚Äôs definitely a picturesque place and yes tourist is high here.  Once you‚Äôre done, you can so spend time walking around the town with shops, street snacks, restaurants, coffee shops, temple, cross over the river for more shops, cafe, etc.  very lovely and relaxing little town with lots of tourist for sure but still keeping the tradition culture for sure.  Got to love the Japanese.

Bamboo forest is good place to visit. Can be crowdy and the pathway is a little rocky (gravel). The walk to the bamboo forest isn't long, you might stumble across one of the pokemon manhole, which I did. Fairly easy location to travel to from Osaka/Kyoto.

One of my favorite places in Japan. The scenery in all seasons are just amazing. Was here several times in Spring during full Sakura bloom and now in fall for the colors. Amazing. Can‚Äôt possibly explore the whole area in a day.
address: Arashiyama Genrokuzancho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto, 616-0007, Japan

name: Cup Noodles Museum Osaka Ikeda
reviews: We love our experience here. The staff always treat us with so much warmth. We started off with making our own cup noodles. It was 500 yen each,you can buy up to 3 cups per person. You will be ushered to start your drawing and then pick your desired ingredients and soup flavours. After they will pack it up,and you vacuumed it into your own take away bag. Super cute. I think we got really lucky, the staff gave us an opportunity to do the chicken ramen experience.(1000 yen per pax) The whole duration took 70 mins but it was the best experience. Heard from the staff that spots are limited and need prior reservations. When enter the room in level 2, you get to change to apron and a cute chick bandana. The staff was so patient and lovely in guiding us step by step on how to make the ramen. If you have young children, this will be a very educational and fun experience for the little ones. ü©∑ I truly enjoy my time.

A wonderful blast from the past! Got to customise my own cup noodle that came with choice of dried ingredients and a soup base.

Paid for the ramen-making workshop too which was quite interesting. Got to make the noodles from scratch. Great hands-on activity for children. It would be good to get the tickets first upon arrival at the museum.

Fun activity in Osaka and a must visit. This place has something for every age group.

The first floor has numbered cup noodle exhibits. The numbers help you navigate an online audio tour to learn more about each exhibit.

At the end of the exhibits is an area where you get a personal cup noodle container from a vending machine for 500¬•, which you can design and color as you like. At the end you take the container to the final section where they put in the noodles, add seasoning (you get to select 1 from the 4 available seasonings), add some toppings (you get to select 4 from all available toppings), then seal and shrink wrap it. You get to place your own cup noodles in an inflated bag to carry as a souvenir.

On the second floor, you get to make your own ramen. It's an interesting experience where they walk you through each step of the process. At intervals when the dough is left to rest and the noodles are being fried, you get to design and color your ramen packets. The entire session is very well organized and time driven. You need an advance reservation for this experience, costs 1000¬• per person and needs to be done in pairs.

This museum is a very nice way to preserve and remember the legacy of the inventor of cup noodles, and to impart the underlying principle in visitors that even the simplest ideas can change the world if you pursue it with conviction.

The only thing i did not like about this place is that there is no dining area in the museum (even though one presentation mentioned that there is one where you can try out some cup noodles). It would be fun to try out some tasty cup noodles after spending about 2.5 hours in the premises.

Our teenage kids (13 and 14) both had fun decorating their noodles! We are cup noodles people and this experience was enjoyable for us as a family. No need for reservations. Just go in and register and pay for the cup you will be decorating (500yen per cup). For the noodle making though, it needs advance reservations and at this time (Oct 30), the next available slots are December already!

Place is not that big so we finished in an hour. It was quite organized and instructions are also written. There were staff too to guide you for the next step. After decorating, you‚Äôll line up to choose your ingredients and soup base.

There were not many people though there was a school kindergarten students who were having their trip hete which was so cute.

There is also a room where you can sit and watch a video. Unfortunately, the video is in japanese so we couldnt quite understand. After the noodle making, there is an exhibit outside which also do not have english. There is however an audio guide you can listen to when you scan the qr code.

Noodles has expiration date of 1 month.
What a unique experience of decorating your own cup noodles. I am sure the kids would love doing it.

This was a great surprise as it was very fun and exciting even for adults, the day I went there were more adults than children at first there was a hands on experience decorating your own pot noodle pot before choosing the contents. Highly recommend for anyone and everyone to visit. The museum itself is small but extremely interesting.

name: SAMURAI NINJA MUSEUM Kyoto
reviews: INCREDIBLE! my husband and i visited kyoto on our honeymoon and thankfully stumbled upon this amazing museum. mami was our tour guide, and she was seriously the most knowledgeable, friendly, and fun guide we could ever ask for. this is an interactive tour. mr. jin was our ninja teacher and he was fun, too!! if you don‚Äôt speak japanese, please don‚Äôt worry. the staff here are very talented! if you are a fellow japanese history nerd, or you just want to pass some time, please visit! thank you

Really great experience. The tour guide Sayo was so good. Her English was great and she was very engaging and funny with her storytelling, yet very informative. My husband and I learnt a lot from this museum. Part of the tour included throwing the ninja stars as well, which was fun. They also give you an opportunity to dress up as samurai or ninja at the end of the tour included in the cost.

The Samurai Ninja Museum was so good! Our tour guide Maya was amazing, super knowledgeable, funny and lovely! A very insightful and interesting experience into Japans history. Very fun and cool! Highly recommend! Thankyou for the shuriken! Thankyou Maya!

Great experience!!! The employees are very friendly and engaging. The sword samurai experience was really cool and epic, got to learn the way of a samurai. Shout out to Kubo-san for teaching us the way. Then the museum tour was very insightful and also engaging. Tao-san made it very fun to watch and listen to. Would recommend!!

We had such an amazing time visiting the Ninja Museum in Kyoto! Our tour guide, Ms. Yuki, was fantastic, very friendly and knowledgeable. She explained so much about the history of samurai and ninjas, and we learned a lot during the tour.

The best part was getting to experience being a ninja ourselves! We got to try throwing the ninja star weapons (shuriken), which was really fun. The kids especially loved it, they even got to dress up in ninja and samurai costumes.

Overall, it was a fun and educational experience for the whole family. Highly recommended if you‚Äôre visiting Kyoto!

name: Gujo Hachiman Castle
reviews:
Visited on a Saturday afternoon and it was not that crowded.
Had a stroll uphill with autumn leaves around.
The slope path was shared with cars so be careful.
If you take the stairs, it‚Äôs faster but quite uneven.

I visited Gujo last week, as well as almost exactly one year ago. And despite it not being an original castle, I very much love this one as much as the original 12 because they have rebuilt the interior out of wood instead of concrete.

The walk around the outer wall is so gorgeous, as well as the views from the tower. Staff are always wonderful and the parking lot right next door is free. What more could you ask for?

The Castel is very well preserved.  It is a small one compared to the Himeji Castel. It has a museum inside but only in Japanese.  The artifacts showed are interesting and well preserved and the views are beautiful.
There is a parking place close to the Castel if you dare to drive the uphill very narrow road that is one way.

The walk towards the castle was fun. I thought the castle was fully renovated but not really. It‚Äôs still wood with creaking noises. ü§≠ The view from the castle was great too. Definitely gonna visit Gujo Hachiman in a different season.

There‚Äôs a souvenir shop and a snack bar outside the castle beside the ticket booth.

I am usually not interested in visiting castles, but this one seemed to have a really nice view of Gujo town, so here we were.

The visiting route is well thought out, with signs pointing out popular photo spots along the way.

We drove up to the castle grounds where there is free parking. The road is very narrow, so you have to watch out for pedestrians. The parking can get full, but traffic is well controlled at the parking lot, and we waited a bit for a space.

There is a small fee to enter the castle, and it is worth it because the view from inside is even nicer.
address: Japan, „Äí501-4214 Gifu, Gujo, Hachimanch≈ç Yanagimachi, ÔºñÔºïÔºô ‰∏Ä„ÅÆÂπ≥ ÔºñÔºïÔºô
